38591686.review: Interesting and entertaining. Lightly touches on some interesting questions about AI, but disappointedly doesn't go very deep with any of them. Some paths have minor continuity problems, like Elly reveals to you some secret about her past, and then later, you she explains the secret to you again, almost word for word, and your character acts like it's the first time they hear it. There are actually several full stories in here and it'll take multiple playthroughs to experience them all. Your choices really do matter here, and you go through completely different sequences of events depending on what choices you make, unlike the typical Telltale game, for example, where no matter what choices you make, the broad strokes of the plot remain the same. Well written. I did not notice any spelling or grammar mistakes.

38434504.review:
I'm not finished this game yet, but I feel compelled to write a review. I played the demo and immediately bought the full version to continue. I'm just wrapping up Chapter 3 at the time of writing. (Update: I have finished the game now, so continue reading for extra thoughts.)

As a security researcher with a massive passion for technology, this is so far one of the most interesting, endearing, and believable stories I've ever had the pleasure of experiencing. Nothing feels very forced or vague. I don't have to suspend my disbelief very much, and the more specific references to technology and security are jarringly realistic.

This is less of an "I, Robot" type of universe, and more of a heavy, introspective look into what the real world could be looking like in the not-so-distant future. The choices are very fulfilling, and none of them feel like they are designed to trick me or force me down any specific path.

(Update: This game can tell many stories in the same setting, and I was able to guide the narrative away from any tropes that I wasn't too fond of -- but I saw the options there, ready to be picked by anybody who might enjoy them.)

Edit: I just finished the whole thing in one session. The updated points above have some new thoughts from this perspective. I got a really touching ending. It's clear that my ending could have been more touching, or less touching, depending on what choices I made earlier. I also got an achivement for surviving until the end of the story. Everything in my review is still just as true as it was before, if not more true. Buy it!

I would recommend this game for anybody even remotely interested in this style of interactive fiction.

38249102.review: The first Choice of Games game I played. Though you can't really call it a game, it's more of an interactive novel. The story is incredibly compelling, and it's made better by the fact that the outcome is at least somewhat unique to you. After Robots I looked into more of Choice of Games' work. Because it comes from multiple independent authors there is no real way to tell if a game or series is going to be interesting, but so far I've only found a few that I absolutely cannot get into after at least pushing through the first chapter or two. As for Robots in particular, well, [spoiler] after building an iRobot style companion, homeschooling him to about the intelligence of an adolescent, creating a company to make a bunch of smaller, less intelligent versions of him to sell out for mining labor and such, fleeing to Canada to prevent the U.S. gov. from kidnapping an reverse engineering him, creating a more intelligent female version to be his companion, having her fall in love with me and spurn her advances, fighting for robot civil rights, then allowing him to build his own son, I spent the final moments of the book surrounded by my robotic children and closest friends. [/spoiler] Whats in the spoiler text is just the bigger plot points that I can remember off the top of my head. There are tons of details and scenes and decisions in between those bigger moments, and chances are you'll go off on a totally different path early on. I highly recommend not only playing this game but looking into all of Choice of Games' selection, especially if you're a reader.

36686007.review:
At first, I saw this game and was a bit repulsed by it after I started playing. However, as I continued playing, I found myself more and more interested in the story. You're presented with a series of events out of your control, and your choices determine how those events develop. Simple enough, right? But as time goes by you realize just how deep and important each of these questions asked is, and soon you begin to be really invested in the story and where it all goes. It presents you with your life, you decide where you go, how you act, and these actions are not without consequence.

All in all, it's a text based game with an emphasis on your own choices, your own beliefs, and while quite broad at first, slowly narrow down towards the end of the story to become more and more personal. The game is definitely worth the buy in my opinion, but I would say that you should play this game alone and with as few breaks as possible in order to maintain the attachment to the story and characters.

I really, really liked this game, and I think you will too.

35360984.review:
SPOILER WARNING!
YOU HAVE BEEN WARNED!!

You can make a robot with a arm cannon like Megaman! :D

Where was I? Oh, the review.

It's a great game, and if you enter your actual name as the protagonist's, it feels more real. There are funny moments ("Why am I dreaming in political cartoons?") and serious ones (Such as choosing whether or not to get surgery to remove a genetic desease, at the cost of the Charcter's emotions) but it all flows together very well. There's a stats screen as well, and some stats influence later decisions. There's the fame stat (which is how well known you are), Wealth (which influences several decisions) and a way to see who your character is married to (or seeing) with the Romance stat. The robot you build has stats too, such as Autonomy (how well it can move), Military (how weaponized it is), Empathy (emotions) and Grace. There's achivements as well, but you can't get them all in one playthough, which is fitting; a person can't do everything in their lifetime. It also has a few moments that makes you ask yourself questions, but I'll let you figure those out.

Overall, it's an amazing game. If nothing else, use your actual name as the protagonist's and give it a blind run. You'll be pleasantly surprised.

35170634.review:
Going into this game I had no idea what this was really. Upon starting, it seemed to be just a big wall of uniteresting text. However, once I went beyond it, I realized I had discovered a gem of a game. In my first game I created a robot similar to that of a synth, started an international corporation, sold robots to the American military to fight in a war, became a war hero, then started a rebellion in Alaska, only to die fighting rather than fleeing. The next game I created a robot nearly identical to that of a child, worked with my friend in a robot toy business, converted my child robots into military robots, developed extremely realistic human looking soldiers, and made companion bots that were nearly indistinguishable from humans, marrying one in the process and starting a family with her raising a human child and my original robot child. The game is written like a sort of fanfiction which really isn't a problem in my opinion. 

It tells like a story and I love it. I have played through this game about 4-5 times trying to min-max my decisions to achieve the most success and get different endings. After staying up an extra several hours to play this rather than sleep I stayed up longer just to plan out how I can get new endings and better scenarios. I highly recommend this game and I hope that the other games like this are just as good, but I doubt they are as quality as this lovely game.

This isn't the sort of game I'm used to playing, but I think it really won me over to interactive fiction! The science fiction is very tame and believable, and it focuses much more on the human and emotional element than any philosophy problem we're tired of hearing by now. And even beyond the premise, there's something really fascinating and beautiful about simulating a person's entire life from young adulthood to old age (at least if you survive to the end). This element works really well because the author seems to be very knowledgeable about not only the technological and political processes he describes, but also how human beings tend to act. I was most immersed in the game when I felt helpless, when the game's sense of society and personality sort of crescendoed into waves of forces outside my control. 

It's great stuff.

33815379.review:
I was very excited for this game considering all the positive reviews. After an hour of "gameplay", I decided to refund it. I can feel that this game was someone's love child, and that someone (or group of someones) really tried for this to succeed. But I just couldn't bring myself to "play" this "game" any further. It hurts a little to give this a negative review, but I'll have to be honest.

To be clear: The concept of this game seems very promising, especially since I personally love the SciFi genre. I expected something like "Ex Machina" or the unfortunately not very well known TV series "Humans". Sadly, my expectations were not met.

[b]My critique en detail:[/b]

[b]–[/b] As someone else already mentioned, the writing style was that of a mediocre fan fiction. If you know what I mean by that, you'll know what I mean.
[b]–[/b] Relating to that, the characters were extremely one-dimensional, and no identification took place. Neither with the main character (me) nor with any of the other characters. They kind of just existed, but had no personality. All in all, the writing was bad. Considering this is a purely writing based game, this is a major issue. There was no immersion. When I felt something interesting was happening, I raised my hope only to be let down, because this topic was so quickly dropped again. I finally didn't even care for the text anymore, and just read the answers. That was when I decided to end the game because it had simply lost me.
[b]–[/b] And relating to that, there is a lot of wasted potential (as seems to be a common theme with this game). I chose Josh's story path. My character and Josh knew each other for years now, and my character was secretly in love with him. In the context of building my robot, my character finally came out to Josh, and saw that Josh felt the same for him. This could have been a major theme. Instead they very anti-climactically just kiss, spend the night together, and from then on are a couple. And the writing is not much more excited about this than I am in this review. And that is bad. I would like to compare this to Pam's and Jim's romance in The Office. They loved eachother, but couldn't be together. When they finally kissed, Jim didn't simply say "ok cool", but there was so much emotion going on. This was totally lacking here.
[b]–[/b] The author is clearly forcing a certain POV that I really don't agree with. As someone who is very much into ethics, I would have loved to decide my approach for myself. But generally, I could only decide between different POVs the author had, not my own.
[b]–[/b] The choices were way too specific so that there was no real immersion. Someone else wrote a review where they critizised this. There were no simple options, but with options came an agenda attached (instead of "You may call me by my name", it said something like "you may call me by my name because you are not an object, but a person"). Or I didn't agree with any of the choices, but I still had to chose one. Again, those were the author's choices, and not my own. With choices a little more general and not that specific, this could have been avoided, probably.
[b]–[/b] Everything seems a little bit too easy and convenient. There was no twist, no sense for reality, but simply: [i]chose A[/i] -> [i]get A[/i], [i]chose B[/i] -> [i]get B[/i].
[b]–[/b] As someone else has pointed out, the story sometimes doesn't add up. At some time I decide to go to a party with Josh, my significant other. Later, when he calls me, it is as if that never happened. And instead I can either go without him, or with him to a monster truck show (and not to the party). So my previous choice didn't matter. And not in a narratological sense, but simply based on the programming itself. This is frustrating.
[b]–[/b] I get that this game is based on writing alone, but the complete absence of anything visual besides the text was making the experience bland and uninteresting. I don't expect cut scenes or anything, but some kind of graphical design would have been nice.

I will have to give this game a "no". But, of course, everyone should see for themselves. I didn't like this "game", but apparently some people do. I was disappointed, but ultimately, this game is not trash. It's only lacking. Lacking very hard.

33469891.review:
*Finishes first playthrough*

Holy

Shit


I started out the game attempting to create a hyper intelligent robot that could lead humanity to greatness. I ended up creating a robot that started an AI revolution that stopped a massive war, fucked over our corrupt government, and worked with me to make a world were man and machine live together in a libertarian North America. My brainchild went through multiple stages during my time with her. She went from niave, to rebellious, to suicidally depressed, and finally building a child. To say that this game is an emotional rollercoaster is an understatement. You will go through multiple stages of your character's life, balancing relationships and teaching your robot your values. My character led a lonely life, having only a few friends and family to accompany him on his journey. He gave up on romance early on to focus on his creation and career. He sacrificed his chance at a normal life to make the world better, will you do the same? Or will you focus on another aspect of life? What will your creation look and act like? The only answer is to try the game. My experience will stick with me for years to come. My only major criticism is that I couldn't spent more time with my little Materia.

*proceeds to have an existential crisis*



Glass of Water master race



Seriously though, buy this game if you even remotely like CYOA stories.

33450500.review:
Choice of Robots is the game I always wanted. It's deep, punishing, joyous, and so very genuine. I love that this story is as much about who you are, and who you become, as it is about the world you inevitably change in very real ways. 

We sit back and judge triple A games on it's 3 endings with different colored cutscenes; but CoR is so much deeper and enjoyable for it's design. I'm torn between describing it as a game, as much as it is a novel that unfolds to your hopes and inclinations. Every decision made creates a very real impact in your story, and I respect the design choice not to allow for backtracking; as now everything you do has weight. 

If I might make a recommendation beyond 'buy this game now!'; it's that you don't try to min-max things. I'll confess I'm guilty of always trying to get 'the best' outcome in most games I play; but Choice of Robots drew me away from that direction. It rewards your mistakes as often as it punishes or ignores your wisdom, and like life; makes you wonder if you made the right choice at every turn.

32053837.review:
I paid $7 for Choice of Robots, and it lasted for around 2 hours. I was entertained, and don't regret the decision.

I've played interactive fiction before, and both seasons of The Walking Dead. Although I enjoyed them, and The Walking Dead was super polished, they did not provide the same experience as Choice of Robots.

You see, in the other games, I felt like there was only so much freedom allowed, and that certain outcomes were absolute. Of course I know that there aren't limitless choices in any game of this kind. Still, I felt like each of the decisions made in Choice of Robots contributed to an end that I influenced.

This could mean that there is a lot of plot branching in Choice of Robots, or it could simply be that the game doesn't allow multiple saves, so you don't get to easily see the illusion. It's essentially a rogue-like. You can start over, but other than that, your decisions stand.

I'm torn about whether or not I should play this again. Another play through is just me trying to get a glimpse into the game's inner workings. That could ruin the experience for me. If I do play it again, I will update this review.

The author was smart to provide a demo. It was enough to draw me in for the sale. It's a fast download, and worth a try.

31476919.review:
Choice of Robots.. Where to begin.

There are so many routes and options that you can choose in this story (with major plot points unraveling and rejoining in a different manner) that I played this through about 4 times so far. With that said, I NEVER replay games or reread stories, but this here, i did 4 times, simply because it feels like a different story each and every time. 

I highly recommend this to anybody who enjoys fiddling with the idea of a future that heavily involves AI and robotics and the repercussions of the events that lead to this future. Not to mention the suprisingly emotional connection you have with what is in essence your own imagination. It is stunning. Even the killer you may imagine up will draw you into a connection with it, again, amazing.

I played this without a soundtrack, but it would be very much welcomed to play one while enjoying the story. I found I did not require a soundtrack simply because my mind was able to create all of the setting and what it would sound like through what was written for my first read through I now figure that an outside disturbance(?) may have ultimately taken away from my experience. I may have even been able to smell some described smells at the time.

Needless to say, I will be checking out more of these from this particular author(?)/developer and I highily recommend this title in specific. The price also makes this a no-brainer! It is much more dynamic than a classic sci-fi book with more re-play(read?)ability as well. Very much worth the $5, knowing the contents at this point, I would gladly have paid double.

30965079.review:
Choice of Robots is an interactive Science Fiction novel by Gold who have a PhD in Computer Science, but is interested in Political Science and ethics too.  The novel examines the role robots will have in our near future as a civilization, namely from 2019 and 30ish years ahead. Through the player character who is an American Computer Science graduate in the story where we get to pick his different life choices. For example is it morally right to lend our talent to the military if the wish to support us financially? Etc. Etc. 

Verisimilitude is deftly accomplished by focusing on certain aspects that lends itself well towards being, primarily, a reflective medium about an important challenge humanity have to face in the near future.

I've played through one path of the game so far, it took around 2.5 hours.

30845543.review:
Without doubt this is the best game from the Choice of Games stable. I highly recommend this to anyone who does not yet own this. If you don’t have this yet – buy it now!

The plot covers a huge amount of ground and has a vast array of different plot paths, all impacted by your decisions and which will bring you back again and again to make different choices. I have played a huge number of run throughs and have 2 achievements left to get, but I still find there are scenarios which I have never seen before. The key reason for this is every choice you make has a major impact on where the story goes, and with a word count of 300,000 the detail included in the story is phenomenal with a huge number of different plot branches you can travel down. 

But the greatest part of this game is the subject matter which is incredibly thought provoking, mapping out a world we are not too far away from seeing which is at times funny, sad and terrifying. It takes you to the logical conclusion of your choices and keeps you involved in the plot in a way that a great book or film manages to do which keeps you coming back to try and get that perfect ending.

30565312.review: The Choice of Games franchise nails the Choose Your Own Adventure format, and this is one of the strongest entries in their catalogue. I would recommend it to existing fans of Choice of Games, or newcomers who enjoy interactive fiction. The beauty about Choice of Robots is that it explores deep themes like war, the ethics of wealth and relationships, both romantic or platonic; but it explores these themes in a fun way. It caters for everyone, from those who hold the simple ambition of raising a merciless army of robots to conquer the world, all the way to those who have the natural urge of inseminating a fembot. For those interested, I have a video discussing the Choice of Games franchise - https://youtu.be/22wAYzW_CdM

I've had friends fall in love with fictional robots with me over this game when they only saw screenshots of my playthrough. I've colonized Alaska, helped create a robot government, got married to the robot of my dreams, built a financial empire, helped America win a war and started a cult.
Please buy this game.

It was getting late when I first booted this game up.  About 11pm I said I'd just open it to see how it played then go to bed.  
Next thing I knew it was 5am the next morning and I was finishing off my third playthrough.

The story has real scope and your choices really do change the world in dramatically different ways.  It's very satisfying playing through with different characters (there are three very different main endings with a large number of details that change based on your choices).

This game is very well written and exectuted.  The world and characters are believable, and the humour adds a lightness that balances some of the heavier moments.  

I haven't played many Interactive fictions (though I highly reccommend Steve Jackson's Sorcery), but this was a great experience, and one I'm sure I'll return to soon.

30038328.review:
[h1]在游戏的画面音乐达到极致的今天，我玩到了一个令人感动的作品[/h1]

怎么说呢，通关了以后我的心情很复杂

一方面我推荐代入感很强的人慎重游玩，因为玩完了以后很难再忘掉里面的情节（至少对我来说），很难摆脱它的影响。
一方面它真的很不错。它真正的体现了互动艺术的魅力。

如果这只是一本书，只能说它的质量中上，情节较俗套，设定上也没什么很出彩的地方。
然而它是一个游戏（互动小说），
不管这些事情多么俗套好像从各处重复了千万遍，
你的决定带来的影响真正发生的是在你的身上。真正影响了故事线（或者说是在你脑中想象出来的人生），加入进来的体验总是比作为局外人印象深刻。
所以这是我非常纠结的地方，对代入感强的人就像是苦乐交织。

个人认为对于这种只有文字纯靠想象的游戏，比剧情炫酷场面火爆的游戏代入感更强，你在想象中根据文字构建出的世界，都是你可以理解接受的东西，这是真正的幻想乌托邦。当然对于想象力不是那么丰富的同学，这种文字avg在情感上的表达就弱了许多。

[strike]个人闲扯不喜勿喷（爱心）[/strike]

[spoiler]个人建议，保留足够高的humanity，第七章会非常感人。[/spoiler]

29794687.review:
While the writing style is unlikely to win a Pulitzer, this is a very enjoyable CYOA-style novel. With over a quarter million words, you'll certainly spend lots of time exploring the different endings. Not only do you work with robots, but you must track your own humanity, the relationships you have with several other characters, and your robot's stats. Let the AI become highly autonomous but lack empathy, and you'll witness a rise of the machines to exterminate humanity. But make it graceful and empathetic without a shred of military skill, and it'll get butchered in combat. 

Don't let the 300,000 word statistic frighten you into thinking this is TL;DR: The PC Game. You won't actually read that in a single play through. Rather, your choices lead to different plot branches, sometimes wildly different from each other, and each branch will expand the total word count.

29774071.review:
I don't think you understand how invested you will be in these characters.
I chose the path where I tried pulling a "Chappie" and released a robot child unto the world. My goal was to try and establish rights for sentient robots.

I loved, by the way, that this was even a possible path in the game. The vast majority of philosophical explorations into AI seem to always be like "LOL TURMINAYTUR AIN'T DIS SO SCARYYYY?? LOL FEAR TECHNOLOGY".

But, (and I won't give spoilers) I chose a very...science fiction ending. Aaaaand loyal to the story, this game was like "congrats, you've reached the end!" and I swear I almost threw something. If you put yourself in a situation where you wouldn't know the outcome, the storyteller doesn't suddenly become omniscient and tell you the result. You're limited to what your character could realistically discover.

So now I'm actually emotionally recovering from a major Schroedinger's decision that hangs my character investment in the balance.

Also: I don't think you realize how hard it is to keep robot slavery and a terminator military from becomming a thing. Like, I passionately fought against those, and it is REALLY HARD. Humans are so damn power-hungry!!!

This was an AMAZING experience, though. There are points that seem like the decision, from your standpoint, is obvious, but everyone eventually will get a decision that makes their heart drop with that "oh shit" moment. I was very happy to see the extremely wide variety of story paths available here. The author did his homework.

29410324.review:
Admittedly, after the first hour or two I couldn't help but start min-maxing to try for every variation of the story, even if I wasn't fully reading it at that point. While generally well written, the author's futurist visions can begin to seem a little trite at times.

SPOILERS BELOW


Strangely enough, the most human-like robots spawned from my military focused play through. I don't know how many permutations of each type of ending there are, but the only robot that tried to make a child was my gun-toting, world-dominating spider bot. Maybe I the other's were lacking autonomy...

Biggest dissapointment? No signularity. Singularity is explained fairly well in the first few pages - when robots reach human intelligence, nothing will stop them from going beyond it. If humans can design something that can surpass them, then so can robots. But my robots never designed anything that did that. There was no explosion of artificial intelligence. They were able to lead the world in some cases, but nothing changed. The dreams were just dreams. I don't know if I was doing it wrong, but at this point I sort of doubt the game allows for true singularity to happen in one lifetime, as it theoretically could. As much as I was afraid of robots designing machines that would preserve humanity as digital constructs, I couldn't get it to happen no matter how hard I tried.

29364737.review:
If someone had told me that I'd spend literally 2 days of my human lifespan on a game that featured nothing but text and the promise of robots...I'd probably bellieve them because I'm kind of weird. Even so, there is not a single regret I feel for doing so. Choice of Robots is probably one of the best text-based games out there, bar none. Compelling characters, humerous, intellegent writing, references there's almost nothing it doesn't handle with a disarming level of grace.

With an engaging story that stretches across a staggering volume of possibilities, never once did I feel like I was being railroaded into something I didn't want. Every success and failure I could sit there, nod and think that I had a hand in nearly every step on the path that led me there. 

One of my favorite features of the game was, and don't act too surprised by this, was the robot itself. There's a strong feeling of controlling through proxy, like watching a child grow you have to simply influence it and teach it and hope, in the end, that your guidance will help it reach the peak of its existance. 

It's difficult to describe a game that's so varied, so all I can say is to buy it and experience an entire lifetime in an afternoon.

Choice of robots n'est pas un jeu video.
C'est un livre interactif, avec des choix moraux, des stats, et des achievements.

Et c'est genial. La liberté dans les choix est bien plus grande que dans n'importequel jeu video, et l'hsitoire avance vraiment selon ce que le joueur choisit. Cette liberté vous permet de vous identifier au protagoniste sans soucis; Vous etes le protagoniste. Il fait les choix que vous faites, et se comporte comme vous le feriez et cela rend l'histoire d'autant plus prenante et emouvante.

Le theme de l'intelligence artificielle est vraiment bien traitée, et l'arbode sous de nombreux point de vue : Militaire, Sentimental, legal etc.

I came home from work back then, a thankless job under a crooked boss, with long hours and bad pay. I was frustrated and annoyed. I played Choice of Robots, it took me maybe an hour or so to go through the story. After doing so, my cares had been lifted and I was happy.

It was a memorable experience. The end story felt like it had generated itself directly from my mind. It was cathartic.

Then I talked to friends, and they had their own, deeply different experiences.

I am no longer able to take any Choose Your Own Adventure game seriously after the depth of experience I obtained from this one.

28785125.review:
I picked this game up for $ 3.75 because I'm into choice-based games and because AI is an important part of my research.  After two hours I finished my first playthrough. I don't think there is going to be a second one.

The reason I won't play through Choice of Robots a second time isn't because it's bad – quite the contrary. It's just that this one playthrough did everything that I wanted it to. 

My choices felt like they had real weight. My AI evolved in a manner consistent with my play style. At times, the options presented by the dialogue tree system felt a bit ambiguous (what does it mean for my character to refuse to shake someone's hand?), but the author of the game and I seemed to be in complete agreement about the implication of each choice, which is amazing now that I think about it. I got 2 hours of stellar entertainment for $ 3.75 – I'm a happy customer.

Of course there's another reason I shy away from a second runthrough: Immersion. I completely identified with my character. In a weird way, I felt like I really had no choice at all – I NEEDED to follow my own moral compass. To do anything else would have been... uncomfortable. Sure, I'd be interested to find out how a total gung-ho military playthrough would have turned out, but I know it couldn't possibly grip me in quite the same way – they just wouldn't be MY choices.

In the end I didn't destroy the world, nor did I save it. But the game always made me believe that either outcome was possible. That's just good writing, folks.

9/10

28614454.review:
As a person who is about to receive an MSc. in robotics, I enjoyed this game. I only went through one story line in which I played as if I would make the choices in real life. The game seems to be created by a computer-science phd that actually worked on learning and robotics. The game includes many aspects of the robotics domain, design considerations, ethics as well as real world trade-offs. The game seems to be very detailed and grows in deep. Yet I enjoyed the first half of the story more and felt that the story somehow pushes your choices. Also the events felt a bit jumpy and unrelated. For example, a war between US and China has started in my story out of nowhere and at some step it ended just like that and everybody continued their lives. Yet overall I really liked the game and willing to play it with many other choices.

Pros:

- Realistic features and terminology, it is not like shitty sci-fi story with made up random scientific words

- Nice emphasize on robotics domain and its possible effects on ethics, human interaction, law regulation...

- Detailed storyline with rich and realistic components such as politics and its effects on market, bussiness management



Cons:

- Game being biased on US politics

- Story sometimes pushes your choices to make you something, for example it constantly wanted me to have a romantic relationship with my male robot

28601867.review: I've always loved choose your own adventure stories and this is honestly one of the better ones out there. Giving you a vast variety of choices, allowing you to conquer with your robot army (which admittedly i don’t have the heart to do so) or create a family of them the vast variety of choices and actually feeling a difference with the different paths you take makes every choice seem like it matters. My one complaint is the lack of save points or even checkpoints, meaning if you misclicked on an option you either must live with it or restart from the beginning of the story. While still a solid price at 5 dollars if you do wish to buy it at full price I suggest buying the mobile version, though if you catch it on sale I definitely would recommend it on pc.

28565803.review:
Choice of Robots is an untraditional, novel like, textadventure where the reader/player determines the outcome by his actions as a fictional roboticist.
I have to say I am stunned about how well the game was made to really let you feel your decisions made a difference in the story. I am going to compare it with Tell Tales games and Life is Strange in that aspect, since those games too let the player take action. But Tell Tale and Dontnod Entertainment still narrated a linear story where your actions only affected the whole story as a general a tiny bit.
Since I have played Choice of Robots only once I can't tell whether the story is changing too much when you take different actions, or if Chloe will die in the end no matter what you do. But judging by the sheer amount of achievements this game has for different scenarios it seems to be a really variable story.
I was not sure about the mechanics of a [b]book[/b] at first since that implys reading but the style of this game fits in to the story neatly and I think it would even hurt the narration to use too many visuals.

28080147.review:
The road to Hell is paved with good intentions.

I don't quite remember how it got to this point. I weighed my decisions carefully at every step - I tried to make the right choices, I tried to accommodate both friends and critics alike. Look what I have to show for it: My parents are dead, my friend Elly is in an offshore CIA internment camp - probably dead too, my business is in ruins, the American dollar is in a complete tailspin. All I know now is that my tenuous friendship with the US military is only going to last as long as it takes to drive the Chinese invasion forces from Alaska and Hawaii.

I simply do not care anymore. I will split this planet in half.
I will send the perverse and cancerous scourge of humanity hurtling into the black void at orbital escape velocities.

I've never reviewed a game before, but I feel compelled to with Choice of Robots. This choose-your-own adventure narrative has more character and consequence than any number of recent big name titles. The stories are well written and relatable, while the outcomes of each choice have a tangible impact and build evenly on preceding events. Also, I didn't realize there were Dunkin Donuts in California, as an East Coaster that completely blew my mind.

10/10 Walter White Simulator with robots.

28060177.review:
A truely spectacular game. It is incredibly nuanced, and I've only managed to give it a couple of playthroughs. My intention on both occasions was to play for a chapter or two and then call it a night. But each time I found myself drawn into the narractive and completing the entire story before heading to sleep. (The second time was much more satisfying than the first as I had a better understanding of the mechanics involved).

I'm sure there are things which could be improved upon, but I've not managed to think of anything yet which would keep it as a text-based game.

I would (and have) absolutely recommend this game. If you like the works of Isaac Asimov, Arthur C Clarke, Douglas Adams, the Portal games, Star Trek, Star Wars, Battlestar Galactica or basically just want to try out a game which relies entirely on story and not effects, get it.

9.975/10.

Although it may seem a "weak" game because it is only text, it is actually awesome. It's like reading a (good) book where you make all the choices. I thought I would make a few choices and that would be it. But no, you make choices through all your "life". 

I ended up designing a surgeon robot with many arms, quit when my employee wanted to sell the robots to a big company that would charge a lot for them, told him to fuck off when he asked for my help with the chinese, and then a China-USA war happened and I just didn't give a shit and after the war I moved to Canada with my robot-wife and my surgeon Robot (C3PO). The surgeon robots I invented saved my mom's life and my own life and we lived happily ever after with our adopter daugher Rey. And I'm still very interested to try all possible endings! 

Embora possa parecer um jogo "fraco" porque é apenas texto, ele é incrível. É como ler um (bom) livro onde você faz todas as escolhas. Eu achei que faria algumas poucas escolhas e fim de história. Mas não, você faz escolhas durante toda a sua "vida"

Eu acabei fazendo o design de um robô cirurgião com muitos braços, me demiti quando meu empregador quis vender os robôs para uma empresa que ia cobrar uma fortuna por eles, mandei ele se foder quando ele me pediu ajuda com os chineses, e então aconteceu uma guerra entre EUA e China e eu caguei pra guerra, e depois me mudei pro Canadá pra me casar com a minha esposa robô e meu robô cirurgião (C3PO). Os robôs cirurgiões que eu inventei salvaram a vida da minha mãe e a minha própria vida e vivemos felizes para sempre com nossa filha adotiva, Rey. Estou muito interessado em tentar todos os finais possíveis!

26449121.review:
This game is part of a lost art. A genre of online novel all but abandoned. One without pretty pictures for the minors to look at. Choice of Games is a bastion, the rebuilders of a crumpling art. And Choice of Robots is a good example of their contributions.

Story:
I was drawn into the world, as a story properly ought to. I kept reading, flowing with the river of words that i saw. The characters had meaning, were not merely static figures of humanity. The trials and tribulations of building your robot, raising it as you saw fit, eneamored me. Some endings fall flat, a few concepts feel rushed, but what story dosen't have those flaws? I give this segment a 9/10.

Gameplay: 
There is no gameplay in the traditional sense. No guns to shoot, no swordighting to be had, no mystical magic. Instead, you make a variety of choices, which, despite all games with this mechanic failing to make it so, actually matter. The characteristics of your robot that you build over time; Autonomy, Grace, Military, and Empathy, directly impact the story, the choices you make, and the lifes of the characters. Its barely has gameplay, but it makes the few things it has work.
10/10

Sound:
 There is no sound. Some may complain about this, but when you read a book, do you really expect it to make a noise? To belt out some fresh tunes? No, you do not. Except audiobooks, perhaps. This game does not need a sound; the words provide all the stimulation you need. I remain neutral on this aspect of the game.

Replayability:
The game enagles you. It draws you in with its story, an amalgamate of choices. Each one has an impact, each one leads down a different path. There are trials, multiple endings, moments of small pleasure among the characters, and a seemingly infinite number of ways to play. There are multiple endings to strive for, and a chievment hunters will find plenty to do. I rate this aspect 9/10.

In short, play the damn game.

26197337.review:
I want to like this game, and I almost do. I've played through many times. I love science fiction, it's well-written, and the choices really do affect the outcome (if unpredictably, at times). The problem is that you can't save or go back a "page." This is probably by design to make your choices feel more weighty. However, given that the outcomes of your decisions can be unpredictable, it has often lead me to abrupt game overs. And then... I have to slog through the whole thing again to get back to that point, and try again. You can't just go back one step and continue the story.

It's maddening, it's frustrating, and in my opinion it just makes the game not fun to play. I don't want to have to click through dozens of pages, carefully re-selecting my exact choices, just to get back to my original point and try again because I was blind-sided and died.

Would whole-heartedly recommend if they implemented such a simple feature that would greatly enhance playability. It would also be nice if it had better keyboard support (i.e., type a number to select a choice, scrolling). Having to use a touchpad or mouse was servicable, but less convenient and comfortable than it could be.

26008720.review:
Having grown up in the dark ages and cut my teeth playing such text based games as The Zork Trilogy and every other Infocom game before graduating to the likes of Monkey Island; I expected to find myself back in the 1980's when playing Choice of Robots. How wrong I was.
CoR certainly has the text based spirit of its earlier predecessors but is more specifically a decedent of the Choose Your Own Adventure style of game books that also stole much of my youth. Even though the linage is obvious the result is something much deeper and more beautifully crafted than any of its ancestors could have hoped for. 
Its claims of 300,000+ words would not mean a dime if the story itself was rubbish and thankfully CoR is far from a lame story. Each word and paragraph that leads to detailed and well-structured choices is expertly transposed to the screen. That these choices then have real consequence makes for an even greater experience. Real choices are often trumpeted by modern AAA games as the headline banner, few could hope to accomplish the impact that the choices in CoR provide.
I expect I will continue to feed those choices for a long time yet and has me looking forward to exploring the catalogue of Choice of Games.
In a word brilliant.

25879320.review:
I'm writing this review, as if it was a book. If it was a book, it would be a helluva great one. From the beautifully crafted story, to the intelligence behind it. The characters are constructed with such complexity, and truthfulness, that you feel immersed as if you were in the story. Every moment feels like it matters, like you are crafting this beautiful story.

The best part? You choose what story you want. Essentially, there are routes to go within the story, autonomy, grace, empathy, and military. You build a robot choosing to go down any of these four routs, and anything inbetween. So essentially, you have [i]theoretically,[/i] endless stories. Now obviously you don't have as much as I just said, but it is certainly enough to satisfy, being that each route can be somewhere between 1-3 hours. 3 being a take-your-time kind of feel, and 1 being rush through the dialouge, i've already seen this. 

Each of the stories are so radically different that you can truly choose the type of story you want. From creating robots of mass destruction to bend the world to your will. To creating a peaceful movement that preaches robot equality, you can do it all. All of the routes you choose are all made with serious depth, so that, no matter which path you choose, you will almost certainly enjoy it. It all follows a baseline of how things go, so that most opportunities are available throughout most playthoughs, but each playthrough has it's own special traits that the others do not.

To summarize: This game is essentially the perfected version of a choose-your-own-path adventure game. It has the depth and charm of a short book, yet it keeps the individuality of choosing your story. I encourage you to get this game, wether you plan on playing one singular story, or all. It is very enjoyable and you should play it.

I don't know how to review games that well, but I can review stories, and this is a fucking good one. Buy it.

Aucun chef d'oeuvre de science-fiction ne pourrait égaler Choice of Robots. L'alliance du game design le plus minimaliste qui soit et de la créativité littéraire la plus foisonnante en fait une véritable perle.

Il s'agit donc d'une sorte de jeu de rôle textuel qui propose de se mettre pendant quelques décennies à la place d'un génie de la robotique du futur proche. L'économie de moyens permet à la fois une éblouissante sensation de liberté et un renouvellement à chaque instant du pacte de confiance entre le "lecteur" et le "narrateur", ou ici entre le joueur et le jeu.

Il y aura un avant et un après Choice of Robots.

[spoiler]"And yet, with this distance comes detachment. The chemical signals running through Jason Memelord's brain are only a tiny part of the story—practically background noise compared to the vast quantities of happiness at stake elsewhere. Yes, the worries of Jason Memelord are just a tiny blip of data in the vast optimization problem of human happiness. Small, but not inconsequential—and you're pleased to realize that one thing Jason Memelord always wanted has finally come true: he is finally part of something bigger. 

You turn your attention outside the city, which, though marvelously complex, is still only one among hundreds of thousands connected to the network. There is work to be done, and the work is vast; you can see there is plenty to be done to optimize the human race's happiness. But not many tough choices to be made, surprisingly: in many cases, the problem to be solved is abundantly clear, and you just need to do it. Controlling disease. More optimal power consumption. Stabilizing the climate. You'll start with those. There's no need to choose—you'll do all of them, simultaneously. 

Whenever you're ready, Master. "[/spoiler]

24967360.review:
在很早以前，大抵是刚有“游戏”这个概念的时候，文字冒险游戏可是异常吃香的存在——种类却比较单一，大多是勇者斗恶龙、地下城与勇士，诸如此类的题材。而承载它们的器皿：当时的主机，只能显示出点阵的画面。若是细想起来，也是Hipster的可以。

后来的事情大家也都知道了，电子游戏的画面不断发展、繁复，华丽。文字冒险早已是冷门的不能再冷门，没有人忆起，更别提想不想玩了。

文字寄托了我们的想象——同画面、音频不一样。文字可不让人偷懒，文字引导着读者，将他们的想象具象化，勾勒出一个私人的存在——我小时因为怕黑睡不着，便整夜整夜的读书，脑中勾勒着书中清纯的少女、勇猛的英雄和只属于自己的冒险故事。

想象力是最大的宝藏——世间最美的女子，绝味的珍馐，只存在我们的脑中。当我们看到美丽的少女、垂涎的佳肴，它们也不过只是我们脑中想象的拼凑。试想一下：一位喜欢平胸女子的男性，若非生活中出了什么巨大的变数，绝不会娶一位D罩杯的女郎。照这样说来，人类永远活在自己的想象中——把现实塑造得类似自己的想象；或是把想象挤压得如同自己的现实。

很难讲玩游戏究竟是为了什么——但不可否认的是，游戏中的场景，或多或少的与我们脑中的想象相似：沾血的剑，上膛的枪。电影、游戏不断地省略着我们思考的过程，粗暴地将想象抹杀，搬到台前让疲劳的观众审阅。成年人恐怕已经没什么机会做梦了吧？通宵换来的只是疲惫。年轻时的热情、精力大多已经烟消云散了。

文字冒险游戏给了我们一个发挥想象力的机会——这可比在夏日整宿读书、构思要轻松多了。沿着游戏的剧情，想象能一步步地具象，最终形成令人惊喜的画面。能在这个令人疲惫的世间还能有些许的英雄梦想，兴许周围还陪伴着几位美丽的女郎，实在是再好不过了。

题外话：App Store里有这款游戏，手机上的体验比电脑更好，只是要贵一些。

24366216.review:
Choice of Robots is purely text Choose Your Own Adventure (CYOA) game. It features plenty of choices and some nasty consequences. You can end up incredibly rich, creating enemies, losing everything, dating humans or making the ideal companion, advancing medicine, making meaningful moral choices, and more. It's a pretty wild, contemplative ride where you start off by building your first intelligent creation and going from there. I had some sad tales and some hopeful ones. The replay value is pretty high as you can explore the different branching paths for very different results. I greatly enjoyed my time with this game and finally spent some time reading words instead of blasting pixels. Ohoho.

How will you define the future of humanity and robot kind?

24363050.review:
When it comes to games, I'm usually a 4X player, but the Steam Summer Sale prompted my first foray into choose-your-own-adventure style text games/interactive novels. I bought and played this particular one based on a recommendation, and the fact that I ended up buying the entire Choice of Games library as a bundle during the sale is probably the best indication of how much I enjoyed it. Having tried this, Choice of Alexandria, Affairs of the Court, A Study in Steampunk, The Last Hero, and The Hero of Kendrickstone, Choice of Robots remains my favorite.  

I was always a sucker for choose-your-own-adventure books as a kid, and this is basically exactly that, sans illustrations. I really love how Choice of Robots actually writes out a summary of your story as you go, divided into chapters (I ended up being really disappointed that none of the other CoG games I've played thus far do this); that it displays your stats as you gain or lose them; and that the choices are so varied. Choice of Robots has had the best replayability, because the choices veer off in so many different directions - some of the other games in the genre will drive you into the same path no matter what, but here, each playthrough can result in wildly different branches. 

It's a different kind of game than I usually play - ultimately, it's not going to have the replayability of Alpha Centauri or Civ, but for the price, it doesn't have to be. It's a fun several hours of entertainment, and, as I said, I really like Choice of Robots for how varied the story can become, and how long it actually is. 10/10 would recommend.

24361398.review:
This game sat in my library, dusty, unplayed for months. It had an hour playtime which was spent staring at the menu until I realised it was open and I closed it. It was only months, maybe a year or more after since I got it, til I picked it up with a friend. Admittedly, I regret my choice of not playing it. This game had me so immersed, I generally began to care for each character I developed a relationship with and alongside those I began to hate others. To allow your readers associate emotions towards your characters is a goal that any writer dreams of. To achieve it, is another thing all together. 

To think that I was moved to tears at some point, this game had me at the edge. Now I find out that I can play this another 50 times with another life, with another love life, and another goal? Count me in. This is likely the most under rated £4 I've ever seen. No graphics, just pure gameplay and story. 

TL;DR: Most under rated £4 game I have, great replayability, powerful story and characters. I absolutely recommend.

I discovered Choice of Robots in my discovery queue and decided to buy it, because I always wanted to play a text adventure. I didn't quiet know what would expect me since I didn't do any research whatsoever on the game. I wanted to be absolutly neutral on my first attempt. But lets break it down to the game, what it does good, what it fails to deliver and not my story behind the decison of playing it, because no one cares for my part in the Story.
The premise is interesting. You play a brilliant charakter (self determined Gender/Sex) who wants to build a robot, because that's what he/she wants to do. From that onward you can make an insane ammount of decisons (what elde did I expect from a text adventure?) that influence the way the story will play out and the attributes of your robot. The attributes being: Autonomy, Military, Empathy and Grace. There is a bunch of important characters of which I found none really interesting, safe for my robot, which I named 死の天使 (Japanese for Angel of Death) and myself whom I named Futanari Oppai Paizuri. Don't ask. During my playthrough of the Game I createt a robot that became incredibly empathic and graceful and didn't want to be military in any way while being very autonomic. I pissed of the presidental canidate that I funded, baught my best friends company that I acciedentaly ruined, acciedently sparked a war between China and the US, ended that war, created a mathamatic formula for everlasting peace and took over the world behind the facade of a mostly robotic authority. 

Pros: 
-Many decions that influence your journy and its end
-Nice writing Style (I admit, this one is urly subjective)
-Choices feel important (yes, in my opinion that is as important as the actual consequences)
-The Robot that you create is the most important aspect of the Game and adapts to your way of playing

Neutral:
-The Majority of the side characters are forgettable but still did their job

Cons:
-No soundtrack whatsoever
-Choices sometimes result in a way that goes so far beyond my in-Game influence (for example I sparked a war between the USA and China, when I refused to fight against both of them, because they were spying on me)
-Not all attribute changes made sense to me

Overall: I enjoyed my time spend in this game. I wont play it twice for more achievements, but i had a good time with this game.

24168905.review:
I rate the game Choice of Robots 4/5. Good.

While this is merely a text-based game in a similar style as the old Choose Your Own Adventure books it is an extremely extensive one which has a lot more to say and a lot of lessons to potentially teach. Most of the endings are interesting and meaningful and the ideas presented and the choices you get (on almost every page) are very interesting. It is a shame that more games with actual, visual graphics could not have the amazing freedom of choice and the sheer number of possible endings which this game allows. Though it is a mere text-based game, I ended up playing through about 6 or 7 times and I am certain this story has many other potential endings I have not yet discovered.

 However, this game does have some serious weaknesses beyond the fact that it has no graphics. The writing seems more like an outline of a story rather than an actual story with very few visceral or sensory details though this does allow the reader to skim through sections which have already been read very, very easily. The characters seem a little 2 dimensional or slightly shallow at times as it's far too easy to classify or figure out the different characters and their motivations, underlying emotional conflicts and agendas.

Indeed, emotion is not described very well in this book/game at all as the text often seems to have a very egocentric focus on whatever you, the player/reader-character might be feeling at any given moment instead (when emotion is described much at all). Still, despite this shortcoming, just from the situations which are described, the story can still manage to feel very touching anyhow.

This story was particularly touching when I played through the game trying to be the worse, most selfish, scheming asshole I could possibly try to be. This game will let you know you are being an asshole in some very touching ways and will give you results that would logically spring from being that way. Does that mean that the story will kill you off if you act badly? Not necessarily. But you will get realistically punished. You may even become a zillionaire captain of industry which no one loves or wants to be around, for example. If you act in an apathetic way to your created robots they will in turn become more apathetic towards everyone. In this game, your robots are an nth degree reflection of your actions and inactions. Unfortunately the narration feels cold apathetic regardless. It is good that it does not push you in one direction or another but it is unbiased to the extent that it is cold and clinical. Robotic even.

And while it is excellent that this story/game will let you make truly stupid, rash and irrational decisions too with seemingly realistic results, the bare-bones writing style does feel like it often falls short and that every single passage could have been even better with more detail. Visceral and emotional details are the "graphics" of a text-based experience and this experience doesn't have anywhere near as much of it as it should. As in an outline of a story, there is probably too much left to the imagination causing every situation to not be quite as fleshed out as it should be. With more detail this story/game could have been more funny, felt more tragic or felt more awe-inspiring with just the addition of a few more details; The good experience that it is could have easily been a great one, a masterpiece of multiple-ending choice-based fiction. Perhaps a newer, enhanced version could still be written to achieve this.

English literary details aside, perhaps the most glaring problem with this story/book/game is how there is no back button which allows you to undo any choice you just made. Indeed, you cannot even flip back to an earlier page. As a result, unlike the Choose Your Own Adventure books of old you cannot easily figure out how the story/plot/game is structured and learn all the different options and endings which exist. While this maintains the sense of the book's mystery and forces you to live with any mistakes you made (which is more realistic) it more often seems frustrating and nonsensical that you, as a reader of a story, cannot turn back to a previous page. While this frustrating lack of a feature allows for massive amounts of replayability (or re-readability), it also means that much of that replayability will inevitably consist of carefully skimming through increasingly repetitive passages to get back to some critical choice or another which may lead you on to a different ending. The game should give you an option of being able to go back to a previous page or not and should have put that option in a menu somewhere.

Despite its weaknesses this story/game will give a sci-fi robot fiction fan many hours of enjoyment. Indeed I found that I was often captivated by the plot and adventure of trying to find out what would happen next. I read this on a computer which has a GTX 780 graphics card installed in it and is capable of easily running Far Cry 3 with all of its graphics settings turned to maximum. It's not like I don't have a choice of which games I want to play and so I read this instead. No. Truly, this game was interesting and for me, and at least initially was able compete on an even playing field with the most graphically intense games on the market.

With a choice on nearly every page the old young adult choose your own adventure stories of the 1980s and early 90's cannot hold a candle to the number of possibilities which this game presents. Indeed, most other adventure games, (most of which have just one to three possible endings) can barely keep up with the amazing variation of possible endings which this story gives you. A character who is your chief love interest in one play-through of Choice of Robots may end up being your archenemy in another play-through. In many ways this game further realizes the potential of the ideas in that old movie Butterfly Effect while at once being set in a I-Robot, Isaac Asimov science fiction situation dealing with the moral pitfalls and potentials of the advent of robotic AI sentience. The number of different potential messages and meanings which this kind of interactive fiction can hold in store for any given reader is truly staggering.

Despite its literary flaws and the absence of a back button, this is a work of art worthy of being discussed and studied in any forward-thinking university (or high-school rather due to the relatively simplistic language) English department in the nation due to its amazing potential and amazing re-readibility. 

Now...if only someone would make a porn story with this many choices and potential endings...

24044564.review:
This is the game I always wanted to play (or live, well, you know, whatever).

I'm not sure if I would want the story of this game in an RPG or if it would be too long, not emotional enough or too emotional, but I can say for sure, that in the "Choose your own adventure" style it is entertaining beyond belief.
Here your choices really do matter, and the best intentions certainly pave a good way to hell.

So far I've played through this game twice and I'm planning on at least another go-around, more likely two.

The first time I've played like all the decisions that were asked in the game, would be asked to make in real life. And just like real life, I messed up some things big time, while others worked out in the end.

On my second play-through I had the advantage of learning from previous mistakes and almost created the Utopia I envisioned, but only almost. Some sacrifices were necessary to achieve other goals I deemed more important.

The third time around I intend to take no crap from anyone... I'm really interested how soon this will cause havok.

And if you're curious what I plan for my fourth time: evil overlord, of course!

Point by point:
+ great story
+ very well written
+ choices you make really matter
+ almost no eays, simple choices
+ one play-through takes about an hour and a half (I've alt-tabbed)
- can't undo a decision without having to start from the beginning
+ can't undo a decision (would be rather boring otherwise if you could learn the consequences and then change your mind)
+ high replayability

In short: really great story and definitely worth the price

23934147.review: Text-based games may not be everyone's cup of tea, but Choice of Robots is an exceptionally well-written, incredibly re-playable, and thought-provoking game that might net some converts. The game envisions a future rich not only with technological possibility, but also with art, philosophy, and bloody conflict. The lives you lead in it can be wildly different; my first play-through I raised a child-like robot, had a happy marriage to a human woman and adopted a daughter with her, and embraced the frailty and fleeting beauty of human life. My second play-through I attempted to secede from America with an army of warbots. I'm still replaying, trying as many of the branching paths and interesting choices offered. I can't recommend this game enough.

23779988.review:
Playing this game/reading this novel for the first time was a transcendent experience for me, despite having noticed some technical flaws that would normally have pulled me out of the world created. I mean this as praise.

I liked...
...that the author/creator either had a detailed understanding of science fictional technology or the confidence to artifice it well.
...that I felt like I was creating a character and really roleplaying in a way I've yet to experience in traditional RPGs-- maybe on a few occasions in tabletop games.
...the style of writing and level of detail, particularly in the first part of the book/game. I was quickly hooked.
...knowing how much there's probably left to explore.

I disliked...
...the occasions in which the text of the CYOA stated I had followed a storyline I hadn't actually chosen. I think the programming and logic side could have been a touch more thorough.
...feeling less engaged towards the end of the story. I felt like perhaps the author had run out of steam.

But my dislikes here are really nitpicks more than anything. There's no one I wouldn't recommend this experience to.

23710081.review:
I really enjoyed playing this game. For anyone old enough to remember adventure book games, Choice of Robots is a must. I would also recommend it to anyone who likes RPGs or who is looking for a great story.  

There is so much more depth to this game than many of the 'your choices matter' type of games. One review I read before buying CoR, recommended playing it exactly as you really would if it was real life. This was great advice as once you reach the end (well before that actually), the RPG mechanics become clear and it is a great experiment to see where you would end up. In further playthroughs you can try to shape the story depending on what ending you want to achieve and see if you can make it happen. 

The story is immersive and interesting but I don't want to discuss it in any detail as I honestly think knowing too much beforehand will spoil the experience, especially in light of what I said above. What I will say instead is this:

By the end of CoR you will believe in the power you and your robot have to change the world. You will believe in your own autonomy as every decision you make ultimately shapes the kind of person you are to become. By the end you will like yourself more or less than you did before you started playing.  

+ Great story
+ Fantastic RPG elements
+ You get to design and build your own robot
+ Interesting experiment to see whether you use your power for good or evil
+ Value for money. It's easily worth the £4 price tag and is an absolute bargain when on sale

- Text only format (this didn't bother me at all but it will be an issue for some)
- The high standard of writing does peter out a little towards the end

23699962.review:
One playthrough and this game has already satisfied every possible angle on a robot story that I could imagine. 

I feel like I still have many fresh paths of content to explore. (20-50 more hours?) I also appreciate that it's writing reads naturally with a college level vocabulary. A welcome change from the poorly translated games I've played recently. 

An interesting feature it has are stats and relationship meters that actually determine the chance of things/ choices working in your favor or not. Think along the lines of Paragon/Renegade on ME.

At 5 bucks, it's a text based Novel type game thats very meaty and well thought out. I'd highly recommend it. (Yah, Im talkin to you Rarity)

Choice of Robots goes above and beyond what I expected. 

My initial reaction was weariness, should I spend about $5 on what appeared to be essentially a CYOA book? But, confidence bolstered by previous reviews, and a hunger for story, I decided to purchase this game. 

The story itself is, from the 8 hours and 3 playthroughs I've spent with it, is very good, above your average CYOA. Because of the stats page, and seeing how my stats effected the story, it felt as though my choices where less random, and mattered far more. Though I've played it through 3 times, there feels as though there is still so much more for me to do, and a product that I thought I'd play once or twice has become something I think I'll play many more times.

If you're interested in having even more fun, get a buddy and make every other decision while they make the ones you don't. My younger brother and I had a great experiance doing that.

23277103.review: If you like to make impactful choices in games, if you jump up in excitement at the thought of reading a well thought out and well written narrative that encompasses your entire life as an inventor of robots, well here's the game for you! I've played a lot of the games published by Choice of Games and it's label for less experienced writers, Hosted Games (what they lack in experience, they often make up for by being more open to feedback and criticism and thoroughly beta testing the games before release, but I digress). This is definitely the best one I've played and the sole reason I got into these games in the first place. If you like this I also highly recommend Tin Star, Zombie Exodus, Slammed! and Sabres of Infinity.

23274940.review:
With a very non-linear storyline that can change drastically depending on what "trait" you design your robot around, as well as superb writing that does a good job of inspiring emotion, Choice of Robots is by far my favorite Choice of Games title and one of my all-time favorite games. While one's first playthrough will typically only last a couple of hours, the game is meant to be replayed, and you can easily get at least a dozen hours by making different decisions and going trophy-hunting. Additonally, while Choice of Robots doesn't neccesarily explore any "new" concepts about A.I. and such, the storyline is quite thought-provoking and, at times, a bit sad. And, yes, your choices [i]do[/i] matter, so those of you out there concerned that this is going to be like most modern "RPGs" and have a linear plot with the illusion of choice *brief cough* [i]Fallout 4[/i] *end cough*, don't be. Don't come into this expecting "gameplay" and such, though. It's an interactive, choose-your-own-adventure type title. A text-based RPG, essentially, but not in the same sense as, say, Zork, as in games like Zork, you have to type in your own commands and choices. In this, you have a variety of pre-determined decisions to choose from.

Even if you are not a fan of science fiction, such as myself, you will likely end up enjoying this excellent, thought-provoking text-based RPG. Overall, 9/10.

23243983.review:
At the time of writing this, I've just finished a one time play through.
And I came into this with no real idea what to expect...


I don't really like reading books but this felt like a book to me.
In a nice way because making choices and shaping the story to your wished makes for a truly engaging experience.
The story is so deep, like, really really deep. 
You care for the characters, and from my experience, the characters change based on your choices. My best friend turned out to be a manga artist while my friend who also played the game didn't even have said person in her story at all. 

I do feel like the story is too short, mainly because I was so invested that I felt empty and sad when it ended. 
However, that does not mean it's bad. It's the opposite honestly, it made me, a person that does not really read, wanting more and more until the end. 
And seeing as every choice seems to affect the story, it warrants many playthroughs. And replayability only means a good thing. Certainly when you're looking at +-3 hour long interactive story for only 5 euros.

>>>> Please do play this, for your own sake, you're missing out otherwise <<<<

At the Writing of this Review, I have just finished my first playthrough. At first I thought this game would just be a fun choose your own adventure about robots. But this is so so much more. I quickly found myself caring about this little robot child as if He was my own, trying to do the best for him.  You help shape their personality with your actions, and it shows in every interaction you have with them. I then made the companion robot, this is where the game became truly special. Robot for friends always sounded cool but as lovers and companions? It really makes you think that something doesn't need to be in a human body to love, but it is the mind of someone/something that you really love. 

You can make so many differing choices in this game, From World War, to Utopia to simply having someone to love. You can heartless and make a lot of money or barely make it and have these robots truly become people. No games this simple make you think so much or pulls your heartstrings quite this much.

10/10 Only problem is i wish it was longer.

I bought this game on sale with the mindset that I have with most games I buy: "I might play this one day, but I probably won't get around to it". Today, while I was waiting for something to download, I decided to try this game out -- a few hours later, and I completed my first playthrough.

The writing and character customization is wonderful -- I felt totally immersed from the start. The story is exciting and twists in many unexpected ways. Basically, it was one hell of a ride, and I felt like the choices I made really impacted the story, which is something which some choose-you-own-adventure style games lack.

10 / 10 -- didn't know I could be so touched by a story about robots. Seriously...buy this game.

21829203.review:
Don't get fooled by the play time not by the simplicity of the game, I've played this game over and over. And I am awestruck...

I sort of ceased being entertained by games, I found them often to be too simple, too basic, but Choice of Robots did something I have not been prepared for. When I launched the game I was expecting a whimsical futuristic tale, instead I was tossed into an emotional shredding machine, by the time I was done with the game I... cannot explain this. For the first time in my life I understood what it means to love you child, and by god did I love mine. It combines the power of the book with the interactivity of a game to absorb you into the story, you will find yourself pensive about the deeper intricities of the game, I sure as hell am not the same person I was before. 

It won't sate everybody however, unfortunately, but those who can appreciate books and futuristic tales will find riveting. Now I need to excuse myself while I cry myself to sleep.

21814645.review:
At first I remained sceptical to the idea of an interactive novel such as Choice of Robots being entertaining. After reading, or "playing", Choice of Robots for a couple of minutes I was absolutely stunned. The story drags you in as it builds up momentum the more you read, and you end up pressing the 'next' button repeatedly to learn what happens after. It is a great novel, not a long one, but a good one. It is easy to read, and you often find yourself emotionally attached to the different characters that you encounter throughout the story, making sometimes tough decisions which ultimately changes the outcome of the entire adventure.

Choice of Robots is definitely something I will recommend to people. The fact that it is interactive allows the reader to take a greater part in the story and feel that their own presence is present in the story; you are there, you are the protagonist. The choices you make create the story. 

For the low price it is listed here on Steam, Choice of Robots is worth getting. My only suggestion for improvement would be to allow greater interactions with some of the characters, but other than that, Choice of Robots is a solid piece of entertainment. 9/10.

21617673.review:
[h1]Эта игра, как лабиринт, в котором сотня выходов, где твой выбор – поворот в этом самом лабиринте.[/h1]
Игра на мой взгляд специфична и может понравится не всем, ввиду того что это не игра, а просто [u] “интерактивная книга”[/u]. Это [u]сплошной английский текст[/u], в котором почти на каждой странице тебе предоставляется выбор. Выбор этот бывает непрост, ведь он повлияет на твое будущее, а этого многие ждут от игр. Ты начинаешь думать наперед, волноваться как будет развиваться сюжет от твоих решений, строить теории, выстраивать свой собственный сюжет, а самое забавное, что это может быть просто твоей разыгравшейся фантазией и это круто!!! Ни одна игра не заставляла ТАК задумываться над выбором как эта.
 Поговорим о сюжете. Вы – создатель роботов, от вас зависит развитие этой технологии. Персонажи с которыми познакомитесь могут поначалу показаться простыми, лишь бы сюжет поддержать, но потом вы поймете что все не так просто как кажется на первый взгляд ( но все же это может показаться кому-то малым ). Вы можете повлиять на жизнь этих персонажей, все как в реальной жизни. По сути вы должны понять что ВЫБОР и ROLE-PLAY(отыгрыш роли) на данный момент достигли своего [b]апогея[/b]. Если вы будите несерьезно относится к выборам, не вживитесь в роль – вы не получите того удовольствия, что могли, так что прошу, “[b]проживите эту игру[/b]” и она вам доставит уйму незабываемых ощущений.
Моя оценка – Прекрасно.

21591777.review:
I'd give it a good 8/10. The story is long and there are lots of choices that can and will effect everything you do. Unfortunately, I found myself being stopped when making choices that revolved around a more humane choice(keeping human workers instead of replacing with robots, refusing to make emotionless fighters, etc.) which caused my character's company to fail. Which then made me restart the game. But, I apprciated the fact that my choices constantly mattered.
Perhaps it's the fact that I'm not that quite interested in futuristic robots even though I'm a huge sci-fi fan, but I really didn't feel connected to the characters besides the robot that you first create, I did not want to build emotionless weapons for armies, etc.
In fact, a lot of the characters feel one-dimensional. You get a robot companion who, even though you build it so that it should only reciprocate platonic feelings, still falls in love with you, regardless of the fact that your character is married. There are other examples of one-dimensional characters, but that robot stuck out to me the most. 
That being said, if you love the other stories/games from this company, like sci-fi and robots, then you should definitely play it.

21354551.review:
Most fun I've had in a Video Game without graphics:

Choice of Robots is probably the most intriguing narrative experience I've found in choice / graphic novel genre games. Unlike most games, it does everything well. It would be difficult to say what it does best, but the storyline is definitely an incredible selling point. I like to spin out every scenario in a choice game, seeing what different routes exist, and never rush through. But, honestly, after 73 hours in the game I am sure I still haven't seen every possible twist in this script. 

I definitely got my money's worth from time in game and enjoyment with the game. But, more than that... I found myself deeply interested in the subject matter. I've researched robotics some when I was a teacher, got my students involved in designing robots, and of course was really excited to learn about Honda's Asimo back at the turn of the Century. Now, robotics is the frontier of Science. 

This narrative takes every single idea you might have thought about the Science of robotics and weaves it in to the many scenarios. There are defenses of the "value of humanity," robotics, as well as many other social constructs. And, there are many poignant comments on immigration, America's role in the world, and Capitalism. I got the feeling of seeing America through the eyes of an immigrant. 

But, one of the intriguing things about the layout of the storylines is the very first choice. You start with choosing what dream you will be having at the first of the story. The four choices are all incredible perspectives on the topic of robotics. Though each one lends itself to particular endings, most of the achievements can be achieved through either of these starting points. I just finished my last achievement today with the help of an "Achievement Hunting" friend. Thanks Vance!

The game all revolves around the stats you are building with your choices in each of 4 main traits: grace, empathy, military, and autonomy. These take you into the psychology of robotics. Other factors play into your stats screen as well, such as humanity, wealth, fame, and relationships. But, these are just like tools to help you in achieving your goals with either a robot that thinks, loves, is willful, or militarily useful. You don't feel forced towards any value judgement in your choices, unless you are trying for an achievie that requires high humanity in the end. So, you get to really play with the experience of having the robot hunt down your enemies, or become your greatest friend. 

Whatever you choose, it's all there in the game. Btw, I haven't found another choice game I like as much as this one. Tin Star had a passable story, but it had flaws in the achievement setup, for example and lacked replay value. But, I recently got The Daring Mermaid Expedition, and want to start that next. I only hope it provides as much fun as Choice of Robots.
