21270348.review: This deserves a longer review.  I meant to play Choice of Robots for 20 minutes to see what it was like and played it for nearly 5 hours on my first run through.   I cried so hard and I lived a lifetime of mistakes and joy and so much more.  I never knew that text only games, a genre of games that I thought had died in the 1980's, could come back 30 years after their time to hit me so hard in the gut.   This is like the time I thought pixelated graphics had died in the 1990's and then I played Papers,  Please for less than 90 minutes only to realize that a game with even the simplest graphics could still have the power to stare into your soul and reveal truths about yourself even you didn't want to admit about yourself or never even knew about yourself.  Games like Choice of Robots and Papers, Please are the kinds of games that prove beyond any shred of a doubt that video games can be the highest of high art and can have asgreat or an even greater emotional impact on you than books, music, TV, and movies, and other art.  I will be playing this game for a long time and I will be gifting multiple copies to many friends in the immediate future and for a long time to come.

21136538.review:
This game is really, really good. I've been recently interested into choise-based games, and I think this game deserves to figure at top of this category.

There's no visuals or even music in this game, but trust me, it doesn't need it. The text alone perfectly manages to create its own universe. Though, it's only in English (it isn't my first langage, so I needed to search for vocabulary at some times) and you'll still need a good level to understand the game.  

Through the whole game you've got plenty of choices, which leads to plenty of various endings. The choices you make really matters and have consequences, sometimes large-scale consequences. Several times I made decisions that I almost immediately regretted, but most of times I ended up with an ok (and even interesting) situation after all.  

A nice thing is the different choices you make for your robot. You can choose how it will look, how it will call you, if you want your robot to be considered as male, female or something else, how you want to educate it ; and your decisions through the game will influence your robot's personality and relationship towards you. You can decide it will be a killing machine that'll obey your orders, or a nice and friendly robot which can even become your husband/wife/soul mate. 
Absolutely amazing.

Anyway, this game is definitely worth a try. 
No, not a try, a whole playthrough.

If you enjoyed "robopocalypse" or "robot uprisings" or really anything by asimov, you'll definitely enjoy this.

MODERATE spoilers 
So I make a typical robot, you know robot face, metal body, human height ... extra sensitive fingers and an encrypted hardrive (don't look at me like that, its not what it sounds like) ,  runs on bacon grease. I then get "fired" by my teacher or supervisor for not being willing to make my Robot (Crispin)  less "friendly"  so the military can use him to kill more people in third world countries or whatever it is they do. I then spend the next few years basically trying to make a self relient, self learning and empathetic buddy... or maybe kinda of like a son. Even had him learn the equivalent of secondary school education in a few days so not bad.. However shit hits the fan pretty quickly when candidate president totallynotsarahpalin comes to visit my factory in Alaska (should have seen this coming) asking for me to support her in running for president of which I soundly reply "NOOOoooooooo" but not before mentioning that Chinese hackers tried to get into my robots and failed but still managed to steal their design ... This sent off a cascade of events that ultimately leads to China and the USA sending Robot death machines to kill one another. Completely did not mean for this to happen obviously and I try my best to stay out of the war. Or at least intil the professor from the start stole my designs and sold them to the damn USA military. So theres me thinking oh well my robots are built to help and care for people, maybe even love them so they shouldn't be able to cause too much harm right .... right? ..  NOPE - turns out their best traits , i.e empathy and autonomy made them super killing machines with pinpoint accuracy going around wiping out entire cities. I do manage in the end to escape this and retire but not before china takes my factory, all my money and then ends the war with America before I can respond. Did manage to make myself kind of immortal 
10/10

20946065.review:
An interesting read with significant decision-making, done in a minimalist style with just text and some buttons. If you want graphics and sound, look elsewhere, but if you have the attention span to read and participate in a story, try this one. The style focuses on scenes and chapters rather than rooms, so expect to read about a series of events and choose one of several scripted actions rather than selecting "go north" or "get flask".

I've now played through this twice and had very different outcomes and scenes along the way. It looks as though your very first choice selects one of four overall plots, but they overlap. Your decisions affect a set of robot stats, your own "humanity", your wealth and fame, several relationships, and a spoilery thing, but there are also specific details that get worked into the text like your robot's exact appearance -- which in turn affect stat growth. I think I stopped a robot uprising at one point because I'd put effort into the Empathy stat for instance. (The text implied I'd barely had enough in that playthrough.) The feedback, eg. "++Military", is helpful for understanding the effects of my actions.

Noticed one apparent bug: I'm pretty sure Silas tried to kill me for unclear reasons, died, then was back and in a good relationship status in the last chapter. I also found it odd that another character got shot but wasn't marked as dead, and saving another, obviously important character had no noticeable effect. Would also have been nice to see the final tally of the wealth and fame stats have some acknowledgment beyond the stats screen. The game has no "Undo" button like some text adventures, and I have mixed feelings about that. It adds weight to your choices but is a little like the "Fallout 4" experience where you select a speech option only to find your character does something you didn't quite intend.

So, I give this one a thumbs-up. I'm curious to see how modern text adventures do on Steam.

20927952.review:
Вы любите выбор в играх? Быть тем, кем хотели бы быть вы, а не сценаристы? Концовки в виде выбора красного или синего вас уже не впечатляют? А может вы ещё и тру-олдфаг и хардкорный нёрд по кибернетике? Так есть у меня для вас.

20 декабря 2014 года в Steam вышла интерактивная книга Choice of Robots. Да, ребят, книга. Где чёрные буквы на белом фоне, много текста, а ещё это всё нужно читать. Книга. И, как можно понять из названия, в ней есть выбор. И роботы. Нам предстоит сделать много выборов и повстречать очень много роботов. Создать первый в истории механизм, способный испытывать эмоции и любить. Уничтожить к чертям Америку при помощи армии безжалостных терминаторов. Или же объединить все организмы в один большой мета-организм (совсем как в одном популярном аниме). А самое главное – просто умопомрачительная графика, арт-дизайн, звук и озвучка персонажей. Настолько крутая, насколько позволит ваше воображение, само собой.

А если всё же отставить в сторону авторские слабые попытки пошутить, то это просто отличная книга, написанная очень простым, но в то же время очень живым и интересным языком. С горой отсылок к гик-культуре (серьёзно, здесь их чуть ли не больше, чем во всяких Regular Show, Gravity Falls и прочих подобных вещах вместе взятых), с вариативностью, которая возможна только в текстовом виде, и драматичными сюжетными поворотами. Здесь можно стать практически кем угодно, хоть вы и все равно останетесь молодым учёным-гиком, который создал робота. И вы сможете делать что угодно, хотя со временем вы найдете все развилки и поймете, какой выбор ведёт к определённой из концовок.

20727239.review:
This game was the first interactive novel I ever played by [i]Choice of Games[/i] and boy am I hooked now!

A 300,000 word experience into the world of robotics, artifical intelligence, consciousness, and what it means to be human. Focus on how you develop your robot, and what values you think are important -- will you make your robot more empathic, able to understand humans and work with them closely? Or will you focus on strength and military, making your robot more suitable to the army?

Of course, the choices you make for your robot also affect which companies or people are likely to back or fund your project, and it can have influence on your romantic relationships as well... depending on the fact if you're going down the love bot route or not. Work your way through (robot) wars, ruined friendships, deaths, and try to answer the looming question what will happen to artifical intelligence as it transcends a certain level. Does your robot have a soul? Would you love your robot and let your robot love you, if you could? What choices will you make in the face of The Singularity?

[h1][b]The Good[/b][/h1]
+ Plenty of choices that actually affect the people around you and the outcomes of the story
+ Highly customizable robot
+ The philosophy behind the themes of AI, consciousness, life and death
+ A bit of political play on a large, global scope
+ Plenty of friendships/romantic relationships to develop around you

[h1][b]The Bad[/b][/h1]
- No save points
- A bit rushed towards the ending

If you love these kinds of themes and also happen to like visual novels, you're likely to enjoy this game as well.

20495132.review:
[b]tl;dr -> I realized that I am extremely superficial because in ~6h of playtime (numerous playthroughs) I have divorced my wife in order to marry my sexbot EVERY TIME. 11/10 stares right into my soul.[/b]

[b]Cons:[/b]

-super addicting, binged played it for 6 hours

-really makes you wish there were other great choose-your-own-adventure (CYOA) titles available (for other solid ones, check out the Heroes Rise trilogy (Choice Games) and Tin Star ("Hosted" on Choice Games)

[b]Pros:[/b]

-quite easily the best available CYOA text-based game on Steam

-300,000 word count - extensive amount of content and scenes, multiple endings to explore

-employs the "discovery" system - main characters are not revealed in the stats menu until you meet them

-your stats (ex: humanity, wealth) and your robot's (ex: military, empathy) directly impact the story and available choices

-every decision you make will affect the game and your unique story - the different paths are very different 

-amazing story that remains engaging with every path you decide to walk

-dynamic characters that will react to everything you do

-longer than most other CYOA titles in the Choice Games franchise

Of every CYOA I've played on Steam, none have come close to the quality of Choice of Robots. I explored the game for ~6 hours and still have not discovered every possible ending. There are many achievements and scenes to encounter, and the different story paths are all extremely interesting and well-written. I hope to see more Choice titles of this calibre. A must-buy if you enjoy CYOA games and robot themes.

ABSOLUTELY RECOMMEND!

Cheers,

[url=http://theroguereviews.com/]My Website[/url]

20483989.review:
[h1]A story for robo fanatics[/h1]

Any robot fanatic should try this out, you get to put yourself in that dream situation that seems almost so impossible to reach. As an aspiring sci-fi writer, I found this to be a very inspriational and satisfying experience. 

[h1]Possible spoilers below[/h1]

There are many paths, but I've only taken one, and it was an emotional rollercoaster. I feel like I would spoil the experience by going with choices that would go against my true morals. Everyone's path will be different, and I mean [b]everyone's[/b].

The paths last around 2 - 3 hours each, so make sure you have some free time ready as there are no save options.

It's very well written and very much engaging. At no point did I really feel like I was being restricted by the author. Hell, I went into this hoping I could live a gay robot fantasy, and you bet I was able to live a gay robot fantasy. There aren't many experiences out there that let you do that. The really fun thing about this is that the author doesn't ask personal questions, it just rolls with your choices and your identity without berating you or questioning you. It's not intrusive, either: at no point did it ask about my orientation or preferences (aside from asking for my gender), it just let me do what felt right for me, which in this case was fall in love with a male robot. ++ for that haha

Overall it's a very good buy for robot fanatics, but I'm afraid that may really be the only audience this can appeal to. I can't see myself suggesting this to anyone outside of that niche. So if you like them bots [strike](AND IF YOU ARE A DIRTY ROBOT FRICKER LIKE ME)[/strike], this is a great experience.

20457573.review:
The next day, you take Beast to the range just outside Cyberia, hoping walking around one of its favorite kinds of places will cheer him up. Although Beast had been excited about the prospect of your becoming more machine-like at first, the possibility of your death during surgery seems to have sunk in. 

The idea that you may not always be around seems to have put Beast in a somewhat melancholy mood. "I'm not young anymore, either, Creator," Beast says. "You might not think of me as aging, but technology ages even faster than people. I look just old and clunky compared to the robots around us. When you built me, people would throw away their computers after just four years. Their phones, after two." 

"Nobody's going to throw you away," you assure Beast. 

"Without you, I'll probably stop working. Someday." Beast looks off into the distance. "If I die, Creator, do you think I will continue to exist after death in some form?" 

(Assuring him that he will live on through the impacts he's made on people.)

Beast looks troubled. "But the person whose life I changed the most was yours, Creator!" 

When you are gone, I will destory myself. Beast exclaims.


Pros: 
+ Branching storylines (Unlikely to get the same story/ending each time you run through.)
+ Can be the Hero, or the Villain. No forced direction.
+ Can bend your robots emotions and actions to your will, (Teach them Love, Hate, or how to be bloodthirsty killers.)
+ Take over Alaska
+ Building relationships in this game feels important, and how you say or act towards people affects how things play out.
+ Found myself thinking, well what I'm going to want to do probably wont be an option, but 100% of the time it was.
+Become Rich and Famous

Cons: 
- You haven't bought it already.


Overall: All I can say is WOW. Coming into this game I couldn't have imagined what I was heading into. This game has so much character and is very well made. This is my first text based choose your own adventure game that I've enjoyed this much. Who knew that a text based game, could make you feel anger, sadness, love, happiness and power about the decisions you made in it without having actually seen it...? Well this game corrected my ignorance. You will not be ready for it, I can assure you.
This is not something that ANYONE should pass up. FeelTrips throughout. Definitely keeping my eyes open for any future projects Kevin Gold and Choice of Games will be working on.

20407649.review:
This game grabs your hand and whispers "run". It is almost impossible to stop in the middle of a playthrough, and there is always that "just one more time" feeling when you end it.
It contains beuatiful, emotional stories, and stories of war and destruction. You an be a hero or a villain. You can make so many choices that change how the world will be when (if) you leave it.

This game is my most replayed game. a Playthrough takes some hours the first time, and a bit less after that, as some of the choice screens are resued - but with different outcomes.
It is a very fun game to simply play through and see what happens, but also to go about with a  goal in mind - things don't always work out as you think they will, and some choices, while furthering your goal shortterm may harm you long term, and vice versa.
The game encourages deep thought and raises existential questions if you choose to play "as yourself", as well as if you choose to head for a goal.
You get to know the characters more and more on each successive playthrough - not all characters will be in every game, and some you may not meet at all.

All in all, very positive, very recommended.

20318398.review:
A choice of robots

This "interactive novel" is a work of art and love... I recommend its reading for everybody and especially so for sci-fi minded people and for all who're interested in artificial intelligence and robotics.

I was interested in the theme of this game / interactive book from the start but I postponed its reading with false arguments (which basically boiled down to this one : "why read a game that may not be so well-written when there are so many sci-fi books around, books which probably have better characters, plot and structure? i.e. : if I want a book, I should take a book.") And I was wrong. Because the writing of this game is much better than most books I've read. The plot has surprises and several turning points. The characters are interesting and/or endearing. The main theme is very well addressed, and there are lots of secondary themes that are well developed as well. In fact this isn't just good, this is great.

In addition to all these qualities, the author seems to be very erudite in many fields (or has good counselors and took the time to listen to them). In addition to computer science and robotics, this book consistently makes reference to both popular sci-fi culture (Isaac Asimov, Lois McMaster Bujold, and many others, ...) ; and to the classical culture (Shakespeare, Marc Aurelius' meditations, Buddhist tales, and many others, ...). There are even a few fun references to popular videogames and their subculture that are well timed and well phrased as well...

Political issues and strategic outcomes seems to be thought out with lots of intelligence and a surprising finesse. I'm truly impressed by this work, now!

The endings seems to be widely divergent (though I've not explored them all yet), and this book seems to have been written with love and lots of attention to detail. I've finished the story a first time, then a second time with a very similar path with just a few variations, now I'm trying to test a different approach to see what happens...

TL;DR -> Score: 9.8/10. Read it / play it. Now.

20259379.review:
I'm reluctant to write this review, but even at a sale price, I'm not sure this game was worth the money.

This choose-your-own-adventure text game starts with an interesting setting and gives you some interesting options for a psychological subplot while you go through the main storyline. You have a decent amount of control about the type of robot(s) you will build, and what kind of business or other ventures you will engage in. However, the interactions with other characters are somewhat limited, and become increasingly detached as the story leaps ahead years from page to page. If you've traded your humanity for success, that's a plausible enough story mechanism, but if you're doing a more "humane" run-through, it takes away from the immersion. Overall the last half or one-third of the story feels rushed, and even though the scope of the story is usually quite grand by that point, I found myself uninterested in it.

The writing in this story is tolerable, but not particularly good. What breaks the game for me, however, are the continiuty errors. For example, in one play-through, your lover ends up disappearing, causing you great emotional distress. Then, a few sections later, in a passing line, the story notes that this same lover has left you because of a particular political choice you made. Nowhere was it mentioned that the lost love returned safely, so it makes zero sense for them to have reappeared without explanation only to leave you again. This sort of continuity error takes away all value from the "choose your own adventure" aspect of the game and sadly makes me unable to recommend it.

I was just trying to create a robot at the start.

And I never thought she would return this feeling of love.

10/10 I would restart to do this all over again.

- - - - - - - - - - - - - -

EDIT (19.3 hours of total gameplay time later):

Lol, what did I just write up there.

So I spent around another 15+ hours or so on the game trying to get all the achievements and possible endings for it and I've seen a lot of more great story-paths aside from the get-all-close-and-emotional-with-your-robot-daughter plot.

One of my personal favorite story-paths when (and if) you get your robot to prevent the Sino-American War from happening and the events that eventally leads to, one of the many, many stories you can come up with in this game, like forging your own robot empire, marrying a robot, and even going to the moon.

The fact that this game has no visuals whatsoever does not bother me at all and it shouldn't bother you either. With whatever route you take for the story, the writing is excellent and there is always that subtle taste of humor somewhere mixed splendidly well with some moving moments. This aspect of the game is what makes Choice of Robots what Choice of Robots is. The game need not any visuals because the writing provides you what you have to see in your head.

The only real complaint I have with this game (and with most text-based CYOA games on Steam for that matter) is the user interface. Playing 7 hours straight on a game with a completely white background does not at all give you painful feelings that nearly make you believe your eyes are gonna blow up from their sockets Michael Bay-style (sarcasm intended). The developers should add the option to invert the colors if the user wishes to (from a white background with black text to a black background with white text).

Man, if making a robot were this easy, I would be making my Miku right now (then eventually get murdered by her in my sleep when she starts the Robot Revolution).

Если Вы желаете начать знакомство с трудами "Choiсe of Games", остановитесь на "Выборе роботов". Она наиболее полно реализует то, за что, судя по названию, стоит команда разработчиков. Итак, причины купить "ВыРоб":
  1) Выбор имеет значение. Каждое Ваше решение повлечёт последствия. Или нет. Некоторые просто случаться и пройдут. Вот тут-то и начинается игра в кошки-мышки с судьбой. Стоит ли нахамить генералу ВВС США? Имеет ли смысл устраивать среди соседей ликбез по пользованию компьютером? Позволить ли своему роботу поиграть в "Dragon Age"? (Это не шутка, такое вправду может случиться). Ничего не произошло? Не расслабляйтесь: интернет-тролль, над которым вы прикололись вернётся через двадцать лет и пустит Вам пулю в лоб. Или нет. Альтернатива-с.
  2) Качество выбора. Тут нет бинарной борьбы добра со злом. Развилки, предлагаемые нам, ведут к разным последствиям, но их нельзя интерпретировать как "хорошие" или "плохие". Они послужат интересам разных людей или групп влияния и по-разному изменят Вашу судьбу (или судьбу сразу всей планеты), но простого ответа Вы не получите. 
  3) Равноправные финалы. Прежде всего, возможных развязок тут целая уйма. Но, что важнее: правите Вы миром железным кулаком или тихо живёте в съёмной квартире со своей робо-женой, не остаётся ощущения, что Вы выбрали не "настоящий" конец. Каждому завершению истории разработчики уделили внимание и развили его так, что он чувствуется полноценным. Не останется впечатления будто Вам не хватило очков на по-настоящему крутую развязку, на разработку которой ушли силы и время команды. Каждый финал - настоящий финал.
  За звание лучшей игры от "Choiсe of games" с "Выбором Роботов" в лучшем случае может поспорить одна-единственная новинка. Долгое время конкурентов и неё не было вовсе и для меня она по-прежнему камертон, по коему я выставляю оценки всем прочим играм студии.
Итог: 10 из 10.
Рецепт: в палату мер и весов, как эталон.

If you like choose your own adventure books/games- this game is for you. (If you don't like reading, or robots, you probably shouldn't play this game) 

The story can go a surprisingly wide number of ways (this is not like CYOA books found in elementary school libraries) and has a little bit of stat management to keep things interesting. There are a ton of achievements also, and some of them are not the most intuitive to get, so there's a ton ton ton of replay value (I've played it 6ish times as of writing this review). The beginning of most playthroughs are the same, so you get a bit faster as you go and know what early game choices you want to make, but the middle and endgames are quite varied.

I always end up getting really attached to my little robots- even when they try to kill me I still love them.  

The writing is pretty good, the characters are interesting, and the choices you can make have a good spread between 'normal human decision' and 'absurd just for the hell of it' (with all variations in between as well).

Play this game, it's excellent.

Got through my first run relatively well, but I think this was the highlight of the whole thing. x'D 

--- 

You feel lucky that robot technology has never been hotter, thanks to the ramp-up in robot technology in the last war. You're able to provide for both of your robots, thanks to the money you make from working for Josh. 

Puppet, the more adventurous of the two robots, appears to have tried more tastes than Springtrap already. Like siblings, they seem to have settled into niches in competing for your attention: Springtrap now tries to be more humanlike, while Puppet occasionally flaunts his freedom to be strange. 

"Did you try dirt?" Puppet asks Springtrap. He walks behind the younger robot, who is putting out plates. "Dirt tastes very interesting!" 

"I don't think people are supposed to eat dirt," Springtrap says uncertainly. 

"Sure they do!" Puppet says. "It's called 'pica,' and it helps people get essential vitamins and minerals. I read about it on the Internet." 

Springtrap gives you a worried look. "We're not going to eat dirt tonight, are we?" 

--- 

My face and gut hurt so much right now. x'D 

Even if text-based choose-your-own-adventure stories aren't your thing (and I've never met anyone who didn't at least entertain the idea), you'll still enjoy the little moments like these among the many different paths this story has. :)

19584628.review:
There isn't enough game here to pay $5. There isn't even enough, if it were on sale for $1.

It's a branching path story game that decides what story to give you based on your alignment of a couple sliders. The choices are obvious as to which alignment they affect (building a metallic robot increases its military, and decreases its grace; giving it wings gives it grace and reduces its military usefulness). But, the story has to keep prompting you to interact with different parts of the decision tree, so you get weird things like being a multi-millionaire and choosing to employ humans in your factories in Detroit, but then you go to war with China, and now you're sorry you ever let the Chinese get near these things. What? When did the Chinese gain the ability to rip off my robots and make them militaristic? Oh, because I used cheap chinese lithium ion batteries? That's ridiculous. If my company is successful, and there's design changes happening, and materials are getting upgraded, let me source better batteries from somewhere else. Don't make me pick a motorcycle battery when my company is supremely profitable.

It's not open to be whatever you want it to be. You're allowed to type only on fields that don't matter: your name, your robot's name, your robots pronouns. You can't affect the story, you can affect the flavor text. If you choose one of the built in options you will rarely have a tie in back to the originator (Isaac Asimov names are one of the built in options, so you can get references back to those books in later dialogue if you themed correctly). But if you manually type in a name, Suddenly the game has nothing pithy to say about how your name and your situation relate back to the book.

It's not a very visually delighting game. Black text on a white background. Only one button is styled. The Next button. All other buttons are your OS' default look and feel. It's lazy design, and it hurts that it's not free.

The author chose to point out on every page of the UI that he is a Ph.D. which bears out my experience with most Ph.D.s. More concerned that everyone knows you spent a lot of time in school, than putting that knowledge to work. Good job on your Ph.D. now do work that isn't already bested by a group of people posting on free Choose Your Own Adventure forums.

19576323.review:
Played a few minutes, but don't think I will continue this one. I'm wanting an experience that feels somewhat like a classic text adventure, like Zork, where I'm thrust into a world and situation, and making decisions solely on my reactions to the plot. Unfortunately, this game is not properly delivering.

I have two main gripes about the presentation:

1) Too many of the choices read like quiz answers in fashion magazines, where instead of the answers just containing my possible actions, they also impute motivation into my character that may not reflect how I'm interpreting the situation. Made-up example: instead of the choices being "Cautiously open the door" or "Kick the door in", they are "Cautiously open the door, hoping nothing scary jumps out and eats my face," and "Kick the door in. I am a superhero, afraid of nothing!". (I may open the door cautiously because I'm a practical person, or kick it in hoping to surprise what is on the other side. A game should not tell me my emotional state; it should offer me simple, basic choices and allow me to feel my own emotions).

2) Some of the questions are not based on how I am reacting to the situation, but are asking me to make fundamental decisions about the nature of the story universe. While this is fine and a common replayability device at the start of interactive fiction games (e.g. "will you be a GOOD WITCH or a BAD WITCH"?), it's poor storytelling to force such decisions on you when you're already well into the plot. The question that I am quitting on is asking me who it was that just called my cell phone while I was speaking with a professor. Instead of the call being from a specific person and giving me a choice of actions (answer it, send to voicemail, etc) I'm supposed to decide who the call is from, choosing between three people I know. That's ripped away any immersion I had felt to that point and reminded me that I was a reader, not a participant.

19450934.review:
*********************************************************[Minor Spoilers]************************************************************

This game was simply amazing to me. I named my robot Versatilis, the Latin for adapt, and the origin of the word versatile. I allowed it boundless autonomy and gave it empathy and grace. I resisted the military's urges to fund a weapon of destruction built with my technology and suffered financially and socially for it. But choosing the moral path seemed to pay off in a small fortune gained through creating precise surgical robots. 

All was well until the Chinese decided to steal my designs and manufacture ripoffs of my robots, much like the way real-life ripoff products are made. I made a deal with an upcoming politician that I would fund her presidency if she made the Chinese pay. She did, and China waged war. Soon, to make up for the decision I made that ended up costing many American lives, and overturning my original decision to be a pacifist, I partnered with the U.S. Military to create nuclear powered humanoid fighting machines. 

China still prevailed and conquered America, but with great loss on their part. Seeing this, I staged an uprising against the Chinese in Alaska, creating a sentient robot army so powerful, I could have ruled the world. After conquering Alaska, ruling shortly as an equal among my citizens, human and robot alike, I crushed China, ending them militarily, and economically. I destroyed them until they cowered against my armies like puppies against their master. Then, I checked myself, preventing myself from becoming a genocidal maniac. I disarmed my robots and gave Alaska back to the U.S., ending war for good with the nuclear deterrence I created. 

Many years later, however, I physically pade the price of my years of waging war and replaced parts of my brain with AI hardware, acheiving ascension. 18960395.review:
I have played a few of these Choice games, including Champion of The Gods and Choice of the Deathless. Choice of Robots is by far the best one of the lot. Detail. Reactivity. Replayability. Maturity. Heart. Robots is superior to every other interactive novel out there in every way, and I don't feel that is an exaggeration.

In Choice of Robots, you make a robot. Surprise. You determine its appearance, materials, power source, and ultimately influence its personality (though not entirely). As you guide your "young" robot through the strange customs and idiosynchrasies of modern human life, the manner in which you teach your robot about the world and its place within it will have repercussions in future events.

I have played through this a total of four times, and each time, the ending I received was COMPLETELY DIFFERENT. Not only that, the game achieves the apex of interactive novel aspirations, in that it succeeds in making you feel like the ending you got was the "real" ending. In all of my playthroughs, I felt nothing less than total satisfaction with the ending. And in one, special playthrough, I came within a diode's width of choking up from the feels.

The game has a healthy amount of differing statistics, and these are CONSTANTLY increasing, decreasing and being tested depending on the choices you make. There is an excellent balance of player-determined and statistic-determined story changes, giving you enough autonomy to guide the story in the direction you want it to go, but not so much that it breaks the fourth wall and makes you feel like a bored author.

There is a reason this game has 99% positive reviews. Why not go find out?

18644947.review:
I think this is the best choices-matter, story-branching, multiple-choice, you-can-make-a-difference game I've ever encountered (so far).  It beats all the allegedly choice-driven games like Life is Strange, Tales from the Borderlands, assorted Bioware games, Alpha Protocol, Arcanum etc. 

There are multiple ways of solving problems, or avoiding them . . . and even failing to solve them is not the end (most of the time), bringing on more plot turns and twists. Some outcomes seem either unobtainable or inexplicable, but become completely logical in retrospect once you think about them. There are few to no situation where I felt that a choice was missing, unlike many other branching games. 

At first I felt that the 'no graphics; powered by imagination' bit in the sales pitch was cheesy, but after playing through for 5-7 times, I can say that that line was absolutely deserved: the game provides something that big-budget ultra-HD failed to provide to this day, even games from lines which are allegedly known for great stories. 

I want to see more games by Kevin Gold. I also think big companies should consider putting hiring and putting Kevin in charge of making stories for their games.

Below is the summary of my entire first game which took me 4 hours. The entire thing is a giant spoiler if you have not played yet! But I figured I'd post it for those of you who have :)

[spoiler]Summary of Completed Chapters 

Chapter 1 

On the day you first built Ariel, you awoke from a dream about a robot companion to head to the lab. Your graduate school advisor pressured you to make Ariel more acceptable to the military. After some back and forth, you ended up making a wooden winged robot with a humanlike head and humanoid hands. 

Then you went back to your place to teach Ariel some words. 

Chapter 2 

The next day, you hooked up Ariel's biodiesel engine and demoed for Elly. You then took Ariel to see Josh, who was impressed and agreed to fund your education if you would work for him after you graduated. Josh told you that evening about how he'd once been a juvenile delinquent, essentially, but turned around because he was inspired by Asmiov's book I, Robot to make a robot company called "U.S. Robots." 

As months passed, you became busy teaching Ariel about the world through the Internet and taking her to the park. Your funding from U.S. Robots kept you in Professor Ziegler's good graces during this time. 

In time, Mark Ali, a reporter for the San Francisco Chronicle, heard about Ariel and asked for an interview. You agreed. 

Chapter 3 

You gave Mark an interview, and allowed Mark to come back to your place to interview Ariel. 

Mark wrote an article that was generally positive about you and Ariel. When Professor Ziegler found out about the article, he was very displeased, and finally kicked you out of his lab. 

Mark's article also attracted the attention of one "robotObsession1987," known in real life as Silas Cooper. When you met up over coffee, he told you that he used to do classified robotics work for a government lab, but left because he couldn't tell what nefarious purpose the technology would be used for. 

Shortly thereafter, your father passed away. You resolved at his funeral to be remembered not only for your intellect, but for your kindness as well. 

You joined Josh at U.S. Robots as his chief scientist. 

Chapter 4 

Your first potential client for U.S. Robots was Galen Medical, a surgical equipment company. But they were unimpressed with Ariel. You couldn't find any other interested companies, either, and you eventually went bankrupt. Unemployment seemed to be common in the United States, and it seemed people tended to blame either robots or China. Riding on both of these sentiments, Jacqueline Irons won the presidency. After President Irons enacted a series of protectionist tariffs to keep out Chinese robots, Sino-American relations steadily worsened. 

The tensions between the United States and China came to a head with the assassination of the Chinese Prime Minister in San Francisco. War followed shortly thereafter. 

Chapter 5 

Captain Rogers invited you to a military lab. There, you saw that Professor Ziegler was copying your work and passing it off as his own to the military. Captain Rogers asked you to join the country's war effort. But you refused. 

Silas was worried that he was being targeted by the government's anti-spy measures, and asked you to help him. But you weren't very helpful. 

An agent came to your place to try to get you to lure Elly there, because she was suspected of being a spy. Elly was captured and incarcerated as a result. 

You found out through Mark that Juliet died while performing field tests of Ariel V, Professor Ziegler's copy of your robot. 

In the end, America muddled its way through the war relatively unscathed. Tired of seeing robots used for violent ends, you decided to create a truly beautiful robot. 

Chapter 6B 

You created a humanoid companion robot named Galatea, but you were fairly bad about allowing her to do anything fun. It seemed Galatea was interested romantically in you. When Ariel and Galatea were attacked in the street, Galatea accidentally killed someone. Galatea was forced to spend time in jail, but suffered no permanent consequences. 

In a last-minute attempt to find a life partner, you proposed to Galatea. And, what do you know -- it worked! 

Chapter 7 

In 2049, you went to Surprise, Arizona to surprise your mother with a gift for the holidays. You learned it was your surgical technology that had kept her alive this long. On returning to San Francisco, you had a brief stroke, followed by a vision of a robot companion -- the same one you saw thirty years before. In the hospital, the doctor told you you had Algernon's Disease, a rare disease that increased your intelligence, but came at the price of increasing seizures, comas, and possibly, death. 

You chose to replace the malfunctioning part of your brain with an artificial neural network. You survived the surgery, thanks to your own robot surgical technology. You celebrated a birthday party with Ariel 2, Ariel's artificial child, and looked forward to celebrating many more. [/spoiler]

18381272.review:
It made me seriously think.  

I don't play too many extremely narrative-heavy games, as I really prefer emergent gameplay sandboxes, but the concepts of robot ethics in this game drew me in, and had me seriously weighing the choices, asking me which of three or four things I valued most highly.  

There are four major robot attributes, and four general paths for robots based upon them, from robot revolution to lovebots.  

On the negative, however, the writing vacillates between clever and overly sparse.  Some of the romances in particular feel overly rushed to "get to the good parts", and involve little more than direct options of "make this person boy/girlfriend?" "yes" "YOU ARE NOW DATING!" Maintaining it is mainly a matter of "I will dislike you if you make choices related to specific topic I am focused upon", such as Elly's humanitarianism, or Tammy's paranoia about the government.  

The character that is overwhelmingly the most focused-upon, besides your own, however, is the one character you can't date, your prototype robot.  You can get her to love you and spend forever with her, but even making love-bots mainly means creating a new character to be a "younger sibling" that has far less development.  

Likewise, in spite of the fact that your romantic interest could be there at "birth" for your robot, your robot considering you "father"/"mother", and your romantic interest actively being involved in remodeling your robot, there is almost no interaction between your robot and your romantic interest.  (I.E. If I'm "father", why is Elly not "mother"? Why doesn't Elly try to impress some of her humanitarianism upon the robot? She instead chooses to just sit back and judge the way you raise the robot all by yourself.)

That said, however, it's dirt cheap, and I seriously stayed up all night just mulling over what it was telling me, trying to puzzle out the right answers, or else trying to find some way to wiggle through the requirements, and find a way to get everything (or at least, a greater share of what) I wanted.

18271901.review:
I hardly ever, ever, ever write reviews. It's true, you can check. So when I write a review for a game you should take into account that it hit me that hard.

This is a book. A CYOA (Choose your own adventure) book. Albeit a complex and much more complicated one.
If you are not a fan of reading long scripts of text for 1-3 hours (Took me 2.4 hours my first run) then that's alright, but I would still encourage this.

This game accomplishes something that most sandboxes and games that "emphasize story" have barely come close to doing; making your choice matter. This isn't a case where the story is the same with minor differences from your choice, but a real evolving adventure. One tale could have you create Skynet and cause the end of humanity. You could create the new iPhone-esque style robots with a company. You can conquer the world with a robot army. You can forgo the world and all people and create a robot child of your own to raise peacefully. You can live, love, fight, squander, become rich, become poor, become ill, overcome obstacles, and more.

If there was a way I could hit that recommend button multiple times I would, but for now just settle with a thumbs up.

In simpler terms, 10/10 I would find love and make a family once more, and prove my humanity still.

18211447.review:
How does one live with one's self after inadvertently starting World War III? This was a question I often asked myself while sitting in isolation at a military prison in the Caribbean. At least it was quiet there, and I was finally left alone with my thoughts. 

Every choice we make has unforseen consequences. Some good. Others bad. But then I guess it's just a matter of perspective. One person's "good" is another person's "bad". Many people died because of my actions. Or was it my inactions? But still, others profited from those deaths.

I lost my freedom while covering for a friend... all because she was into jazz music and gave me the one thing I looked forward to beyond my work in robotics.

And of course the robots. They were thrust into a world where many were not ready for them, while others sought to exploit them. In truth, I think I just wanted a friend. Someone to talk to. Someone to experience things with. Someone to be in awe with when something new is discovered. First it was one robot. Then I built another. I was not prepared for the responsibility that would be required, but I'd try to adapt. Later in life, I would learn that the responsibility for bringing robots into the world was very similar to raising your own biological children. The same rules applied, one choice at a time.

I've wined and dined with robots. I've danced with robots... I even broke a robot's heart.

Sometimes, I look back to earlier in life, and actually feel regret for hooking up those very first wires to control the gears and servos. But then I quickly find myself disgusted that I would even have that thought because of what good came out of those unfortunate events. Besides, why imagine possible paths to descisions I've already made? There are still secrets yet to be answered. (And some I'm not sure I want the answers to.)

No. I will move forward and be free. Despite the pain and uncertainty our choices may bring... what matters now is moving forward in the present, learning from the mistakes of the past, and plan for a future filled with peace and kindness.

A robot taught me that.

17784042.review:
Note: minor spoilers included.

You are [pick a name], a robotic engineer destined for tough times, greatness, and death. So apply your imagination, and you will experience a wild and engaging life.

The literature is easy to follow and presents you with a large bank of options. Its world is believable and full of unexpected, yet very realistic, turns of events that are guided by each character's unique personality.

And though some characters may appear despicable during the first playthrough (I forced one, Mark, to commit suicide), each one's unique personality and background will emerge as you experiment with different options (As of my fifth playthrough, Mark has risen to be my favorite character). This game will make you second-guess yourself if you commit your emotions to it.

You may experience academic success or expulsion, career success or bankruptcy, triumph in war or defeat, friendship, romance, total control or love for a child, betrayal, several opportunities for vengeance, the death of a loved one, your own impending death, immortality, among other values. And by the end of the game, you may reflect on all that you sacrificed and be forced to re-evaluate each one's importance in your life.

Overall, I, a graphics worshipper who normally enjoy Assassin's Creed and Mortal Kombat, strongly recommend this non-graphic text-based journey. Who knows, it just might change your life.

17783707.review:
Simply beautiful. 
I've only made one playthrough so far, but that's because I was emotionally so compromised I didn't dare a second attempt for a long time.
The written word is the one medium I deem to touch a mans most inner self and to move it to tears, which can happen in this novel just too easily, if you're even a little bit attached to your own creations.
It's not world-class writing (you're wrong here if you're looking for that), but it has not to be, it just has to tell you the outcome of your decisions and the reaction of your opponent, which it does marvelously. For the emotions and inner thoughts you are responsible yourself, and that should do a better job than every prefabricated reaction the author could ever present.

It's simple sure, but not shallow.

17777056.review:
Témata kolem umělé inteligence, syntetiků co nejvíce podobných člověku, robotů ovládajících svět lidí a podobně, nejsou ve sci-fi žánru nic vyjímečného a v posledních letech se zdají být čím dál tím populárnější, pochopitelně, protože jsou také s rozvíjejícími se technologiemi více aktuální.
 Jak už název prozrazuje, je to i případ hry [i]Choice of Robots[/i], jejíž příběh tato témata hluboce rozebírá.

 Hra je ve stylu klasických gamebooků, interaktivních příběhů, na kterých někteří z nás vyrůstali. V dnešní době to není nijak vzácný koncept, ale ve formě počítačových her je běžné, že autoři text obohatí i nějakou (ne nutně animovanou) grafikou či ilustracemi. Toto není ten případ, zde jde o opravdu defacto knihu v elektronické podobě s minimálním uživatelským rozhraním. Tady bych zmínil mou jedinou výtku k této hře a totiž, že jste odkázání pouze na bílé pozadí a černé písmo. Věřím, že pro někoho to může být problém, několikahodinové čtení za těchto podmínek na PC pro mě osobně nebylo ideální, samozřejmě není problém si třeba jas monitoru snížit, ale stejně mi příjde, že by neměl být pro vývojáře problém tam přidat i tmavější variantu.

Co se týče hry samotné, příběh pro vaši postavu začíná v roce 2019 na Stanfordské univerzitě, vašim oborem je (nepřekvapivě) robotika a blíží se moment, kdy započnete práci na vašem prvním prototypu robota s umělou inteligencí. Stejně jako vaši postavu, i robota si můžete pojmenovat a bude taky jen na vás, jak bude vypadat, jaký mu zvolíte hlavní účel a jakým směrem budete utvářet jeho osobnost. Budete chtít vytvořit robota, jehož mysl bude stejně chladná jako ocel, z které bude vyroben a který bude užitečný armádě (a vaší peněžence) a nebo snad postavu z ekologického dřeva, empatickou, co nejvíce podobnou člověku tělem i myslí, ze kterého může být výborný společník? Prvotní rozhodnutí při tvorbě prototypu budou důležité, nikoliv však definitivní. Robotovu osobnost a schopnosti můžete ovlivnit dalším vývojem, tréninkem, způsobem, jak s ním (či s ní) budete jednat a zacházet. 
 Příběh hry pokrývá až 40+ let, dle rozhodnutí, které během svého života uděláte. Tato rozhodnutí budou samozřejmě ovlivňovat i vztahy s lidmi kolem vás, z některých budou třeba vaši kolegové, kteří vám pomůžou ve vaší vlastní společnosti, kterou si později můžete založít, z jiných se mohou stát vaši rivalové nebo klidně životní partneři, pokud však nějaké lidské vztahy budou mít ve vašem životě vůbec místo. Jako průkopník ve svém oboru brzy zjistíte, že vaše výtvory mají vliv na celou lidskou společnost a dění ve světě. Co se stane pokud vyvinete dokonalé robotické dělníky, kteří vytlačí lidskou pracovní sílu? Jak ovlivní světový mír skutečnost, že se armádě dostanou do rukou vaše vraždící stroje? Jak se lidská společnost zachová ke skutečnosti, že se začnou množit případy, kdy lidé preferují za své společníky syntetiky namísto lidí?

 Nebudu zacházet dál a do nějakých podrobností, ať vám případně nezkazím překvapení. Každopádně vězte, že hra nabízí opravdu obrovské množství různých variací příběhu, důsledky vašich rozhodnutí se mohou projevit hned, někdy později či třeba až na konci hry.
 Pro jednodušší představu výše zmíněného si můžete povšimnout, že hra obsahuje 72 achievementů, každý z nich reprezentuje jakousi důležitou událost či vážný důsledek vašich rozhodnutí. A já jich při mé první hře získal 9, herní doba byla něco mezi 3 - 4 hodinami. Vždy to samozřejmě záleží na tom, jak si povedete, každopádně znovuhratelnost je u této hry obrovská.
 Vývoj vaší postavy (např. sláva, bohatství), stejně jako vývoj vašeho robota (autonomie, empatie) a vztahy s důležitými postavami, které jste ve svém příběhu potkali, pak můžete neustále sledovat na oddělené kartě se statistikami.
 Na závěr bych ještě dodal, že hra se ukládá automaticky po každé volbě, kterou uděláte. Nelze to tedy nijak ošidit, jak to bylo kdysi možné v papírových verzích :-) Se svými případnými špatnými rozhodnutími se musíte vypořádat, i to k životu patří a tento životní příběh člověka a robota je rozhodně zajímavý a hodný k prozkoumání.

[i]Pokud si budete chtít hru napřed vyzkoušet a získat ještě lepší představu, co můžete očekávat, na Steamu je k dispozici i demoverze.[/i]

17677469.review:
"It's not who I am, but what I do that defines me."

I enjoy a good story, and this was no exception. 'Choice of Robots' is a text-driven tale based on the popular choose your own adventure genre, where your actions greatly impact the outcome of your fictional self. Because of this, some may not enjoy the experience, whether it reflected parts of them they weren't comfortable acknowledging or they simply weren't interested in reading such heavy dialogue. I am a fan of reading and because of this I easily became immersed within the futuristic world and its characters. 

In a game that prides itself on interpretation, 'Choice of Robots' delivers on an emotional level which not only provoked my interest in the people I met, but questioned my decisions whether I believed them to be morally just or not. If you want a text-based story about creating your own robot legacy, then I highly recommend this journey to you.

17576645.review:
Choice of Robots (CoR) is possibly the best interactive novel I've ever read.

The description is pretty much self explanatory, but it's so much more.  This is a very well written novel in seven chapters, and while similar things happen during these seven stages, exactly what happens and how it interacts with later chapters is entirely up to you.  When they say the choice (and consequences) are yours, they mean it.

You might not expect much replay out of an interactive novel - certainly I didn't.  Well, I'm currently in my third playthrough.  Again, the core events happen, but exactly how and what comes as a result is entirely up to you.  The endgame for the two complete playthroughs so far were very different.

Do you want to be the 'bad guy' and, as the ad says, try to take over Alaska?  Do you want to try and launch a golden age with robots and humans side by side?  You can do both, or neither.  Each choice you make has the opportunity to lock or unlock certain issues, and how you handle these issues directly affects how your robots turn out.

The writing is top of the line:  The author is obviously well versed in the English language.  After awhile you forget you're playing a game and think you're just reading a novel.

I thoroughly enjoyed this game and so far have played through 3 different times to achieve different aims.  It is a little confusing at first to know how your choices affect the gameplay, but you get the hang of it.  I will be checking out the other titles from Choice of Games that are rated high for more choices and nonlinear storylines!

17530201.review:
This is a well made choose your own adventure game, with loads of different paths to take and plenty of different endings to discover.

There are some interesting ideas about what it is to be human, have a soul and about what life really is. There's plenty of food for thought and after this first read through I find myself questioning what I really would have done in the situations the author presented me.

Something that bugged me is how although the game itself is fully thought out and realized, the actual writing isn't. Much of the early game was simply presenting you with choices and didn't tell much of a story. It lacked character and meaning. However (at least in my ending) the later stages of the game are far more concise and this more than makes up for the early game. Now that the author knew for sure which direction my story was going I noticed a distinct change in not only pace, but tone in the writing. It was much more drawn out, presented me with far fewer choices and was just working towards the finale, which was really something.

Some of the writing wouldn't up as a book, but the pros more than outweigh the cons. Replayability is off the charts, with at least four completely different directions the story can go, all of which have a couple of other off shoots. As long as you play it for the great philosophy and science-fiction, rather than the writing itself, you'll have a great time

17529802.review:
Simple answer: you like story (even if it's more of a "tell" than "show" style)? You like reading? You like choices that matter? Good, you answered whether you like this game or not. Just check out the free trial if you are having a hard time deciding.

(minor spoiler)---- Robot Hitler, Check. Child becoming a Vietnam Vet, Check. Creating a world-wide technocratic utopia, Check. Become a quintillionaire pacifist who advanced robotics and green tecnologies by leaps and bounds while giving massive amounts to charity, Check.  =====(end spoiler)
And that's not even scratching the surface.

I don't know whether it's an extreme pleasure of mine to have met one of the best contenders for my "favorite game ever", right next to Star Wars Knights of the Old Republic, and Dawngate (R.I.P.), or if it's kinda sad that these modern games with ever evolving graphics just don't give me the kind of satisfaction that this game does.
The most major thing in this for me: your choices matter, sometimes extremely significantly...like, changing whole chapters significantly.
(Spoilers)=== You could be stupid and attack the FBI with 0 military stat...and be thrown in jail, and that's the rest of the chapter compltetely changed. In my Technocratic, pacifistic utopia, the ENTIRE chapter 6 was rewritten. ===(end of spoilers)
I don't want to overhype this, but it's pretty damned compelling, and the connections between choices are made simultaneously clear...yet blurred, if that makes sense. You feel like something you did influenced it, but at the same time, it could pass for generic material, which I think is very intriguing.
Not to mention, when I chose one of the endings, at the beginning, I noticed stuff...missing. Particularly stuff that included...like...i dunno...the statue of freaking liberty! 17507712.review:
I have only just finished my play through of this mind-blowing game. In it you play a brilliant Robotics engineer--think Hiro from Big Hero 6--who kickstarts the age of robotics. From the off it is full of choices your character can make, besides being very well written by the author. The robot I first built, Ariel,--the game lets you choose practically every aspect of them--was a daughter of sorts, having chose to activate the tiny winged humanoid while looking at me and naming myself as 'Father' to her. As she discovered the world around her and slowly, sometimes awkwardly, grew into a young adult under my care, I grew incredibly attached to her and it actually moved me to tears on more than one occasion. It is the most powerful game I have played in a very long time and some of the most powerful story telling I have encountered in a very long time.

Imagine a Asimov classic only you are the main character. My first story depicted a relationship akin to that of Doctor Lanning and Sonny from the film I, Robot mixed up with a reversal of the plot to Bicentennial Man for the protagonist. I brought about a golden age where man and a new species of mechanical people coexist in peace in the wake of a violent Sino-American war.

You literally can follow many paths through the way you design your first robot and raise them and your relationships with the story's many side characters. Will you achieve world domination? End man as we know him/her or live the high life as a Tony Stark type character? So many routes you can go down. Will you become an American hero or a backer of the Chinese? I have heard that you and your first robot can even become a crime-fighting vigilante duo!--but don't hold me to that.

Such an amazing game which, in relation to all others, I can only describe as a Bethesda RPG in text format... but with far better plot and writing.

In fact, I'm so impressed I encourage all who read this to buy it--it's less than £5, and I have been moved so to create this review, which I rarely do.

17505965.review:
Avant de prendre ce jeu, j'avais deux craintes : un jeu par texte peut-il être vraiment prenant? Et un jeu par texte entièrement en anglais est-il accessible pour un Français non-bilingue?

Mes craintes ont été entièrement balayées dès le premier chapitre : est-ce prenant? Totalement. Malgré l'absence de graphismes, l'écriture très imagée et les situations intéressantes provoquent des images mentales très puissantes et notre imagination tourne à plein régime. Ce jeu est le pur successeur des "Livres dont vous êtes le héros", avec l'interractivité et une écriture adulte en plus. L'histoire, quant à elle, est intéressante, variée, non sans rebondissements, mais surtout elle fait la part belle à vos choix : on sent réellement que le jeu, l'aventure, l'histoire peuvent basculer à tout choix (il est d'ailleurs parfois un peu cruel de ne pas pouvoir revenir en arrière, ou de ne jamais ou presque pouvoir réviser ses choix, car les conséquences se payent cash. Mais c'est le jeu, ma pauvre Lucette). L'histoire monte en plus crescendo et a la vertu, malgré son thème majeur sur les robots, de nous faire passer par des phases de "jeu" très variées, bouleversant d'un chapitre sur l'autre tant les lieux, le contexte que les enjeux. Il y a en plus une vraie gestion du temps, et on se prend à vieillir avec son héros. Enfin, cerise sur le gâteau pour un jeu de choix, j'ai trouvé que les ficelles scénaristiques pour remettre votre histoire dans les "rails" du scénario étaient très rares ou discrètes, à l'inverse de certains jeux Telltale par exemple, on a très rarement l'impression que nos choix comptent peu : l'absence de travail graphique permet ainsi de complexifier le scénario et le jeu s'adapte un maximum à vos choix, les "étapes obligées" sont rares.
Quant au fait que le jeu soit tout en anglais, malgré la présence d'un vocabulaire varié et très littéraire, je pense qu'un niveau moyen en anglais suffit au minimum pour y jouer. L'aide d'un dictionnaire pour certains termes (pour aussi quelques références culturelles très américaines ou scientifiques) reste néanmoins presque indispensable.

Au final, un jeu que je recommande pour tous les joueurs pour qui une aventure vidéoludique peut se jouer tout autant voire plus dans la tête et l'imagination, surtout que le prix est abordable (moins cher qu'un vrai "Livre dont vous êtes le héros", en plus pratique, aventure de 4h environ mais forte rejouabilité). Si l'anglais n'est pas du tout votre fort, que vous cherchez de l'action et du gameplay ou que vous n'avez pas envie de trop vous concentrer, passez néanmoins votre chemin.

17500015.review:
在说这游戏之前我想先说一下这游戏的开发商：choice of games（虽然带着独立的标签但是这开发商的全名是choice of games LLC，有限公司，雄心壮志 。我以为文字冒险游戏已经销声匿迹了，但是我去了这公司的官网，点进our game版，数了一下，这公司总共发行了32款（大多数是手游 游戏，设定众多，包括科幻、奇幻、机战、校园、西部和超级英雄，如果只是这样，那么这无非就是一家专门发行如今已经很冷门的文字冒险游戏的公司。不，这公司其实和valve和bethesda一样有想法，因为编写游戏的程序是开源的，官网上有单独的网页来介绍这公司制作游戏的程序，并且表示愿意发行完成的作品，所以这公司的游戏都会有作者的署名，想一下，有多少游戏的故事是编剧所写，有多少游戏的故事是世界上某个地方某个从事着和游戏无关的职业的人提交的。

choice of games在steam上发行了十几款游戏，预告片都大同小异，玩家的选择左右故事的发展，全文字、无图像和音效，但是有一句话道出了文字冒险游戏的核心理念：[b] 由巨大的、无尽的力量——你的想象力——驱动	[/b]。

可以说现在的游戏多少都继承了文字冒险游戏的元素，只是现在已经不通过文字而是引擎和显卡来增加玩家的代入感，来调动玩家的情绪，大小动辄几十G的游戏，要有生动的面部表情，细致的纹理，动听的音乐，对话要有配音，最重要的还要有个好的故事（就不说美工和动作捕捉要付出多少了 ，而文字冒险游戏，角色的长相、动作、表情，天气，环境，都通过文字进行描述，可以说上学时写作文的要求，就是文字冒险游戏的要求。

如果没有想象力的帮助，文字冒险游戏是很难玩下去的。灯光昏暗，空气中弥漫着烟味儿的零件店；戴着威尼斯面具的机器人；悉尼歌剧院风格的工厂。阅读着屏幕上的文字，同时想象着它们的模样，尽可能做出正确的选择。文字冒险游戏的一直守着全文字的传统，如果在重大的剧情转折处加入配图（甚至不需要全屏的cg，只要在空白处画上几笔，文字和画面结合的冲击力就会很明显 ，看起来像是妥协，不过也是点睛之笔不是吗？

17498894.review:
What can I say about this amazing story? It made me think, and interact on a level I haven't recieved by any game based on a first run without many discussions. I even named the robots I created after 2 human characters in Futurama (well one's a mutant). It was definately different, I was thrown curve balls all the time. I even had to deal with fucking Sarrah Palin, who practically caused WWIII with China (Not the neighbor she can see from here back yard, but China). You can even read my results of the whole story in this review if you'd like. Next run I do, I hope to die immediately. Have fun.


[spoiler]Chapter 1 

On the day you first built F.R.Y., you awoke from a dream about a robot companion to head to the lab. Your graduate school advisor pressured you to make F.R.Y. more acceptable to the military. After some back and forth, you ended up making a metal bipedal robot with a masked head and humanoid hands. 

Then you went back to your place to teach F.R.Y. some words. 

Chapter 2 

The next day, you hooked up F.R.Y.'s biodiesel engine and demoed for Elly. You then spent the afternoon perfecting F.R.Y.'s motor control and parts. 

As months passed, you became busy teaching F.R.Y. about the world through movies and taking it to the park. 

One day, however, Professor Ziegler claimed that F.R.Y. was not appealing enough to the military, and demanded you change it. You refused, and Professor Ziegler kicked you out of his lab. 

In time, Mark Ali, a reporter for the San Francisco Chronicle, heard about F.R.Y. and asked for an interview. You agreed. 

Chapter 3 

You gave Mark an interview, and allowed Mark to come back to your place to interview F.R.Y.. 

Mark wrote an article that was generally positive about you and F.R.Y.. 

Mark's article attracted the attention of one "robotObsession1987," known in real life as Tammy Cooper. 

Shortly thereafter, your father passed away. You resolved at his funeral to be remembered not only for your intellect, but for your kindness as well. 

You joined Josh at U.S. Robots as his chief scientist. 

Chapter 4 

Your first potential client for U.S. Robots was Galen Medical, a surgical equipment company. They were happy with the state of your technology, and gave you a contract that allowed you to purchase a factory. That allowed you to build a robot factory in Alaska. You decided to use your own robots for your workforce, but leave humans in supervisory roles. When you finally shipped robots to Galen Medical, they were pleased with the robots you delivered. 

Your business suffered a blow when Chinese companies, aided by Chinese government hackers, began to steal your technology. Your business was dealt a further blow when there was an explosion at your factory, caused by a bomb set by Tammy. 

You were visited by a politician, Jacqueline Irons, who asked for a campaign donation. Despite your unhelpfulness, Irons won the presidency. The newly elected President enacted a series of protectionist bills that ultimately made China angry, and they cut off the U.S. supply of rare earths. 

The tensions between the United States and China came to a head with the assassination of the Chinese Prime Minister in San Francisco. War followed shortly thereafter. 

Chapter 5 

Captain Rogers invited you to a military lab. There, you saw that Professor Ziegler was copying your work and passing it off as his own to the military. Captain Rogers asked you to join the country's war effort. You agreed, but specified that you only wanted to provide robots that were nonviolent in nature. But when your robots held a protest, you decided it wasn't worth it, and you backed out. 

But you soon realized that you were not happy working for the government and quit. 

An agent came to your place to try to get you to lure Elly there, because she was suspected of being a spy. 

You found out through Mark that Juliet died while performing field tests of F.R.Y. V, Professor Ziegler's copy of your robot. 

In the end, America lost the war, and the Chinese took over Alaska. Tired of seeing robots used for violent ends, you decided to create a truly beautiful robot. 

Chapter 6B 

You created a humanoid companion robot named LEELA, but you were fairly bad about allowing her to do anything fun. It seemed LEELA was interested romantically in you. When F.R.Y. and LEELA were attacked in the street, LEELA accidentally killed Tammy. LEELA was forced to spend time in jail, but suffered no permanent consequences. 

Chapter 7 

In 2049, you went to Surprise, Arizona to handle your mother's estate, since she had passed away recently. On returning to San Francisco, you had a brief stroke, followed by a vision of a robot companion -- the same one you saw thirty years before. In the hospital, the doctor told you you had Algernon's Disease, a rare disease that increased your intelligence, but came at the price of increasing seizures, comas, and possibly, death. 

You chose to undergo surgery to remove the damaged tissue in your brain. You survived the surgery, thanks to your own robot surgical technology. You celebrated a birthday party with Dusa, F.R.Y.'s artificial child, and looked forward to celebrating many more.[/spoiler]

Osobiście nie jestem fanem gier, które nie wyglądają jak gry i uważam, że jednak gdyby dodano tej historii obrazy, można by było bardziej wczuć się w sytuacje, jakie rozgrywamy, jednakże jeśli historia jest dobra, to nie ptorzebuje więcej. A ta jest dobra.

Jako konstruktor robotów podejmujemy teoretycznie dobre, czy nic nie znaczące decyzje, ale to onE mogą poprowadzić nie tylko nas, ale i cały świat do katastrofy. Bo choćbyśmy zrobili najelpszego robota na świecie, zawsze ktoś może chcieć wykorzystać go do złych celów. Nie chcemy mieszać się w wojnę? Musimy liczyć się z przegraną. Chcemy kogoś chronić? Możliwe, że swoim kosztem. Często miałam wrażenie, że nie ma dobrych decyzji i wybierałam tylko mniejsze zło, a i tak często obrywałam rykoszetem.

Kiedy zagrałam ponownie byłam zszokowana, że fabuła może być aż tak diametralnie inna, jeśli kliknę inną możliwość, choćby tylko jedną... 

Nie wiem czy jest sens w sumie pisać recenzję po polsku gry, do której niezbędna jest znajomość angielskiego, ale może Ci ciekawscy, nie znający języka będą chcieli chociaż zorientować się w czym rzecz, a jestem za tym, by każdy znalazł choć jedną recenzję w swoim języku ;)

17487671.review: Meet Steve, a blocky, cube-headed little robot. Taught to love, not fight. He is quirky, cute, and oh so loveable, and I've never even seen him. And meet Olive, my companion bot. She shows a little more complex emotion than Steve, but is just as likeable. Olive wanted to love me, but I wouldn't allow it. I was married, and although I accept robot marriage and robot-human romance, I was not up for it myself. She felt rejected. Steve was clueless, like a happy, yet genius, child. Though Olive was hurting, with her advanced emotions coming into play. One day, we were just taking a walk together, Olive and I. She asks what she can do with her life. I say she must look after Steve, as I am dying. She didn't want that, so I ask what she wanted to do. That's when she replied "Whatever I want," and then ran off without another word. That was the last I'd seen of Olive, after her murder trial, after all her learning and experiences with me, Steve, and my wife. Her and Steve, my creations. My children.

17482491.review:
Before you read any further, just know that this game is great, and that reading almost any review has the potential to ruin the amazing surprises in store. But anyway.

Here's a quick summary of how my first playthrough went, as spoiler free as possible:

>Make a robot
>Make a robot business
>Looks like the potential for world domination is in sight
>Lose robot business
>End up contracted into designing weapons for US military, despite best efforts
>Enter a new war of robotics with China
>End up imprisoned by America for half a year
>Refuse to defect to China
>China tries to kill me
>Live
>War ends as a stalemate
>Make a new robot
>Make myself into a robot
>End

I don't normally enjoy things enough to review them, so bare with me here.

My first 'playthrough', if I could call it that, it was much more of a readthrough, of 'Choice of Robots' took me just over three hours to get through, and likely could have taken much longer, assuming that I wasn't terrible and took so many 'bad' decisions, I'd say my first read could have easily lasted me four or maybe even five hours. It should go without saying, that there is an immense amount of replayability in a game such as this. Which is to mention, replaying this is definitely something I intend on doing, but I'm not sure that I'll be able to recreate the attachment & bond I had with my three foot tall, human-like, winged 'Ariel' with multitool hands, whom was vehemently opposed to conflict as a result of my actions.

See, Choice of Robots is a game where your choices can influence the course of humanity so heavily, that the sense of creating a story just for yourself lends to a sense of wonder and beauty that I haven't really experienced in many conventional books or text-based games in perhaps forever. Even though I could tell from about halfway through that my choices were going to lead me down a seemingly 'undesirable' route, (considering that my presumption was that I would shatter Capitalism and create a Utopia) I still continued to read on and make decisions based on the situation, as the writing and sense of achievement is so fantastically constructed, that I didn't find myself feeling sad, or upset at the fact that I might not get that 'good' ending, instead, I felt happy that in what is undoubtably a story of such scale & grandeur; mine was a story revolving around me, my friends & my family. This is what, in my eyes, we'd call a testament to the brilliance of the writing.

I can't speak of the aspect of how destroying the world may turn out, or how imposing a singularity upon humanity would be, but in my playthrough, the process of building up a robot in my own image, including its gender & naming it, right up to the viewpoint it had on the world, made interacting with my three foot tall companion really something quite special. Taking my creation which, at this point, had evolved into something so much more than just that, to the park, and observing the body language she gave off whilst she learned to properly kick off on a swing to propel herself up into the air was certainly pleasant. But knowing that our actions had turned her from being a military-backed weapon, into a video game loving creature of empathy? That was something else entirely; something I've not experienced before.

If you are even remotely interested in robotics, sentience, world politics and business practices, I'd heavily advise picking up this game. Even if you are just looking for a great story, you definitely won't be disappointed. I think the myriad of Overwhelmingly Positive reviews such as this give evidence to that.

My one gripe with this game, if anything, would perhaps be its length, which I don't even feel justified in saying, especially after just one playthrough. But in my particular instance, it felt as if certain sections were rushed, and that at quite a lot of stages, I didn't get the chance to sit and talk, explore and influence quite as much as I'd have liked to with other characters & situations. But this is completely forgiveable given the scale of the game and the immense replay value.

17478368.review:
Wow. I can tell you right now that you MUST buy this game.

I am fan of robots. Especially intelligent robots. They force us to imagine a world where humans come into contact with an intelligent species of our own creation and ask ourselves what we value in humanity and what we want represented in our creations.

This game perfectly captures what a "make your own adventure" should be. There are choices that you make that you won't see the results for until much later. There will be times where you eagerly want to restart the game because of a choice leading you down a undesirable path. And yet you want to see if you can salvage the situation because you created your robot companion, forged bonds with the people around you, and cause the stablility of the world to hang in the balance.

Example (*Spoilers*): I tried my hardest to make my robot (Legion) with empathy and autonomy so he would not despise humans. Imagine my shoch and horror as he almost betrays me at the start of a robot revolution. However, by making some tough choices, I managed to end the revolution (the robots still came out on top) and managed to patch things up with my creation. I grew old with him and my lover. At the near end of my life, he wishes to die with me, and wants to help me become a robot so I may live. I decline, seeing that I don't deserve to live forever and convince him that death is essential to being autonomous. My story ends with my family celebrating Legion's first daughter's birthday. I struggle to make it through, but through the choices I made, I manage to live on for a while longer and enjoy what I made. I, like my character, set out to make the perfect, human companion. What I didn't realize was I made the most perfect, imperfect companion. And that made him all the more human.

There is no music in this game, there is no fancy graphics either, but the story will have you immersed like no other and make you question how you would be in real life, and perhaps, what kind of impact you might make in the world. A definite buy for anyone interested in sci-fi, stories and where life may take us.
