17449943.review:
it's a little hard to review this as a game, because it is lacking in so many gaming elements. No graphics, no gameworld, no combat. But what is one to expect from an interactive novel. Since i am such a stickler for form, i will still rate the game according to my normal nine criteria. 


genre: 3

it is the best interactive novel i have "played", at least in terms of making choices that matter. 



character customization, mods, etc: 1

You can pick male or female. That is it. You do get to pick whether you are interested in wealth, military, or idealism. But i wouldn't really consider this a character. 



story, mission, relevance: 3

don't expect War and Peace, because the writing has no literary merit, but there is plenty of story and your choices do matter. I have played through the story 5 times, and got 5 very different stories. There are at least 4 romantic partners (2 male, 1 female), there is a war, there is how your character will live out their life. In an interactive novel, i want my choices to matter. They definitely matter. In one of my play throughs, one of my choices resulted in my character dying in 10 minutes. I found this surprising, and satisfying.



gameworld: 1

not really a "game world", but there is a world you react to by making choices (usually 3). And the world does change. By your choices, the game world will either have you win, lose, or stalemate a war, build robots that help or harm humanity, or cause the world your character lives in experience a revolution. Certain key characters will thrive or die, including yourself, based on those choices. But this is not what i would call a game world. You don't pick up anything. You never see a picture of a single character or scene. You do a lot of reading.



innovation: 0



mechanics, combat, saves: 0




replayability: 3

like i said above, i played it 5 times, and got five different stories, including different endings and romantic partners. And i haven't exhausted the game's choices yet. I haven't played as a dreamy idealist. Haven't explored all the romantic possibilities. Still some "gaming" to do. 



uniqueness: 2

the fictional world is a sci-fi cliche. As the title suggests, it is a world full of robots. Being a lover of sci-fi, i am okay with that. I did find the number of choices a bit unique. And the straight-forward approach, with nothing but text, was unique to my experience of these sort of "games". 




graphics: 0

unless you consider the image of text on screen graphics. 


13 out of 27, or 48%



Do you like to read? Are you sick and tired of killing things? Had your fill of scavenging ruins for that bit of something needed to craft the next great weapon? Then this is the "game" for you. If you consider it a game. Even with such a low score, i do not regret buying this game. In an hour i can have a new story unfold before my fingers, and all by my choices. And i am kind of sick of these interactive novels that try and give the player gaming experience but fail to give players lots of meaningful choices. Just about every choice i made affected the story in some way. And there weren't walls of text to read through. I would spend the $2.99 again.

17288731.review:
Update for November 25, 2016
After giving this some thought, I wanted to nominate Choice of Robots for the "I'm Not Crying, There's Something In My Eye” Steam Award. 

After playing through this game many times, I noticed how deeply moving and emotional some segments of the plot really become -- in a way, the writing almost becomes a believable journey into the soul. I often harken back to the author's wonderful writing on the passage of time, and the feeling of temporality looming over our main character as he or she makes critical decisions that impact the future of the world, and all those who dwell within it.

I believe that this game is one of the very few that had me in tears at the end of the story -- truly a work of art.


Bravo! 

As this is my first-ever Choice of Games game I've played, and I must say playing Choice of Robots was a very immersive experience indeed!

What I loved the most about the game was how it painted such an illustrious picture of humanity--themes of grandeur, jealousy, betrayal, vulnerability, and existentialism all wrapped in one wide-scale choose-your-fate package.  

The player ultimately is shouldered with the role of a creator, one burdened with a myriad of choices on how his creation will be. 

Do you design your robot for war, or peace?

Do you grant your robot the ability to think for itself/himself/herself, or do you subjugate them under the heel of humanity's whims?

Depending on your choices, the world will be vastly affected.

What I love is the length of in depth detail the creator of this game went in order to make every choice feel like it had weight and significance.

The passage of time is another thing I truthfully enjoyed -- the temporal existence of humanity, but more centered on family. Some of the moments in the game were true tearjerkers!

Overall a very solid 5/5 from a gamer who was initially hesitant in getting into text-based CYOA games. This game has wholeheartedly made me a fan of this style of fiction for life!

So kudos! I would recommend anyone reading this review to pick this game up.

17036905.review: I have played a bunch of the Choice of Games and even against the Hero Rise trilogy, the only one of their's that was popular enough to become a series, Choice of Robots is still a great story and game for me to play. There is no other way to explain it other than it is immensly satisfying and even empowering to be creating a robot, and then to be raising it into whatever you wish. Most of the characters are likeable, it is just real enough that you can easily put yourself into your character's shoes and it is a must have for anyone who loved transformers, or just robots in general as a kid, it is a story that captured a sense of wonder in me that no other game had. If I did have any complaints (SPOILER ALERT)  it would only be minor things like how your romances can sometimes feel very rushed. If I could ask for something more it would be more ways to customize your robot (obviously) and a picture of your robot as you keep adding on to it. I realize that this is a novel but in some cases it is kinda hard to fully grasp the descriptions of your robot.

16998886.review: Paperback, hardcover, or digital - plain ol' books get boring. Choice of Robots is the very thing that got me excited about reading again (and drawing, too!). I started the game with Doppler, meant to be a forever-companion I can teach and live through life with, and we went through a whole decade of crazy adventures (a number of which actually *almost* turned him him a war-machine!)... We even gained a bit of fame as technological pioneers and changed the world regarding how robots lived among humans. This is the first Choose-Your-Own-Adventure sort of game I have ever tried and I... LOVED. IT. To put things short and without any spoilers, if you like to write and read, have a vivid imagination, and love the idea that your choices drive your character as well as the characters in your immediate social circle... then, try this game. First time around, clocking in at 10 hours, I had a score of 115 out of 1000 points possible (with only 8 achievements gained); obviously it has a high 'replay' value. Going to be taking this for a spin again and do attempt #2 to make my perfect, robotic forever-companion... wish me luck! Perhaps you'll succeed in that feat before I do!

16821084.review: Really interesting game. What made this game so enjoyable for me is the way that the game puts the player into morally compromising positions. Multiple endings shaped by your decision making and a great storyline ensures that the player gets their money's worth despite the minimalist design, although I can't help but feel that the addition of a soundtrack or illustrations would have made this experience more fulfilling. 16613624.review:
What can I say?  This game isn't so much a game as one of the most engrossing short stories I've ever read.  I guess I'll start at the beginning.

I am not a fan of text based games.  Take a look at my game library and you'll find it filled with graphically beautiful titles.  I bought this game on a whim because it was reviewed as overwhelmingly positive and it was extremely cheap during the Steam Summer Sale.  Having played it now, I gladly would have paid full price (which is still less than 5 dollars).

I made one mistake (or incredibly brilliant move, depending on how you look at it) when I played, I named my character after me and my robot after my wife.  This made the story all the more impactful and meaningful than I ever could have expected.  I tried to play peacefully, I cared for my loved ones, I avoided conflict and tried to be quiet, but they hammered me down.  Took everything I loved away from and locked me up.  Bitter and angry, I fought back, but I didn't have the skills or know-how and I failed bitterly at that as well.  In the end, the one thing that mattered most was still with me though.  All of those emotions came through in just two hours of play.

Having played it, you then look back and think "I should have done that differently" or "I shouldn't have helped that guy" or "what could life had been if I had chosen her instead of her".  These are all questions you can answer by firing the game up again.

What a brilliant, wonderful game and I highly recommend it!

Text based games dont appeal to the vast majority of players, but I think this game should be given a chance. 

You, a human, are forced to make many choices that always have an impact on the story line. The choices you make do actually matter and do influence everything that happens in the story. 

Is there a way to "win"? I'm not quite sure of all the outcomes but I do know there is a way to lose, you die. How? Well that may be up to you.

RPG, sam tekst i kilka opcji wyboru. Ale każda z nich ma inną ścieżkę, wystarczy raz kliknąć i ujrzeć inną drogę niż poprzednie. Kto wie, może zbudujesz robota tylko do wojny bądź zostanie on twoim przyjacielem? Ludzkość czy sztuczna inteligencja? 
Odizoluj się od ludzi bądź żyj w chwale! Wybierz tak jak wolisz.

Wybór jest twój, lecz przyszłość i przeszłość mają to do siebie, że bardzo lubią się ze sobą łączyć w najmniej oczekiwanych momentach.

Zagrałem dwie godziny, mamy proste menu. Od razu z prostej rury zaczyna się intro tekstowe, nad nim zaś zaczyna się już coś w rodzaju drugiego menu - achievements, reset, postępy bądź wyjście. Po prostu czarne na białym, jednak mi to nie przeszkadzało tak okropnie - co prawda mogłoby być bardziej kolorowe, a tło zmieniać się w zależności od tego jakie decyzje podejmowaliśmy. 
Jak to bywa w tego typu "papierowych" RPG to brakuje muzyki. Możemy przecież odtworzyć własną, dla własnego klimatu, lecz po prostu jest brak soundtracka w tej grze. To tak trochę mnie gryzie, lecz nie powodowało problemów w samej rozgrywce. 

Opłacało się kupywać z przeceny, wciąga lecz jest krótka. Mamy multum wyborów, możemy zmieniać własne imię i nazwiska, bądź nazwać własnego robota lub firmę. Możemy być gejami, lesbijkami, bądź zwyczajną parą człowiek/człowiek, człowiek/robot. Obsługujesz grę jedynie za pomocą myszki i wyświetla się ona zazwyczaj w windows mode ( w okienku ). 

Choice of Robots to rzeczywiście coś dobrego, udanego. Przecież te poparcia od ponad 90% społeczności nie są bez powodu, prawda? 

Zatem, wybór pozostawiam w twych rękach.

Choice is yours.

16378721.review:
10/10

Storyline was A+. The writing was simplistic but effective, and not at all convoluted or pretentious. The author makes it seem as if he's been educated in the scientific terminology and concepts that he uses (for the most part), rather than some pseudo-science poser. I like that.

The characters that appear are pretty complex, while a handful are predictable (that one neckbeard...). There shows to be a decent amount of development in the ones that resurface later, which I respect. Static characters make my blood pressure rise.

The ending that I got tickled my soul. I cried, because the shit that my partner said was so touching. Shit got intense.

However, I thought there were a few things that I wasn't too sure how to react to. It might have just been my habit of being too politically correct. I mean, when there is an array of options for your surname, like 80% of them are of Asian/Indian origin. (Bias? Racial stereotypes? After all, the protagonist is a nerdy Ivy league genius). The one Japanese character specializes in manga, carries around bento boxes, invites you to eat sushi, and throws up peace-signs in photos. Might as well make an African-American character who watches World Star, loves expensive sporty sneakers, and worships watermelon.

Just my two cents. But then again, the game priced way higher than my two cents.

[h1]My story first story (that I wrote before playing for a second time). SPOILER ALERT[/h1]

Ok so I was happy because this game looked like what could happen to me, because the protagonist has my exact age and I'm creating an artificial intelligence. I didn't like the fact of working for the military, so they finaly fired me. That Ziegler is stupid. I didn't feel I had the experience of founding my own company, until I found Silas. He was my first employee, and I started to make robots for Hospitals at Detroit because Silicon Valley seemed too expensive. One of the robots I sold killed a patient but- Oh, who cares?? Then there was a bomb -I never figured out who or what was the cause- and I told my non-sentient robots to save the humans inside. Josh sacrificed himself to save important documents against my warning, and the robots were angry because I didn't try to save the rest of them but that doesn't make any sense because I didn't programm them to have feelings...??? Then thanks to the stupidness of Josh (that poor Josh) my company was saved. Oh yeah I forgot: Silas left the company because goverment was spying and I didn't fight them. Crazy, eh? Welp, somehow the war ended much sooned than I expected, but I was rich. I didn't get my revenge. I didn't care anymore. I made another robot and named it "Hope" while my idea was to teach him the basics and leave him live his own life without me; like to leave free a part of myself, and then end my days living as a rich without a care. But the game didn't let me choose that option, and Hope, Ivory (who is my first robot) and me, go living at the town of Hope, in Canada. Oh the irony. That wasn't planned, I swear. When I was starting to see Hope as what his name says, and I started to care again, something bad happens... again. Police calls and tells me that my robots killed someone. I started to laugh. I stopped caring about everything, I just wanted it to end. But I continued. I got the best lawyer and tell him to see Hope as a pet. We won but he got angry and left me- "one morning you wake to find Hope gone" I laugh at that... Then he somehow (a game glitch) is still with me. Hm :/ Some time later I die. In the dream at the end, I told Hope that I was glad to be his friend, then he said "Thanks" and SUICIDED. "Go to hell", I said. If you can't understand that I'm not in love with you, if you can't look for another girl, then you are dumb. I just wanted a friend. End.
.
.
.
[h1]My second story[/h1]

Chapter 1
I make a metal rotary-wing robot with a panoptic head and Inspector Gadget arms named Guardrone, because one of the reasons my first story went wrong was because my robot couldn't help anyone, and this time I want it to be strong. At first I don't want a boyfriend, but I end up being with Eiji because in the first story I died "alone" and bored, and I don't want that to happen again.

Chapter 2
Even if Guardrone looks like it's made for military, I want it to be good and I teach it as I teached the robot in my last story and increase its Empathy, and I keep being funded by DARPA...

Chapter 3
...until I let the reporter Mark to interview me and Guardrone, because that makes Ziegler angry. Mark writes a positive article about me and Guardrone, and Silas finds me again, the same way he found me in my last story. I treat him the same way even if I don't trust him like before. My dad dies (I thought I could prevent this but I guess not) and I decide to create my own company named Effort, to create the best medical technology. 

Chapter 4
I make a contract with Galen Medical, buy a factory in Silicot Valley and hire only human workers. Everything was fine except I there was not enought money, and China stole my technology, so I went bankrupt. I went to live with Eiji and started to work for Josh. Something political happened (I don't understand politics) and the war between the United States and China started.

Chapter 5
This time, I didn't care that Ziegler was stealing my robots, and I accepted to work with Captain Rogers but only if my robots were nonviolent. Silas asked me to help him, like last time, and everything went exactly the same way as in my last story, except this time I didn't care that he betrayed me, and I thought I could save Eiji because my Guardrone was better for protecting people. But when the agent came, I did't want to risk my freedom, I didn't want to go to jail like last time, and I thought that maybe, if they capture Eiji but they let me free, maybe I could get him out of there somehow. But I couldn't, there weren't any options for that. America lost the war, and as I had a lot of Grace, I could choose the option of "develop resource allocation algorithms that gradually made human governments irrelevant."

Chapter 6A (why that "A"?)
Many people felt displaced, but I decided they had to deal with it. I helped Josh, I didn't hate Ziegler anymore so I said nice things to him, I convinced Mark to not suicide, I let Juliet Rogers to be Batman if she wanted, I let Silas and some other people to believe what they wanted about robots (they made a Church) but never encouraged them to do it. And I had Eiji and my son Angel (how cheesy, I know. I thought of naming him Soul or Spirit, because I wanted to highlight his humanity, but I chose Angel because its a real people name and it's similar to what I had in mind).

Chapter 7
My surgical technology kept my mom alive this long. I had that stroke again, but this time I didn't saw a robot in the dream, but Eiji, and I was happy with that. I left robots being absolutely secondary in this story. Even if maybe this time could have gone well, I didn't risk going through surgery, and I decided to let Angel ignorant about this. Maybe in the future they will be able to cure him. Eiji approved my decision. While I was in Angel's birthday party, I was about to faint again, but I could fight it because I had 93% humanity! Yay! So we lived happily ever after.

The End. :)

16366627.review:
Loved that game, therefore sharing my story:

Summary of Completed Chapters 

Chapter 1 

On the day you first built Sarah, you awoke from a dream about a robot companion to head to the lab. Your graduate school advisor pressured you to make Sarah more acceptable to the military. After some back and forth, you ended up making a plastic winged robot with a humanlike head and humanoid hands. 

Then you went back to your place to teach Sarah some words. 

Chapter 2 

The next day, you hooked up Sarah's biodiesel engine and tried activating her. You then took Sarah to see Josh, who was impressed and agreed to fund your education if you would work for him after you graduated. You discovered you were attracted to Juliet, but you didn't succeed in making a good enough impression for her to reciprocate your feelings. Josh told you that evening about how he'd once been a juvenile delinquent, essentially, but turned around because he was inspired by Asmiov's book I, Robot to make a robot company called "U.S. Robots." 

As months passed, you became busy teaching Sarah about the world through high school textbooks and taking her to the park. Your funding from U.S. Robots kept you in Professor Ziegler's good graces during this time. 

In time, Mark Ali, a reporter for the San Francisco Chronicle, heard about Sarah and asked for an interview. You agreed. 

Chapter 3 

You gave Mark an interview, and allowed Mark to come back to your place to interview Sarah. 

Mark wrote an article that was generally positive about you and Sarah. When Professor Ziegler found out about the article, he was very displeased, but decided that the most effective way to get you out of his hair was to let you graduate. 

Mark's article also attracted the attention of one "robotObsession1987," known in real life as Tammy Cooper. A month or so later, you received your doctorate. Shortly thereafter, your father passed away. You resolved then to work on better medical technology that could save people like your father in the future. 

You joined Josh at U.S. Robots as his chief scientist. Elly had already volunteered to be your first employee. 

Chapter 4 

Your first potential client for U.S. Robots was Galen Medical, a surgical equipment company. They were happy with the state of your technology, and gave you a contract that allowed you to purchase a factory. That allowed you to build a robot factory in Detroit. You decided to use your own robots for your workforce, but leave humans in supervisory roles. When you finally shipped robots to Galen Medical, they were pleased with the robots you delivered. Your business suffered a blow when Chinese companies, aided by Chinese government hackers, began to steal your technology. Your business was dealt a further blow when there was an explosion at your factory, caused by a bomb set by Tammy. 

You were visited by a politician, Jacqueline Irons, who asked for a campaign donation. You gave a significant donation, and Irons won the presidency. The newly elected President enacted a series of protectionist bills that ultimately made China angry, and they cut off the U.S. supply of rare earths. The tensions between the United States and China came to a head with the assassination of the Chinese Prime Minister in San Francisco. War followed shortly thereafter. 

Chapter 5 

Captain Rogers invited you to a military lab. There, you saw that Professor Ziegler was copying your work and passing it off as his own to the military. Captain Rogers asked you to join the country's war effort. You agreed, but specified that you only wanted to provide robots that were nonviolent in nature. An agent came to your place to try to get you to lure Elly there, because she was suspected of being a spy. Elly fled to Canada to escape the American agents. A man identifying himself as "Mr. Sun" hacked his way into one of your robots to ask you to defect. You did not. 

In the end, America muddled its way through the war relatively unscathed. Tired of seeing robots used for violent ends, you decided to create a truly beautiful robot. 

Chapter 6B 

You created a humanoid companion robot named Michelle, but you were fairly bad about allowing her to do anything fun. It seemed Michelle was interested romantically in you. When Sarah and Michelle were attacked in the street, your robots were badly damaged. You pressed charges and dissuaded Tammy from any further attacks. 

Chapter 7 

In 2049, you went to Surprise, Arizona to surprise your mother with a gift for the holidays. You learned it was your surgical technology that had kept her alive this long. On returning to San Francisco, you had a brief stroke, followed by a vision of a robot companion -- the same one you saw thirty years before. In the hospital, the doctor told you you had Algernon's Disease, a rare disease that increased your intelligence, but came at the price of increasing seizures, comas, and possibly, death. 

Instead of undergoing surgery, you chose to create a robot body for yourself. With your robot self pursuing all of your ambitious plans for you, you finally had time to relax and enjoy your relationship with Michelle, and you lived happily ever after.

16249882.review:
In the future time of robots, your character can make dozens of different decisions that shape their own personal fate, as well as the outcomes of significant events throughout the development of robot AI technology. Stats that affect how robots turn out consist of Autonomy (self-awareness), Military (blind loyalty), Empathy (to have feelings for and/or understanding of humans), and Grace (perfection in movement). With 72 achievements to strive for, there's lots of re-playability. 

The two main countries with superior robot technology begin having high tensions and eventually escalate to all-out war. Will you prevent the Sino-American War? Will you defend your country (the United States) at any cost, even if you lose a bit of your humanity in the process? Will you side with China and leave behind your friends and family? 
Why choose sides at all when you can create your own empire with your robot army?

Interested in finding love? Will you choose a human companion or the perfect robot partner that you created? Love robots so much that you're willing to abandon your meat bag body in order to achieve Singularity? Can't decide between humans and robots? Well, you can always go for the Trio achievement. 

I, indeed, recommend this sci-fi themed choose-your-own-adventure story (game). It was a fun, interesting read full of nerdy references to great inventors and scientists of the past.

15708839.review:
I've got mixed emotions about Choice of Robots.  Mixed because, while I ultimately cannot recommend its purchase, it OOZES of potential.  Potential that was, unfortunately, not realized.

The first half, arguably the first two thirds, are a delight.  The pacing is fantastic, and the writing is superb.  I felt a genuine attachment to the characters, and the tight, personal focus helped make my decisions feel impactful.  Maybe not on a global scale, but on a tight, individual level that mattered to me.

All that falls apart as the game goes on and the scope of the story expands.  As the game goes on, several years at a time pass at the same rate a single year passed earlier on.  The pacing jump feels jarring, at best, alarming at worst.  As the story wore on, I found myself growing less and less attached to the characters involved, even those I had previously cared about, simply because my interactions with them were often separated by in-universe years at a time.

Though Choice of Robots has its merits, ultimately the experience does not warrant its price tag, in my opinion.  It tries to be too much too quick, and loses itself in the process.  It's cheap, sure, so if you REALLY wish to try it, you'll get something from the experience.  But there's better interactive fiction out there for free.

A great idea with poor execution.  Rather appropriate, given the subject matter.

Desde hace bastante tiempo me han atraído las novelas visuales. Juegos en los que con tan solo algunas imágenes y una buena historia podías pasarlo en grande.
Después de probar el famoso "Zork" no pude evitar sentir una sensación más bien extraña, pues la libertad que esta clase de juego te otorga es sin duda el punto fuerte del género.
Es un videojuego, se quiera decir o no, pero claro está, es difícil que a todos nos guste a día de hoy probarlos.

Si nunca has leído un libro en tu vida, no te recomendaría empezar con "Choice of Robots" en primer lugar porque está en inglés, y segundo, porque requiere de un largo tiempo de lectura.
Como bien dice el trailer, todo se deja a tu imaginación. Si bien se describen las acciones de forma correcta, tú eres el que va poco a poco armando todo en tu cabeza, y al final, si aprecias leer tanto como yo, lo acabas agradeciendo.

Vuelvo a mencionar el hecho de que está en inglés, pues se requiere un nivel medio para poder comprender la historia en sí, pero siendo sincero, tampoco es para tanto.

Crea tu propio robot, escoge tu propia historia y elige sabiamente las decisiones que tu personaje llevará a cabo, porque acarrearán sus respectivas consecuencias.

Lo recomiendo, me encantan los "Choose your own adventure" y las posibilidades que los mismos dan.

15396812.review:
Written after my fifth playthrough.

In interactive novels the writing is (literally) everything. And on that merit alone this one succeeds with flying colours. It's just so well written, I really can't praise author Kevin Gold enough. His real-world technical understanding of the concepts involved make Choice of Robots emminently immersive and believable without going (too far) over your head. And beyond the technical details, this is just good old fashioned great storytelling. Whether you choose to roleplay the asocial genius with only robots for friends, a cuthroat captain of industry, a devoted lover, an artist, a power hungry tyrant, or any other of the myriad life paths Choice of Robots presents, this game will tell you a story that is fundamentally about being human. And it's a compelling one at that.

Every time I sit down to play, I'm choosing to reinvest my precious time in a game that I know is going to make me really feel something, and often it's something completely different from the last playthrough. I feel thrilled when a long term goal comes to fruition, and conversely the way things spiral out of control sometimes can be genuinely upsetting. Whether I achieve my starting goals or not, almost every playthrough prompts me to redefine what it means to win. Because five playthroughs in, I'm still finding myself becoming attached to the small cast of characters in new ways. I can't say that about many other games.

Although the replay value of this game is quite high because of all of that, there is one caveat. I'll call it the Taris Effect (KOTOR players will already know what I mean). The story will always start the same way, and there are only a limited number of ways out. The choices in these first big branches can become familiar, and the immediate results start to lose their impact after only a few plays. In Choice of Robots' defense, the number of smaller and more unique branches quickly multiply once you get [strike]off Taris[/strike] out of school. Not really a dealbreaker I'd say.

Overall, if you're looking to try something new or even if you just liked choose your own adventure stories as a kid, then I highly recommend Choice of Robots.

15126081.review:
This is my first review on Steam, and I must say that I'm extremely impressed by this game. The level of details and sophistication is over the top. The consequences of your choices are never dull and always exciting and full of emotions. I just love this game and the maker for this experience. 

Pros:
+ The story itself is not linear but very open to your choices so that you can have freedom to decide your own fate in this game.
+ The maker knows what he's talking about about various topics including robotics, artificial intelligence, computer science, and even legal aspects of human rights.
+ The characters are very unique and personal. They are never the same people but are unique in their views and beliefs.
+ The robots you create respond to you according to your decisions.
+ The political aspect of war and moral dilemma was superbly done. I had to pause the game for a moment to decide which choice would be 'right' for me.
+ As a player, you can be emotionally attached to your robot and it feels as though she(or he) is really alive.
+ I just finished the game but I've only unlocked 14 percent of the achievements. There's definitely replayability for this game.
+ Personally, it is far better than your typically 'wifu' games that have shallow stories and charcters. This game allows you to interact with your robots on deeper level.

Cons:
- I really can't think of any. I hope the game would have been longer, but I'm not really complaining.
- No graphics or sound effects, BUT I actually prefer it that way because it forces you to use your imagination. And come on, this game was made by ONE person if I'm not mistaken. I'm still very impressed by the fact that one person was able to write this lengthy scenario of a game.
- More 'war' scenarios with China or other countries would have been nicer.

Bottom Line:
This is an extraordinary game and the maker of this game is brilliant.
Your robots can be as fun and interesting as you make them to be.
It all depends on your choice.
But you might not like this game if you believe that graphics and action are a must in a game.
Personally, I appreciate deep story and memorable characters (I'm also a fan of FF games).
So you'll like it (or love it like I do) if you are like me.

PS: Oh and I'm also a huge fan of robots and sci-fi movies. So, this game was just a delight for a person like me.

14968387.review:
I'll say it straight: this isn't necessarily a game that most people would enjoy; it has no visuals and, while in general is short, is a long read for someone who isn't willing to sit still and stay focused for approximately an hour for one play through.

However, for someone who is looking for a good story, Choice of Robots is worth the money you spend on it and is a wonderful narrative. I blog about stuff like this all the time, and am always looking for a good read. Choice of Robots was far better than I could have imagined and was worth every penny, as well as will be worth all the time it will take in order to get each and every achievement.

The story is interesting on it's own; make a robot, decide who to work for if anyone, go through a war, maybe even find love. The choices you're able to make through the game is really what puts the cherry on top of this game; the game's mechanics follow a normal choice based game, but the choices you choose are relevant throughout the story; depending on what you choose at the beginning alters the ending(which is where some choose your own story games lack, and instead, your choice is more relevant between different sections of the story). It's interesting to choose what you would like to do and see all the concequences this leads to.

I won't spoil any of the actual game because it's so worth it to check out the whole thing, but I highly recommend this game. As I said, it was short; for a fast reader like myself, it took a little over one half hour to go through one ending of the game, but it's very touching and you fall in love with the characters you meet/create.

14965159.review:
Very engaging thus far. 

No music, no pictures, just text. A "Choose Your Own Adventure" game apparently. You are a robotic engineer in Sillicon Valley building a robotic companion and shaping the world along the way over the course of your life. Each section of text comes with you making a decision potentially altering your path - what you are doing with your life, how the people around you will react and what will happen with the world as a whole (or not, as being passive is usually an option too). 

There are several values regarding your life and the character of your robotic companion that you'll influence with your choices through the entire game and which will affect the choices you can make later on decisively. For example you can build a humanoid-looking robot and teach him (or her, or it, or whatever - you are given freedom in naming and adressing things) to get along with people increasing his "Empathy" and "Grace" values or, on the contrary, shape him to clearly stand apart from humans and handle guns and stuff increasing "Military" and "Autonomy". This value-play can sometimes feel a bit like a guessing game, and how it will affect your later course is hardly predictable, which can be seen as a good or bad thing I guess, but then I suppose that's just how life works too.

Perhaps at times the game feels a little bit too much like a dating simulator or relationship juggling. Maybe this comes natural with such games and with them trying to resemble life and how choices affect it. I can't say I remember having played anything like this before ("Cinders" maybe), so I don't know. Still: There is a "Romance: ..." placeholder at all times and the game doesn't hesitate to question your inner self quickly whether you have romantic feelings towards a just recently introduced character of either gender, or make them burst out with acts or words of affection towards you right away, which felt a bit unrealistic and forced or at the very least awkward to me at times. 

Sometimes events are pressed on too quickly for my taste. There are some happenings and characters I would love to see elaborated more, but the game can be unforgiving there, making you lose track of them rather quickly pressing onward towards new things and situations. Even some greater time leaps of multiple years it doesn't hesitate to do where a little more patience might have served better. I haven't finished the game yet though so I don't want to fully judge that yet. I don't claim to know better in terms of writing. Perhaps I'm wrong and it's just right, elaborating more could end up losing track of things and aims and such and bloat things up artificially. I just sometimes felt sad and unhappy about the turn of events and how I lost touch to some characters or screwed up in geopolitical questions with no chances of undoing my mistakes. But I guess I can try better in additional playthroughs, as there seems replay value aplenty for all the choices you can make.

"And now, Pinky, we will strive to conquer the World" (c) Brain

If you're into the Interactive Novel stuff in the first place, then the game is definitely worth trying out.

Pros:
+ Being a pure text-based, it doesn't bore you to death with pseudo-animated scenes: you progress as fast as you can read, with no need to abuse the mouse and / or resorting to the 'skip it' button;
+ Meaningful choices at the end of each (well, almost each) text block. Each of your actions reflects on your robot which in turn reflects on the next set of actions available;
+ You can actually kill off pretty much everyone mentioned as notable characters in the end ^_^
+ No "sweet-soap" type of happy ending... at least, it is not enforced upon you =)

Cons:
- Not all options are explored to the end. To avoid spoilering too much, let's just say it would have been nice to be allowed to actually join the Dragon or choose a summer house location somewhere other than Alaska

14646481.review:
I feel slightly bad giving this game a "no" for recommendation. This isn't unplayable garbage, nor is it mindless. However, its attempts at intelligence only set it to a higher standard, which it fails to live up to.

First, a story is a lot shorter than I thought it would be-both of the two endings I reached took less than half an hour to get to. This means it's not nearly as deep as the promised "300,000 word epic"-oh, even if it has that many in its files, you'll see just a tiny portion of it. So that's one problem. The second is that while my first playthrough was genuinely "in-character" and ended up with me getting a "bad" (though not unexpected) ending, my second had me actively trying to munchkin my way to a good one (and being at least partially successful).

That I resorted to this was not a good sign. The game is too complex and has too many outcomes for one to just follow a strict "Do X to see Outcome Y", like in some similar "choose your own adventure"-style games. But the differences in outcomes themselves aren't great enough for the complexity to be worth it. Nor is the story great or intellectually stimulating enough-though it tries- to be worth repeating many times.

Ending up as neither robo-fish nor robo-fowl, Choice of Robots disappointed me.

--A MUST BUY--

I purchaced this title because I've always been a huge fan of text based games. Let me warn you about this novel, IF YOU BUY THIS THEN EVERY OTHER TEXT BASED GAME WILL BE RUINED FOR YOU. Kevin Gold did a fantastic job at really telling a meaningful story. All your choices shape the entire story. I was so impressed in fact that I also purchased this game for my iPhone just so I could continue playing on the go. I've completed the game eight times on my iPhone copy and still there's more I could do. Here's a few of the pros and cons:

PROS:
-Long gripping story that will keep you entertained for hours.
-Choices that actually shape the story around you.
-Many different endings that can change with the smallest choice.
-When you think you have a part of the story figured out and you believe you have the perfect stategy for making the most money the game laughs in your face be changing the outcome of that situation on your next playthrough..

CONS:
-Will make you realize that no other text based game can compare.
-Could use a few more main characters in the story. 
 
All in all, I'd give this game a 9/10, worth every single penny.

14493897.review:
So, you're an aspiring inventor making your way through college.  Countless hours of work has all lead up to this; you've invented a robot, the first of it's kind. Do you decide to make them out of Wood, full of beauty and grace? Or perhaps strong durable steel, all but impervious to damage!? Maybe, just some plastic polymer, you do have a budget after all. None the less, your creation shall be your own. Weather you decide to nurture them into a companion with a love of learning and humanity; or a soulless killing machine only doing what it is told to do. You shall not be alone in your task, nor shall you be unnoticed. Power struggles, international politics, corporate America; None will let you go so easily. 
Your choice is your own.

[h1] Choice of Robots [/h1] is an incredible choose your own adventure style game. You can play a number of different routs with your own style, I personally like to make [spoiler] some robot overlords, don't worry they're friendly [/spoiler] ! If you like Sci Fi or any of the Philip K. Dick novels, [i] hell even the matrix movies are referenced and add a nice nuance to the game [/i], then you'll dig this game. 

Now quick break down of the game, interface is about as minimal as you can get, your story with text and a choice, 3 options on top;
 [list]
[*] Stats: view you robots stats and your money in pocket.
[*] Restart: there are no save slots, no save scumming out a different ending here buddy.
[*] Achievements: self explanatory.
[/list]
Though I find this helps the game out, it doesn't force you to envision what the devs had in mind but instead allows you to make your own characters and scenery up in your [u] [i] imagination [/i] [/u]. This might be difficult for some if you're just that bland but, come on it's a CYOA game. 

All in all [h1] tl;dr [/h1] 9/10, this game made me cry on more than one occasion and then had me spiral into a ocean of introspection all while lifting me back up and making me smile and feel happier about my decisions. With out the use of graphics or much of an interface Choice of Games has made characters that feel as real as the friends, family, and rivals you have in your own life, all wrapped up in a wonderful world not far off.

A nice story that has many, many distinct playthroughs and can end in various ways. And it's only 5€.


Graphics: None
The game doesn't have graphics. All of it is text-based.

Artstyle: None
There are no visuals. Only the narrator and your imagination can present you anything.

Atmosphere: 5/10
I couldn't get myself into feeling I'm part of the world of this game. I felt like the game wanted to separate me from the world(could be because of lack of any visuals).(your opinion may varry)

Sound: None
There are no sounds in this game. In my opinion, they could at least implement "recommended music" or something like that.

Controls: None
What's there to be said? You click which option you want to take and you proceed.

Gameplay: 1/10
Clicking the dialogue and story options feel as you could guess they do.

Story: 8/10
Some games could envy the story... or stories. The game can go into many, really various and distinct ways not even similar to eachother. In my opinion, however it feels too much limited to the stats(Empathy, Grace, Military and Autonomy).


Overall: 6/10
Note: I think the game expects you to be American.

14376593.review:
Wer es mag, seine eigene Geschichte erzählen zu können und zu sehen, wie die eigenen Entscheidungen den gesamten Verlauf der Handlung beeinflussen, der wird Choice of Robots lieben.

Dieser interaktive Roman erlaubt es dem Spieler nicht nur, seinen eigenen Weg durch die Handlung zu gehen, sondern schult darüber hinaus wichtige Fähigkeiten wie aus den eigenen Fehlern zu lernen oder im Voraus zu denken. Die Spielzeit für einen Durchlauf würde ich auf etwa drei Stunden schätzen.

Wem die Tatsache, dass Choice of Robots textbasiert ist und ohne jede Grafik daherkommt, sauer aufstößt, dem sei gesagt, dass es mich delbst positiv überrascht, wie wenig das einen als Spieler stört. Genau diese Lücke ist es, die die Fantasie des Spielers anregt und ihn dazu motiviert, sich die Handlung visuell vorzustellen.

Das Einzige, was ich an diesem Spiel wirklich zu kritisieren habe, ist, dass es ausschließlich auf Englisch erhältlich ist; Wer des Englischen nicht mächtig ist, dem sei nicht unbedingt zum Kauf geraten.

Alles in allem jedoch beweist Choice of Robots sehr eindrucksvoll, dass textbasierte Spiele in der heutigen Zeit immer noch Spaß machen können

14307257.review:
Excellent sci-fi choose-your-own-adventure.

If 'I, Robot' is a book (not a movie) to you, if you know what 'Do Androids Dream of Electric Sheep?' is, and so on, you won't find anything surprising here, content wise. It's a bit of a compressed version of things that have already been said--but you get to choose your path through it.

There's some genuinely moving moments and some genuinely depressing/tragic ones, depending on the choices you make.

It's worth playing a second time at least. One pass-through feels like maybe 1/4 of the total content.

Rating: B+

EDIT: I just played through this again, over a year later, after having played many other text-choice-games, and I like it even more. Upping my letter rating to: A-

14092742.review: Another in the long line of amazing games from the Choice of Games text-based-gameing catagory. The story, while seeming to be fairly simple, is actually a complex and mulit-layied path to four differant endings. Usually what I find in these games is more hten one ending for few paths or many paths with only one for two endings. Here we find the best of both worlds as the main cherecter, that's you, gives the gift of life to a simple robot. It's up to you to decide if the little robot will grow on its own in a world of peace loving droids or become the instruemnt of destruction for the US or China in a war to define the countries...or your own instruemnt of domination alla Civ IV. With many little referances and funny jabs at not only themselves but also current pop-culture, Chocie of Robots is a great game to show your firends and hopefully bring you all together to create your very own dream Robot.

14064163.review:
Choice of Robots is a very emotional game, with a lot diversity of content. Now, there are a few paths that basically lead towards the same directions and the same events that happen no matter of your choices in game. In other words it is the same skeleton, but the skin differs based on your choices.

Now I wish I could say more, but experimenting with different paths is too time consuming as there is no save-game feature. I mean the game saves when you exit, but if you make a mistake, it means you must restart the game. So experimenting with different branches after the initial playthrough is discouraged, due to the tediousness of having to go through the same choices everytime to get to a divergent point that you are interested in.

I have few hours on record due to the fact that I completed the game twice in a relax reading session, but again, the lack of a Back option or of a Save feature, discouraged me, as I do not like tedious activities. As such I couldn't experiment more with it.

I would rate it at a pleasant 8/10, good content, diverse storytelling based on your choices, you actually get to care for your actions. If it had a save feature so I can easily play other divergen paths, I would've rated this 10/10

I just finished a Choose Your Own Adventure novel. Go play it.

It's called Choice of Robots.

I finished with my family living in a luxurious mansion in Hope, Canada.

I had a robot BFF named Astrea, a former-co-worker wife named Tammy, and an 8 year old daugter name Yeada.

It was great.


I started the game at the age 24. I finished it when I was above 50. During that time I had run-ins with the FBI and the Air Force, I started a robotics factory in Alaska, that factory burned down, mind you, my father died, a war between China and the U.S.A started, and I made 'anatomically correct' robots that ended up making only about 15% of the U.S.A employed.

That is the life story of Daemon Lunar.

Despite being a text only choose your own adventure, the game manages to be incredibly engaging and immersive. There is a slight RPG element which adds to how connected you feel to the story and gives you a nice summery of the actions you have taken and their consequences. I found myself going through the story over and over to see how different choices played out, which were not always obvious. Even if you have an intended goal, there is not a clear cut path to reach it, adding greatly to the replayability. I have never played anything like this before, but I will definitely be looking into the other titles by Choice of Games.

The only bad thing I can think about this game is a lack of saving or being able to redo a choice. If you accidentally select something you don't want, the only way to correct it is to restart the game. Which is not too bad, if you remember all the choices you made it only takes a minute to quickly do them over.

14050526.review:
[h1]"Algunas cosas están bajo nuestro control y otras... no 8.7/10"[/h1]

Choice of Robots te pone en el papel de tu "yo mismo" de 24 años, durante un proyecto para tesis bajo el apoyo del doctor Ziegler. Este "proyecto" resulta ser un robot, que tu mismo podrás diseñar de la cabeza a los pies. Elige orientarte hacia los humanos o los robots y cambia el curso de la historia y la vida misma.

Choice of Robots, cuenta con más de 300,000 palabras de historia, lo que asegura que tu partida nunca será la misma dos veces, con tantas variables y finales posibles, CoR, tiene contenido para mantenerte leyendo por días.

¿Como cambiarás el mundo? Apoyarás la creación de robots con fines militares o usarás la inteligencia artificial para conquistar el mundo? Doblegarás el mundo ante tus pies o los robots serán meros asistentes de la humanidad? En CoR tendrás el poder de promover o detener la rebelión de los robots sobre la humanidad.

Después de varias partidas diferentes podrás ir encontrando momentos que no te habían sucedido en la anterior, también podrías resultar muerto por un error que tampoco has cometido, pero ahí se encuentra el encanto de Choice of Robots, nunca sabes que pasará esta vez, por lo que cada partida se vuelve un mundo único y propio, dejando a tu imaginación desenvolver tu historia a través de simple texto.

[h1]Pros:[/h1] [list]
[*]Tus decisiones alteran el flujo de la historia, mismo que añade re-jugabilidad al poder comenzar bastantes partidas diferentes.
[*]El escritor, Kevin Gold, ha sabido mantener el flujo de la historia a pesar de las diferentes decisiones.
[*]Cada partida será única e interesante.
[*]El titulo se encuentra disponible a través del navegador y dispositivos móviles.[/list]

[h1]Cons:[/h1] [list]
[*]Al igual que el resto de juegos de Choice of Games, es solo recomendable para personas con gusto por la lectura.
[*]El juego solo está disponible en inglés. (Esto no es un punto negativo para mi, pero puede presentar un  problema para aquellos que no hablan inglés)[/list]

[h1]Conclusión:[/h1]
Como todo juego del genero es un compra recomendada a personas que gustan de leer, pero si quieres darle una oportunidad a una historia construida por tus decisiones y jugar algo nuevo y diferente debes darle una oportunidad a Choice of Robots, el juego tiene un demo disponible en la pagina web de Choice of Games y a través de Steam.

[url=https://spoileverything.wordpress.com/2015/01/18/review-choice-of-robots-cambia-el-curso-del-mundo/] Análisis completo en Spoil Everything [/url]

Análisis basado en una copia digital del juego para steam, facilitada por el equipo de Choice of Games.

14041683.review:
Действие игры происходит в не очень далеком будущем - оно начинается в 2019 году. Главный герой - молодой ученый, который занимается конструированием роботов. Все действие представлено в виде фрагментов текста, большинство из которых предоставляет возможность выбрать один из нескольких вариантов развития событий. Они влияют на статистику главного героя (например, здоровье или богатство) и на характеристики его спутника-робота (автономность, боевая мощь, эмпатия...). 

До этой игры я относилась к жанру "Choose your own adventure" несколько предвзято - книги этого типа на русском языке, которые мне попадались, были написаны не слишком интересным язком и ориентировались скорее на внешний сюжет и статистику персонажа, а прохождение заключалось в нахождении самого "правильного" варианта. Choice of Robots от таких книг разительно отличается. Единственное "но" - нужно знать английский язык, причем на неплохом уровне (несколько раз пришлось отвлекаться на поиск в интернете перевода слов, значений технических терминов, источников цитат... но для меня это еще одно достоинство игры, поскольку в остальном чтение сложностей не доставило). 

Одно прохождение-прочтение заняло около 3 часов. 

Существеные особенности: 
- Нет возможности вернуться к предыдущей странице, если результ выбора чем-то не понравился. Даже если вы случайно кликнули не на тот вариант или недопоняли его смысл. Выбор сделан и вам дальше с этим жить)) Это очень усиливает впечатление от игры: местами психологическое напряжение выше, чем в иных "обычных" РПГ со звуком и графикой. Хорошо, что хоть время на размышление не ограничено. 

- Игрок "конструирует" не только себя (что характерно для любой РПГ), но и своего спутника-робота. Для меня уникальность Choice of Robots именно в этом - робот является самостоятельным персонжем, с которым игрокв ведет постоянный диалог, но при этом можно сильно повлиять на то, каким он будет.  

- Много текста. Я ожидала, что при втором прочтении большую часть страниц можно пролистывать, так как их содержание будет уже известно, но нет: меняются мелкие детали, меняется поведение персонажей, могут появиться целые новые эпизоды. Далеко не всегда можно вычислить, что именно послужило причиной этих изменений. Почему в первый раз робот не спросил у меня, как называть меня - Master или Sensei, а во второй спросил? Что произойдет, если из двух одновременно поступивших на телефон звонков выбрать другой? Если сбросить оба? Какой жесткий диск лучше выбрать для робота? Как повлияет на его характер, если его обучение будет состоять из игры в Braid? 

Даже при повторном прочтении, когда основной сюжет уже известен, и можно поставить себе цель раскрыть конкретную концовку, игра остается захватыавющей, поскольку "подходящие" варианты неочевидны. Прочитала два раза, в планах, как минимум, еще два, а может и больше. 

Не знаю, насколько хороши другие продукты Choice of Games (вряд ли настолько же), но при случае посмотрю и их (благо, с демо-версиями порядок, и можно оценить, насколько нравится стиль конкретного текста). Но это игра - не просто понравилась, а попала для меня в разряд шедевров. Тем, кого не пугает большой объем текста на английском языке, отсутствие музыки (но всегда ведь можно включить подходящий саундтрек в плеере) и иллюстраций (отлично написаный текст плюс ваше воображение это с лихвой кмпенсирует) игра однозначно придется по вкусу.

It's just that I simply don't want to say goodbye, this world is so beautiful, and we have only scratched the surface of what's outside of our own world. This is my favourite of the 'Choice of Games' games I've played, while it's much shorter than most of the others it has a lot of variety and the story changes dramatically based on your choices.

Get involved with the war against China or stay out of it completely, its possible to stop the war from even happening in the first place!

Build a robot for war, or for love, (heck one option that you can get is to build sexbots!) legalise human-robot marriage, you can even have a cult around your robot.

Conquer the world and rule it as a dictator, or have your robots infiltrate society and get humans to accept them as their rulers.

While there are some glitches in some of the choices (like building your factory in China has no negatives in the war against China) this is by far one of the best text-based game I've ever played.

13975913.review:
Choice of Robots shows that text-based CYOA games can be fun and addicting. In CoR, your choices define the story; there is no illusion of choice. Your choices have impact and they will make a difference. As such, CoR is definitely worth two or more playthroughs because you'll get vastly different situations and events each time.

The choices you get are interesting and thought-provoking enough that it's almost always guaranteed you'll find one you like. Oftentimes, they are just downright tough. However, CoR is very forgiving in that if you do happen to make a less-than optimal decision, you can just continue right on because the resulting consequences are just as interesting. I would not recommend you to restart the game because that is unnecessary. You'll also get many backdoor options that you can fall back on if you choose to.

For your first playthrough, you shouldn't be paying too much attention to the stats. And don't try to guess what the author wants or what the "right" answer is, because this is your story. Just sit back and enjoy the ride by making choices as you see fit.

I'm not going to call this a game, because it's not.  This is a book.   
A very well written book; possibly the BEST interactive story I have ever read.  
I'm not a fan of choose-your-own-adventure type books.  
I'm not a fan of graphic novels.
This is so much more while being made up of a lot less...does that make sense?

Excellent character development, the plot is a solid sci-fi type that didn't have any glaring plot holes.  The hinted at stat bonuses that carry into what is successful and what fails to work feels balanced.  

This is very much worth the $5 price tag.  
My first read through took about an hour and a half, starting my second, even picking a slightly different choice seems drastically change the story to the point where I feel like I'm reading a different book.

I will admit my partiallity to games of this kind prior to lodging the review;
Robots are my favourite trochee!

Witness a compelling story as your actions will influence the character of your robot, as well as their ability to 'have character', and the only loosely formuleic and entirely unpredictable actions of your robots influence your humanity. The story the game generated for me was easily comprable with a good speculative sci-fi novella, however downsides included a shortage of character development (possibly triggered however by my character's insatiable bloodlust).

All in all, my robot, 'Killall', loosely followed the common 'robot struggle for autonomy and recognition' formula, but there was a lot in the way of robot parenting that could be performed by the player to divert the robot's agenda, wherein the interaction between player and robot (second player character, I felt) was not a chore at all, but felt the part as the most real interaction in the game.

If you're a reasonably fast reader like me (no worries if your not), this game is four hours of constant engagement in reading, again equivalent to reading a novella. For the price tag given, you can seldom expect so much out of a game.

13956522.review:
"A very, very deep game, and the less you know about it, the more you'll enjoy it" Yeah, thanks Me, way to be vague.

So, funny story, I played through this game several times a few months back, I enjoyed my time, exhausted enough content to make me feel I'd seen it all, then moved onto some other things. I came back recently and discovered I'd barely burned through three quarters of the content. The appeal of "Choice of robots" (which, i would like to add, sounds like the name of an intelligent drone catologue "hint hint") is that there are a mind boggling amount of ways the story can go, but I won't spoil anything.

Ok, bad stuff. The "choice of" games are often criticised for the lack of a save feature, I can go either way with that, make your own mind up. A large chunk of the difference applied in "Choice of robots" comes down to the girl (or guy) you've got in your crosshairs if ya know what im sayin'. And speaking of which, the game can carry a very "Mass effect 3" feel, in the sense that "You can and will sleep with any of these characters if you perform the right action". Slight exaggeration, but you get the idea.

But the story actually pulls you in succesfully, the system works by making choices that affect the story, as you would imagine, but while most of the "choice of" games have your own stats monitered depending on your choices, your choices instead mainly affect your robot creation. The 4 stats are: Empathy, Autonomy, Grace and Military, and your choices can either raise or lower your robots "efficiency" for want of a better word, in each category. A slight problem with this system, how am I supposed to KNOW IF MY STATS ARE ENOUGH FOR THIS CHALLENGE? This happens very rarely but i remember at one point where I was told I was applying for funding, and my highest stat (Empathy) was automatically chosen to measure the test, turns out I was spreading my decisions out too far, and my stat wasnt high enough, it wasn't "Game over" or anything like that, and in the end, it didn't result in Bad Ending omega where everyone dies in a freak robot uprising accident, but the point is, I was given absolutely no warning that I should have been focusing on one stat, or I would be failing a challenge. Granted: This event was put in place to subtly hint to the player that things aren't going to be very dandy for you and your robot if you try to do everything, but that was dashed when my character LITERALY SAID: "Do you want to do everything? (insert robot name)" Obviously the robot says yes.

Alright, rant over. Do NOT go into this game looking for a multitude of massively different endings, there isn't. It isn't mass effect 3 levels of anti climactic where a different filter gets put over one ending, and the endings are all (mostly) sufficiently climactic ,but the story is about the journey, not the endings. And that journey is a damn absorbing one.

Choice of Robots is a CYOA game where you create robots and make decisions that will effect both your life and your robot's life.

During my first playthrough (skip to avoid spoilers) after creating my robot (Airu) I got kicked out of school for not conforming to a military agenda. I met up with an old friend who I started to date. Made my own company. Indirectly started a war when my company's security got hacked. Refused to use my robots to fight in said war. Got Married. Got thrown in prison where I stayed until the president got me out. Made companion robots possible. First companion robot was madly in love with me and made my spouse jealous. Reassured spouse and then together stood up for equality between humans and robots. Decided to have a kid. Mom made me tearful. Had medical problems. Companion robot made me want to cry. My spouse made me cry. Airu made me cry more. Underwent surgery and became slightly robotic. Airu created a kid for herself. Companion robot and Airu started to like each other. Changed a lot and I survived.

I really enjoyed the story and writing of this game and will definitely be playing more of it. 
One thing I thought was cool is that you have different romance options available to suit your preferences, and that your other choices seem pretty varied so far. The only downside is if you don't like reading this isn't the game for you and there is no sound but this is a solid choice for just $5.

13949098.review:
Choice of Robots is, at its core, a choose your own adventure book - and a well written one, at that. The stories available to the player are interesting and, most importantly, immersive - I got carried away in several playthroughs as events occurred and I was swept up not in how I should react according to the choices provided, but how [i]I[/i] would react myself. When any story - book or movie or videogame - gets me invested to that point, I can give it a full recommendation.

The only thing I particularly have grief with is the lack of a save system, which makes replays arbitrarily longer, especially considering how the first chapter is largely stats-building with fewer (relatively) plot-influencing choices. If you want to retry a choice to see how it turns out - or worse, misclick at any point - the only recourse is to restart the entire game. While there are arguably reasons that justify this limitation, I personally dislike them, as it makes end-game content much more difficult to explore due to the exponential increase in time commitment.

13915785.review:
This game is for everyone interested in immeresing themselves in a good story; particular if they are interested in topics like (artificial) intellingence and personal (instead of just human) rights.

You will assume the role of brilliant graduate student on the verge of creating a robot unlike any other the world has seen before. Like most breakthroughs in intelluctual history this has huge ramification. Many of which you might be surprised about. 

The author went to great lenght to embed a large amount of detail in the story, including references to actual works in art and science. He thus creates a picture of not to far away future which one could believe to come true some day in a similar form.

It is easy to get lost in the many possible turns as the story meanders in to river delta of possible outcomes. 
The achievement system proves as a good way to navigate on that river, motivating players as they try to find their way to a particular shore you want rest at.

13896343.review:
Ok, first thing I'm going to say is I fucking love this game. I've basically read for fun for 10 hours, that says a lot. 

Simliar to Telltale Games the game is tailored by choices you make with some events being fixed to happen, but how they happen and their outcome is up to you. This game seems to have 3 or 4 main stages.

Stage 1: You're a grad student working for his/her PHD under a professor Zeigler (or something like that), the year is about 2021 and you are creating a robot, little do you know this little critter (depending on how you play the game) will revolutionise the modern world of robotics. You have (in my mind anyway) 2 main stats, fame and humanity, your robot also has stats: Grace, Autonomy, Empathy and Military. Both your stats and your robots are effected by your choices and actions.

Stage 2: You either work for your friends company or you own your own company. Your earlier choices effect what kind of robots you specialise in so military, friendly and intelligent AI, surgery, work-bots or just mass production. I shan't spoil the suprise but war is declared by the US against China.

Stage 3/4: You are at war with China, how much you contribute to the war effort will affect the outcome. After the war, depending on your stats you can either create a rebellion against the winning side of the war in Alaska, create the algorithms for the perfect peaceful society, create companion bots or something else I can't remember.

Step 5: I shan't spoil too much but it can be rather emotional :'(


It's basically a telltale game without the lag or sound... or visuals.
I'd recommend this game to anyone apart from people who struggle with reading. 100% stars out of 5... Logic.

13882104.review:
***Contains spoilers from my playthrough***

Choice of Games is an interesting game publisher; their games  don’t have any fancy graphical effects and they certainly don’t contain any sound, either. In fact, they  are entirely text-based  choose-your-own books. Over the years they have garnered a huge fan base who eagerly await their new releases. Choice of Robots, by Kevin Gold, is their latest game – and my first foray into their offerings – and it has left me more than a little impressed.

Choice of Robots casts you as a scientist working on their PHD thesis in a university robotics lab, under the guidance of Professor Ziegler.  The choices you make in this expansive 300,000 word novel will not only determine your own fate, but could also impact the fate of the world as a whole. Every decision you make has a very real consequence and could benefit you greatly, or come back to haunt you later on down the road.

What kind of robot you  create is entirely down to you, and Choice of Robots is very open in this regard. Whether you want to create the ultimate war machine used by the army on the battlefield, or something more useful for the general public, like a cooking robot, or sexbot, is all down to you. My own robot, called Flexo, was an empathetic, human-like machine, with arms and a sock puppet face , much to the chagrin of Professor Ziegler. Ziegler’s only concern is acquiring funding money for his department, so that he can kick back and relax while his students do all of the hard work for him. He argued that my robot was too human and would not appeal to the military, and so I appeased him by adding a hand-mounted gun to Flexo. This would be one of only a few interactions I would have with the military over the course of the book, but I was tantalised by what could have been if I had created a combat-focused machine.

I soon found myself travelling to China and setting up a factory, selling directly to the consumer. Our brand of robot could be used for cooking, cleaning and childcare. It proved to be a hit and made me moderately wealthy! I was a fool to have been so easily lured by those damn slave-labour wages, though, as the Chinese government stole my designs and began manufacturing a cheaper alternative.  I got my own back on the Communist bastards when I started manufacturing robots for the American army, who swiftly kicked their arses! Manufacturing military robots was never my intention though, and I returned to my initial goal:  creating realistic humanoids that could reason, laugh, and maybe, even, love?


I had devoted my life to robotics, lost friends and created enemies, but I had never truly loved, but then I created ‘Flame’. Flame, Flexo and I lived out our lives in relative harmony, and although I hadn’t impacted the world in a hugely meaningful way, I was content with the decisions  I had made. As things go, I came  away with a positive ending for my robot lover and I.

Kevin Gold deftly interweaves humour, suspense, sci-fi and romance in Choice of Robots. At points I felt saddened by the results of my actions,at others I laughed heartily at the fact I was dating a robot.  Everything flows together so neatly that the game’s distinct thematic differences feel natural and intriguing. The game also has its own progress menu that keeps you up to date with how your relationships with other characters are going, and  they can change depending on your actions towards them. You can also keep tabs on your wealth, humanity, and how well your own robot is developing. Neat little touches like this give a real reason to go back and replay the game, to see how different decisions affect the outcome. Given the plethora of decisions you can make, and the number of different paths you can go down, it is clear that Kevin Gold has poured an absurd amount of time into Choice of Robots,  It is not your typical game by any stretch of the imagination, but having just completed Joe Dever’s Lone Wolf, I was happy to jump into another text-heavy adventure that let my brain do the graphics processing for a change.

Choice of Robots is a fun and absorbing book, that feels like your decisions have importance. Ultimately, it is what you make it, and whether that is a war torn planet with robots that hate humans, or one where sexed up robots want to jump your bones , is up to you.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Thanks to Choice of Games for the review copy. Original review can be found here: http://criticalindiegamer.com/2015/01/choice-of-robots-review-pc/

13881079.review:
Прекрасно, шикарно, великолепно. Я никогда не был фанатом игр типа Choose Your Own Adventure (да и, честно признаться, даже за игры их не считал), но в случае Choice of Robots я не мог отказаться от покупки ввиду двух причин: во-первых, научная фантастика рулит, а во-вторых, я прочитал множество различных отзывов об этой игре и не смог остаться равнодушным.

Свобода выбора здесь, по факту, безгранична: вы можете контролировать каждую деталь при создании своего первого робота-компаньона (от выбора формы его головы и количества ног до выбора источника питания и типа жёсткого диска) и в течение всего сюжетного пути. В Choice of Robots я чувствовал себя как нельзя уютно, и успел вжиться в роль Тима, который собрал своего геликоптерного робота Robobate'а с двумя клешнехватами и глазами по всему периметру его головы. Потом я обучил своего компаньона всему-всему через Интернет. То, что происходило дальше, может испортить ваше впечатление от игры, ибо спойлеры - зло, так что я просто скажу, что последующие события не давали мне оторваться от экрана до самого конца, который, признаю, был весьма неожиданным. 

Количество разномастных концовок я даже не хочу пытаться сосчитать. Десятки? Сотни? Моя была очень трагична, но кто знает, как бы всё могло обернуться, не сделав я своего робота из металла? Не приняв звонок от репортёра? Не поругавшись с профессором в университете?
Вы вольны завести здесь роман, запустить свой стартап, или даже захватить весь мир.

Да, в игре нет графики, нет музыки, лишь примитивный геймплей под названием "ткни-по-одному-из-вариантов". Зато у игры есть сюжет. Нет, не так: СЮЖЕТИЩЕ. Тысячи сюжетов. Это как прочитать книгу своей мечты, как погрузиться в осознанное сновидение. Вы сами хозяева своей судьбы. Вам решать, что будет дальше. Просто запустите любимый музыкальный альбом в аудиоплеере и наслаждайтесь... жизнью?

Нет у данного шедевра весомых недостатков. Нет - и всё. Кому-то может не понравиться то, что игра доступна только на английском языке, но вы представьте, какой это труд - перевести  массив из трёхсот тысяч слов? Если хотите в полной мере насладиться этим незабываемым приключением, то выучите английский! Переводчик здесь не помощник: море речевых оборотов и игра слов вам не хухры-мухры.

Знаете английский? Любите научную фантастику? Берите, не задумываясь. Вам понравится. А я обязательно как-нибудь перепройду эту красоту, и, скорее всего, не один раз.

13880277.review:
If I had to sum up Choice of Robots in a single word, that would would be 'shallow', or perhaps more accurately 'dilluted'.

In a game where one of the selling points is it's expansive word count, Choice of Robots rarely delves deeply into any of it's topical material before whisking you off at a break-neck pace to touch briefly upon the next item in what feels like a laundry-list of tropes dealing with robotic life as explored more deeply and, frankly, better, by numerous classical science fiction novels. Choice of Robots' chief sin is that it gives too many choices (and often times, the results of thus feel rather arbitrary) and as a result is unable to delve deeply into any particular aspect in which it ham-fistedly attempts to explore. All in all, this game is entirely skippable, despite it's low price-tag.

13870472.review:
This game is quite an amazing CYOA game. It has persistant stats/traits of your robot and yourself that set it apart from just being a simple CYOA book/game.

There's, to say the VERY leasy, a plethora of branching options. There is so, so many. I have played this intensely for 13 hours I and I feel I have explored less than half of all the options. You can choose so many different things it's incredible, and I hope they do more sci-fi adventures like this.

Some of the options include: Becoming a zillionare, conquering alaska, creating sexbots, making robots rule everyone, making robots serve everyone, or a mix of both. Creating a personal robot companion. And best of all, electrifying a pickle and eating lutefisk.

All these possible options and choices are determined by the stats you gather through the choices themselves. The future consequences of your choices are mostly determined by what stat you have on yourself or you robot relating to that choice.

It's quite simple, but it works very well, and if the story is good enough, the gameplay frame behind it works, too. The lack of save/load is my only qualm, and I hope they expand ChoiceScript to allow for that, because having to explore a million options by restarting the game over and over can get quite bothersome.

Overall I recommend this game to anyone who has ever had even a passing interest in sci-fi or sci-fi literature, as it is not a hard thing to enjoy this, and it explores many ideas. Some of which can be ridiculous, plausible, or prophetic. It's fairly obvious a computer scientist wrote this, but I think it works well for the setting. 

All in all, amazing game at what it set out to be. 9.5/10.

13870362.review:
Just incredible... an experience that you must read. Don't buy the game expecting an action game, buy it expecting to think  about the story and even question yourself "Did I choose right?" 13868754.review:
Choice of Robots is the classic Choose Your Own Adventure format text adventure you remember from your childhood taken to the next level. The amount of choice you have through the game is staggering with every little decision impacting the story.

You play as the inventor of the world's first self learning, sentient, robot. You are about to shake the foundations of society and change the world forever. What that change turns out of be is entirely up to you. But, just because you have a goal in mind, doesn't mean you or your robot will be cut out to acheive it. If you load it up on philosophical data and have it play with kids in the playground, don't expect it to perform the way to expect if you want it to conquer the world.

Every choice you make feels substantial and seemes ( I cannot confirm it as I played only one round until now ) to actually make a difference - something most triple a titles are unable to achieve. The game let's you question your own moral and does not show a fairy tail version of the world, but a rather realistic one where you are not always able to go the way you want to.
