Un Chef d'Oeuvre... l'histoire s'adapte et se différencie à chaque fois...
Peignez un monde en guerre, en paix, devenez qui vous voudriez être...
Voilà la preuve, si il en fallait une que les graphismes ne font pas le jeu, c'est la trame qui le fait!
Ici, la trame n'est pas juste interessante, elle vous emmene à travers votre propre imagination, ce qui la rend quasi illimitée.
Je le conseille vraiment, 5€ pour un tel jeu vaut totallement le coup.
Un bon niveau en anglais est cependant nécessaire, le jeu n'étant pas en version française, chose qui m'a laissé un petit regret.
Je lui donnerais la note de 9.9/10, pour le manque de différentes langues.

Hier bleibt einem überlassen wie man seinen Roboter gestaltet. Wobei jede entscheidung einfluss auf den Roboter und die Umwelt nimmt. Wie Sheldon Cooper schon sagte: ,,Ich spiele dieses Spiel mit dem Leistungsstarken Rechner der Menschheit, meiner Fantasie :3" Es ist einfach mal eine willkomene abwechslung ein Text-Adventure Spiel zu spielen als immer nur irgendwelche Grafik sehen zu müssen oder nevende Geräusche. Es ist wie ein Buch nur eben mit eure Geschichte. Am ende ist man berührt von der Geschichte (oder auch nicht wenn man irgendwas falsch macht^^). Fazit: Mit eines der besten Text-Adventure spiele die ich gespielt habe. Wünschte mir dennoch man könnte es in anderen Sprachen spielen ausser nur Englisch. :/

13845254.review: A fantastic game with huge replay value. Keep in mind however that the game doesn't take it's self realy serious all the time, bearing that in mind it's only as joking as you want it too be. Every choice leads to a diverse set of circumstances that grows wider the farther into the story you get. At the start your a grad studant finishing what amounts to the first truly working robot ai that sets the standard if you let it. You get to choose the peices that make up it's form from a wide variety of parts, and then you shape how the robot grows. It can be anything from mindless killing machine to a companion equal to any human, to a god like entity that shapes the course of history, or you can end use it to further your own ambitions. Your personal life impacts your work and how your robot grows. The comedy is fantastic and ocasionaly if you want it, fourth wall breaking.  Please take the time if your a sci-fi buff to buy this game.

13838291.review:
Now, I DID enjoy this game. Author had a way with words, don'tyasee? Plenty of moments that induced things like frission, wonder, pride and the like. You could do just about anything you can imagine with your creations, from becoming a dictator of your own nation, to subtly controlling the world through voodoo mind-trick computer program back-doors, to even establishing a religion based around your mechanical men. Because of these qualities, I would recommend it.

However, as a warning to anybody who bought this for a similar reason that the ol' Colonel did, in hopes of exploring a "Her"-like smokin' robo-romance, I must say... The only thing you CAN'T seem to do in this game is put the moves on a hot robot missus! The content just isn't there. You can't get sweet on the first robot you make no matter what you do, and your interactions with any others feel completely forced and artificial (pun not intended, you hooligans). 

There are also several "bugs" that've right flustered me, such as story branches that should be impossible - imprisoned or dead characters suddenly rising from the grave or bustin' out of the big house for no apparent reason, previous decisions that should've made certain things impossible having no influence, et cetera. Doesn't impact the story too much, though. 

Overall, I give this game 3 out of 5 drumsticks.

13837228.review:
TL;DR Much awesome, robots, a must play for people who like choices and reading.

When I started playing this, I thought it would be a quick jaunt through some basic choices. I turned out to be an engaging and well spun tale complete with tough decisions and moral choices. Each time your playthrough the game it offers you a new path to follow and a new direction for the story to go. It was the little things for me like naming my personal robots, my company, and even my own child that really made it memorable and more interactive and immersive. Overall, it was well written, engaging, and definitely replayable. Also, it's packed with achievements if hunting them down is your thing.

I would recommend this to anyone who has a love of science fiction, choices, reading, or clicking boxes!

13836027.review:
In my first playthrough, I wasn't sure exactly what I was expected so I played how I would probably do in real life and ended up with a personable robot that became so autonomous it started demanding additional wages for it and its fellow robots.  My second playthough I took the role of a typical "profits first" CEO and ended up with a race of robots determined to take over the planet.   With a gun pointed at my head I either had the choice of helping them achieve singularity or I would be killed.

The amount of work put into this book is rather amazing.  The beginning is repetitious in subsequent playthroughs because the time is spent designing and building your robot.  After this point, however, your story can vary wildly.  A lot of philosophical questions are addressed throughout your life.  It's reminiscent of Asimov in a number of ways.  Occasionally, you are limited to choices that differ from what you want to do, but not often.  

For completionists, there are a number of achievements to get depending on what you've done or who you've become.  The game suggests you look through them, I suggest you avoid doing so unless you have played through many times.

Make no mistake, this is a book, but I couldn't put it down.  Plus, the digital format helps avoid the temptation to cheat skipping ahead to the results.  Recommended.

+ nicely strung together (I made a pretty strange robot, but the story nicely accomodated for it)

9/10

SPOILERS

I became a war profiteer by making hyper-intelligent warbots with a strong sense of morality for the military which conquered China. And eventually the robots realized just how flawed humans are, they revolted and I got executed.

Nachdem ich das Spiel aus Neugierde gekauft und installiert hatte (dauert nur wenige Minuten) wollte ich es vor dem zu Bett gehen kurz antesten. Mit dem Ergebnis das ich 5.5 Stunden durchgespielt habe, und es inzwischen 05:00 Morgens ist.
Meine Befürchtung, das ich mit dem englischen Text Probleme haben würde waren unbegründet, er ist leicht verständlich.
Ein Spiel das nur aus Text besteht. Unvorstellbar? Für mich nicht mehr. Die Bilder dazu entstehen automatisch im Kopf, weil man in die Story regelrecht hineingezogen wird.
Für heute ist Schluß, aber morgen starte ich das Spiel nochmal, und gehe neue Wege. Diesmal habe ich glorreich, und ohne Waffen oder Intrigen überlebt. Ob es mir im nächsten Durchgang auch gelingen wird?

This is a text-based game around robots. Your actions and decisions throughout the game will have an immense impact on the further development of the story. A story with so many choices, endings and comical pearls - once dramatic, once romantic and once militaristic. Which path will you take? Needless to say, this means there is a lot of replayability value. I'm currently at my third playthrough and I'm enjoying every single minute of it. Absolutely recommended.






"Father, I am proud to report 1,126 headshots in a row!" Famulus calls after you. "Also, I am having a very curious conversation with a player who accused me of being a bot, but then did not believe me when I confirmed his hypothesis!"

13818061.review:
This is a great game: it's well written, thought provoking and packs a surprisingly emotional punch!  Discovering how the seemingly insignificant choices can later come to change the storyline makes for a really interesting journey and if you're a robot fan there are lots of ideas, jokes and references to enjoy: from Asimov to Optimus (and If you're a really big robot fan you can even marry one!)

I'm finding this has much more replay potential than I first expected too. It's a big story and there are a lot of different strands. At first I learned a lot about myself going through trying to make honest, heartfelt choices (turns out I'm not much of a KillBot Overlord type at all). Now the list of 72 achievements is keeping me coming back trying out different paths (though I'm completely stuck for how to get a few of them!) Don't let that plain white screen out you off. After so many games with ever flashier graphics and movie-length cut scenes it’s quite refreshing to let my imagination do the bulk of the processing for once!

13776628.review:
As a gamer who usually plays games with fancy graphics, I didn't quite expect myself to try out a game like this. I had several games from several different categories, and i never thought of playing an interactive novel before. During the holiday season, i noticed this game, oddly titled Choice of robots, but it was really cheap, and had good reviews, so i picked it up. Maybe it was my nostalgia towards books, or maybe my curiosity for something different, but i did find myself pleasantly surprised by this text based adventure. It touched my heart in a way no other game has done before, and made me learn something about myself, even things i didn't even think would in me. It showed me flaws in myself, and generally actually did make me a better person. 

I highly reccomend this game, as it seems like it has a bit for everyone, and it has the potential to really learn about our true selves.

10/10, amazing story

13775861.review:
If you like Choose Your Own Adventure books, this is well worth checking out. It takes the experience of CYOA and keeps you from "cheating" through the story (you know what I mean, who hasn't checked out what the answers are to the various choices before committing?). I know that the other game I got from this publisher was based on the fantasy world they created in a regular book trilogy, so I will to see if Kevin Gold has his own set of books worth reading. 

Be warned, this is a text-based adventure game. There are no flashy graphics - there is reading and a lot of choices.

13774797.review: A fun text-based game that gives you a lot of options and freedom.

13773292.review: Probably the best game I've played from, 'Choice of Games'. Now, I've only played four of their games, but I don't know if they could ever top this game. The ideas presented on robotics, humanity, and their future combination has been said before, but the story sucks you in just enough to make every choice seem real. That is if you're actually paying attention to the story at hand. I've played through it several times, and I have to say that my favorite features are in the chooseable beginnings, the shaping of your first robot, and in the dilemma's presented in wanting to make something more human or something completely machine. I don't want to go anymore into it for fear of spoiling something, but I have to say that this is a great buy.

13773278.review:
I didn't expect that very first choice to have the impact it did, but it did.

I've been fond of CoG's listing of interactive novels ever since I found the Heroes Rise set, which was a wonderful three parter. Then it was Mecha Ace, and now Choice of Robots.

You affect the world, you affect everything around you with the choices you make. Is your robot going to be a soulless military machine? An emotional believer in robot-human rights? Or something else in between? Will you hate all the humans and assume they're exploiting you, or work with one or two and see where the road takes you?

It's a long road, and there are so many ways for it to end.

"Happy birthday, to you..."

13698568.review:
(Changes have been made to CoR since this review was written.)
I recently finished playing "Choice of Robots". My first time through I lost badly.I'm still trying to wrap my head around how my own personal choices were deemed inferior. But since it was MY story, I'll have to accept my failings, though I have to expect the creator/writer of EVERY choice I made to be willing to share those flaws.
I've played many text games. When I began playing there wasn't much else, unless you wanted to play Pong. Zork, which I played in 1985, is still perhaps my favorite computer gaming experience. Some of the WONDERFUL Infocom games, such as "Suspended: A Cryogenic Nightmare" actually benefited from being purely text. 
I've read many pages of science fiction. Between my two favorite catagories, science fiction and fantasy, the pages literally number well over a million, so there aren't many speculative fiction concepts I've not encountered.
But we're here to discuss "Choice of Robots". First off, on the basis of cost/hour this is among the MOST expensive, shortest computer games I have ever played. True, it was less than $3 (on sale), but lasted under 2 hours (even with starting over on PC #2), most of the time spent in thought. There was nothing new in this game, beyond perhaps some of the more recent concepts not devised yet when I was doing the bulk  of my reading. As far as robotics, Asimov has already said pretty much everything encountered in this story, better. While Dr. Gold has allowed the reader/gamer to create his own character, or explore themselves (however briefly), a writer as good as Asimov (or numerous others) creates a world so real you believe yourself a part of it. As far as feelings of reality, I prefer the latter.
I began it a second time, but only a few pages, so I'm not sure if I "achieved" further. I'd presume I received around 1/10th of the achievements. This presumably means one of two things: 1) either the story branched so often that, even with substantial overlap in story, there were perhaps in excess of 20 endings (seemingly too many to consider equally), or 2) the story was far more fleshed out for a prefered reader/gamer type, and I was not among them. (I don't understand the purpose behind having achievements in this game, except as a selling tool. Why create a "loser" scenario (OR winner) in a game marketed as being an individualistic world? "Personal choice"="wrong choice"?)
This felt less to me a story OR game, and more like a personality test, perhaps as component of a thesis. I admit, by far the majority of the time I spent was in contemplation of what the character I created might actually do if he were real. While the other characters I was given were extremely superficial, I still felt a strong obligation to create as real, AND as good, a world as possible for them to participate in. But despite MY agonizing over choices, I felt the writer rapidly lost interest in my character as I made less "literary" choices. He simply ended the story with no resolution of any kind, leaving the lead character to complete his participation several short paragraphs after life-extending, life-affirming choices. While I anticipated fighting for life using robotics as tool/metaphor, the majority of the story remaining as life choices are considered/corrected, instead I was reading the last paragraph on the final page. The overwhelming feeling was one of abandonment, much like Mary Shelley wrote of Dr. Frankenstein feeling for his creation. Except that the abandonment was of OUR jointly created world.
Quite possibly this game/story simply wasn't written for me. Perhaps if I were educated or intelligent, or imagined greatness, there might have been some AMAZING stories in this game. Instead I'm just a regular guy with personal dreams of home, hearth and health (albeit, while dealing with greatness would be for me, a GREAT story to create, or better still, to participate in.) I've read those other people's accounts lived out THOUSANDS of times in other stories. This time I wanted it to be my story. Perhaps there are choices that would have made it longer or more interesting, but then it would not have been MY story. And after all, wasn't that the whole point?
(4 JV)

13618293.review:
Wow. That was such an unexpectedly wonderful experience.

As this is a CYOA (Choose Your Own Adventure), your experience may vary, but, I say with little hesitation that [i]my own[/i] experience with the story is the most meaningful experience I've had with a game - ever.

Although wonderful in their own right, choice oriented games like The Walking Dead and Mass Effect don't even come close to what this game accomplishes.

[h1]What Choice Do I Have?[/h1]

CoR gives you choices.

CoR gives you lots of choices that make the story feel like your own, fostering immersion in a way that traditional literature cannot.

CoR gives you lots of difficult choices that may have you thinking hard and agonizing about the potential consequences. The game has no manual save function. If you make choices that lead to a premature ending, you can't undo and must start over. (such branches seem rare, though, and replaying doesn't take much time once you're familiar with the text)

CoR gives you lots of difficult choices that have a real impact. Something that is uniquely possible when the creator is unconstrained by the need to create full art assets for every possibility.

[h1]Deep Dive[/h1]

This "game" has no graphics at all except for the cover image, which is exactly akin to a book cover illustration. Is it a game or a book? I say it is most certainly a game. Graphics is not a requirement of a game. Interactivity is. A series of choices that impact the experience do a game comprise.

CoR's language is competent, but not "literary". It reads like a matter-of-fact narrative of events that might actually happen in your life if the stars align in just the right way. Initially, I got an "amateur" vibe from the writing, but later realized that the experience may actually benefit from the simple, contemporary writing style. As the story progressed and sucked me in deeper, I became much too busy thinking about what was going on to criticize the writing style.

CoR is (mostly) accessible. Although the fact that it was written by somebody with a Ph.D. in Computer Science does show. Having a CS degree myself, I certainly appreciated that perspective. Although lots of artistic license is taken for the sake of plot, there is lots of grounding in contemporary technology.

The story makes mostly "reasonable" extrapolations starting from the near future forward several decades. Like all good science (or 'speculative', if you prefer) fiction, the story poignantly references the present while writing about the future, framing the timeless human condition in extrapolated contexts.

To elaborate about why I put "reasonable" in quotation marks above, the story explores the future in ways that could, for the most part, conceivably happen, and many futurists would even claim that CoR's extrapolation towards the Singularity doesn't go far enough. However, the author is not afraid to explore fantastic scenarios that probably won't happen, at least not soon, and in some cases, hopefully never.

The scope of the story is indeed quite epic, following the main decades of a lifetime of the character you control. I do have to object to the game description's categorization of this as a "novel", though, as it is not nearly long enough to count as one. At best, it is the length of a (very) short story (a single playthrough takes a matter of hours). On the other hand, the sheer amount of content of all possible branches easily exceed the length of a long novel (50% longer than Moby Dick). It's quite an accomplishment.

And, if you are worried about this being a boring, technical slog, don't be. Despite the apparently sterile subject matter of robots, there is plenty of emotion in this game - or, at least, there can be, depending on your choices.

[h1]Turn to Page 23[/h1]

I've only explored one of the many, distinct branches of CoR. I will probably be going back to explore the others.

I heartily recommend CoR to anyone who can read English, especially those with an interest in technology and/or science fiction.

Note that there is also a free demo where you can play through the first 2 chapters (out of 7), either via Steam, or on the developer's web site.

[h1]UPDATES[/h1]

Having now explored a few other branches and having made more "optimal" choices, I feel that choosing less optimally for the first playthrough does make for a better experience.

My first playthrough involved an above average number of failures and tragedies, which amounted to a much more poignant experience than when everything basically goes well.

I do suggest playing the game "organically". Perhaps it is unlikely to play optimally the first time around anyway. Certainly I would discourage any attempts to "cheat" by looking up optimal choices beforehand. That would truly ruin the experience. You can always go back later and "fix mistakes" on subsequent playthroughs.

13606891.review:
I was recommended (and later gifted) Choice of Robots by a friend.  I'm a huge Transformers fan, so a game entirely revolving around the idea of playing a character that creates robots and the impact/influence that has on the world immediately grabbed my attention.  I tried the demo, and was hooked.

I'd never heard of the developer, "Choice of Games" before now, but their other works are of a similar vein.  All of them are basically text-based CYOA (Choose Your Own Adventure) games, much like the old CYOA books of our childhood.  You play a character is can be like, or unlike yourself, and progress through a series of choices that can have a variety of branches, leading the story's eventual conclusion.

"Choice of Robots" follows the life of a young college student, trying to build their own robot.  It starts with a cryptic dream sequence (an excellent plot hook I might add), before going into 'character creation', which consists of selecting a name (either a custom one, or chosen from a list), and your gender.  (I should note, you can only select 'boy' or 'girl', so NB people don't get an option, sorry!)  From there, you make choices which influence a variety of stats (which can be easily checked), including your Fame, Wealth, status of your relationship with the NPCs, and other numerical values.  The status screen even gives you a summary of all the completed chapters so far, sort of an abridged version of your story.

The writing is well done.  It's vague enough that you can easily imagine events or people in your head as you would want them to be, while still giving them enough detail that it's not a complete blank space.  There's a template, and you can fill the gaps.  The way the game interprets your choices is quite fascinating too.  Even small, seemingly insignificant choices can influence future areas.  Not all influences turn out to be significant, but it does address and acknowledge choices you've made, so it feels like you're having a greater push on the story.

However, for all of the game's interactivity and originality, it falls (sometimes painfully) flat in a few areas.  The biggest and probably most damning thing, is the lack of a save/load function.  It autosaves your progress, so if you need to take a break, you can shut it down, go do something else, come back, and immediately jump back in.  And with the summary in status, you can easily determine where you're at.  But without a hard save function, you literally have to start completely over to experiment with new branches and decisions.  This does give a sense of finality and weight to the story, since you can't save-scum for an "ideal" outcome (to whatever degree a player would consider 'ideal anyway), but it makes trying out different decisions painfully tedious, as you have to start over totally anew each time.

This leads to the second issue, and one that most adventure games always fall into, and was the trap of the CYOA-genre: replayability.  While Choice of Robots has a LOT of variation, after a while you do start to notice the patterns.  You'll start to know which options lead to what future choices.  Eventually, it probably becomes second-nature what sort of paths lead to a particular ending.

Which ironically enough, leads to a sub-issue of this problem.  While some of the patterns are obvious, others are not.  Painfully not.  There's a few branches I have NO idea how to access, because the options you'd need aren't very obvious, and the achievement descriptions don't help at ALL.  And as there's no guides, it's a constant stream of trial and error.  This also hurts in-game.  It's not always obvious how good (or bad) a stat should be to elicit a particular response, or to enable particular choices, which again, can only be determined through trial and error, and a LOT of it.  So be prepared that if you're someone who really wants to earn/unlock everything, it'll take some time.

The NPCs tend to suffer as well.  As the story focuses on your avatar and his creation, the NPCs, while recieving a modicum of development, don't really tend to be more than accessories to the overall story.  There's a variety of them, and story does do justice to fleshing them out at times, but after a point they sort of fall into scripted roles and don't really contribute to the story beyond being names.  And scripting can be a problem as well.  There's a few milestones you simply cannot avoid, and a few events where you would think there should be a third option or a way to avoid having to go A or B, but none exist.

Even with these issues, Choice of Robots is an excellent game considering you can get it for under 3 dollars right now (until the sale ends after New Years anyway).  I would highly recommend it to anyone who:

- Wants a fun little diversion from the madness of Triple-A games
- Loves robots
- Enjoys the CYOA genre
- Has a few bucks to spare

Probably my most favorite 'Choice of Games' game yet, right beside [i] Choice of the Deathless [/i]. To be honest, I started the game off not too into it, disliking how the game opened up and unsure of what to expect and whether I'd enjoy the story. After a few pages into it, I fell in love with it, and consequently my little robot child. 

As other reviewers have said already said, it's hard not to give away any story spoilers while discussing PROs and CONs, but I'll give it a shot.

The game does a great job of giving you several ways to navigate throughout the story, while making each story "branch" or "path" just as detailed as the others you passed over. While some of these CYOA games feel like choosing one option over the other is only to gain/change some stat, with little variance in the rest of the story, [i] Choice of Robots [/i] does not do this. It's also incredibly written, with just enough detail to help you envision the story, while giving your brain the freedom to "fill in the holes" to your desire on how something/someone looks. For example, you design a robot specifically pick out certain components/aspects of it that give you a general basis of how it looks. However, someone else may have picked the same exact makeup of their robot but imagine it differntly in their head because the writing leaves things purposefuly open for you to imagine.


In short, if you really enjoy scifi writing and the idea of advanced robots in the near future, you'll absolutely love this game. Even if you don't, like me, you'll probably still end up enjoying it and admire it for the plot and detailed writing.
If you hate CYOA games, which is totally fine, .... yeah you probably won't enjoy it. But you wouldn't be reading this review if you absolutely hated them would you? I don't know. I'm done.

13554434.review:
I'm a pretty big "Choice Of Games" booster. I've played most of them, including the Hosted Games. They're fun to play around with and some have pretty good writing. However, most of them don't live up to the concept of being a choose-your-own-adventure. Instead, they are more like customizable linear narratives. There are things that are always going to happen, you can't avoid them, all you're changing is your reaction or the broad methods you use to complete the scenarios.

Choice of Robots is easily the best CoG release. That core that exists in all CoG works is present in Robots. There are plot points you always hit, but they are more like the screws to the narrative, not the meat of it. Your choices mean a lot in Robots. The story and specifics change based on your choices. YOU, the PC, feel like much more of a character than in other CoG stuff. You feel more drawn in. The customization, the impact of choices, gives the game an insane amount replayability. Where other CoG games have you skimming through the text on replays to find the one paragraph that has changed since the last time, with this one the changes are in your face. You will experience radically different stories each time.

Secondary characters are always pretty weak in CoG games. They're not spectacular here, but they are better than usual. The romantic interests in CoG works are quite often non-characters. They tend to be little more than some text in your stat window. Here they have a little more character, picking one person over another will lead to minor events playing out differently. It's a good step that is small, but noticeable.

There's one problem with Choice of Robots (unless you consider the game being text only a problem and if that's the case you don't need to read this review to know if the game is for you) and that the lack of a save of any kind. This is standard for CoG and in the past it hasn't been too much of a problem. Here, I find it bothersome. Possibly, because in Choice of Robots it feels more like a "Game Over" than a "The End."  If the possibility of death was more prominent in the game, if it made things more tense, if it were anything more than just a narrative possibility it would be much less annoying. If you're OCD, you have to go back and try to recreate your game exactly to get back to that point.

If you're a fan of reading, a fan of CYOAs, if your favorite part of RPGs is dialogue trees, then Choice of Robots is the perfect game for you.

13532914.review:
I'm passionate about (some of my friends would say obsessed with) robots and I like CYOAs (Choose Your Own Adventure). This made Choice of Robots a must-buy for me and so far I'm not disappointed. Definately recommended for people who like robots or soft sci-fi and who are interested in CYOA games.

For the computer I actually prefer my CYOAs in the form of interactive fiction/text adventures (like Zork, Spider and Web, or Suspended which also prominently features robots). That way the choices can become sort of puzzles and the player can have more freedom over what to do and if it's done well can lead to awesome "wow the devs thought of everything!" moments. I think Choice of Robots would also have benefitted by that form and the freedom that comes with it, especially together with its neat stat system for your robots.
The freedom of choice in the game is still reasonably good. You usually get about 3 or 4 options to choose from and most of the time they are very different from each other and every option changes the course of the game quite a bit, giving a lot of replayability.
However some big events will always or at least almost always happen at a certain point in the story as far as I can tell so far. They usually play out in a different way, depending on your choices, though.

What hurts the replayability a bit is the saving system: When you close the game while in the middle of the story, you continue at the point you had reached once you start the game again but there's no option to manually save a game state or undo a choice. Arguably this makes your choices more "meaningful". But sometimes it would be nice to be able to go back and see what happens if I had done X instead of Y in an otherwise unchanged path without going through all the same choices that came before again.
It would also help with a few choices that are worded a little too vague but the majority is worded in a way that makes it more or less obvious what your character is going to do, so that point is not a big deal.

The story and the writing itself are nice and I enjoyed all of my playthroughs so far. You start by building your robot after your own specifications, continue to develop it depending on your choices and possibly even change the course of the whole world.
You can be a misunderstood genius living in your mother's basement, CEO of a multi-million dollar robot company, try to take over the world as a mustache-twirling mad scientist, or even transcend humanity towards a life as machine.
Personally, I would have liked inclusion of at least some more common robot tropes, like assigning basic laws (Asimov's, others or none) to the robots or being able to pursue creating pure AIs but you can't have everything.
There were only a couple things I didn't like but they are little details and come down to personal preferences. 
One is the mention of actual brand names for some things (like alienware or Dr Dre's headphones). I get that they probably help to characterize some of the characters but I feel like that's a missed opportunity to use the scifi genre to full effect by inventing new original devices and imagine how today's technology could develop.
Granted, the game takes place in the not-so-distant future of 2019 but there are also already sentient robots and flying cars.

Another thing: in several spots (most prominently character descriptions) the game appears to have been written with "political correctness" always in mind. I don't want to discuss PC in general at this place but I think that it doesn't work well as a literary device in a piece of fiction and grinding down the edges, so to speak, hurts the storytelling. Again this is a matter of preferences, just know what you're getting into if you're absolutely allergic against those kinds of things.
In the same vein some political aspects of the story seem a bit loaded (especially when the military, the US, or money is involved). The game is never preachy about any of this, it just seems a bit ham-fisted in some parts. 
Anyway the game is not a political or economical simulator but an interactive story about robots and it does that point well, so that are only minor points. If nothing of this bothers you, Choice of Robots is a great COYA game.
7/10

High quality writing and an abundance of choices that influence how the story plays out. Even choices that don't seem to be all that important can alter the outcome quite a bit.

You should bring the patience to read large amounts of text - obviously - but it's well worth it. The writing is really good and offers not only a nice technical perspective on AI and robotics but also some philosophical insights about life and humanity.

Parts of the story are based on logical extrapolation of current political relationships and events, which makes those parts seem a real possibility for the future and not just some lazy fantasy.

Everyone who is interested in AI and robotics and is not afraid of reading should buy this. Everyone else should at least take a look at the demo before simply skipping this game altogether.

13490120.review:
Choice of Robots is the, as of now, latest installment of the series of text adventures called Choice of Games, complete with the series' usual tropes and occasionally annoyances. If you're familiar with these games or enjoy text adventures in general, then it's simple: pick this one up, it's the best installment yet. If you're not however, it's as good a starting point as any, especially when there's a free demo that adequately presents what the game entails.

Robots is about crafting, growing and teaching your own personal robot, and for someone familiar with the Choice of Games series, that's all you really need to know. Besides the wildly varied tone and settings, the majority of these games function nearly identically.  For those who are new, it's a text adventure, and what that boils down to is simply: You read a whole lot and make choices. There's no graphic, no music and no action (besides the ones being described with words). And if that puts you off, that's fair, still, the demo's free if you want to confirm your position.

As with most other games of the series, the choices you make influence your stats and how the story progress and, again, as with the other installments, the game encourages at least a certain degree of specializations. What is new, however, is that the protagonist have only one stat to keep track of, humanity, which tracks how kind, humane, social and emotional your decisions are. Your robot, on the other hand, has four stats: Autonomy, Military, Empathy and Grace, and the decisions you make throughout the game influence what kind of robot you will have, and, in turn, how you will influence the world. Would you end up with a mindless militaristic machine at your whim, a self-conscious and independent robotic sentient being or a curious, constantly learning robot with near (or perhaps completely) human emotions? Chances are, though, you're going to end up with a combination of all the things in between. 

While, like the other Choice of Games, Robots do strongly encourage specialization in at least one or two stats, the games do not seem to punish you as harshly for deviation from your initial plans. The other Choice of Games' strategic elements usually boil down to specializing in a number of areas and then make only decisions that test your strong points and avoid your weaknesses. Robots is similar, except you have more leeway and, in fact, planning becoming a lot more difficult as decisions often have unforeseen consequences. For example, there's a point in the game where you are able to make a decision on what kind of information you want your robot to extract on the internet, and allowing it to pick up whatever it wants result in it learning things like "Big Brother is watching" and "the US is the bad guy", resulting in a substantial raise in intelligence (Autonomy) and a distrust of authority (Military). There's also a point in the game where your robot is interviewed, and if your Autonomy is high enough, the review will claim your robot is smarter than humans, giving it a boost in confidence (Autonomy) while making it more arrogant (decrease in Empathy). While the unpredictability of the gameplay structure here may hamper cold strategic decision making, it also makes the story more spontaneous and exciting, as your choices can have truly unforeseeable consequences later in the game, making the narrative incredibly dynamic. That said, depending on what you choose to focus on, the game can also end up rather difficult, requiring multiple restarts, which is even more frustrating considering the fact that the game has no manual save whatsoever, forcing a restart every time you want to change something. I believe this is to make you committed to your choices and make each playthrough special and dynamic, but I still feel that the game would benefit more from having a save system of some description, especially when you've already completed the game and don't feel like skimming through most of the story to change one decision. Robots, in particular, seems to offer more consequences and variations to your decisions than any other game in the series I've experienced (skim through the achievement list if you want to know how much you could achieve, and know that I only got 10 in one playthrough, and I thought I did pretty well). That said, personally, I don't plan on replaying the game anytime soon. This is in no way a fault of the game, but rather a strength, as I feel so attached to my first playthrough that any second attempt would feel as if I've cheated that unique experience.

But gameplay aside, this is still a text adventure, and as a game that's going to make you spend the majority of your time reading, it lives and dies on the writing. Robots, like most of its predecessor, does not disappoint in this regard. There's moment of humor, melancholy, romance (with the usual inclusiveness of the series) and, perhaps most of all, introspection. The parental relationship between you and your robot becomes clear very early on, and the game handles it extremely well. Your robot grows, imitates and reacts to your actions as you would expect, with great curiosity and bewilderment. As I watch it develops, I feel proud when it understands or questions, scared when it picks up undesirable tendencies, happy when it expresses indignant at cruelty and warm when it seems more human than any living character by the end, while still having more to learn and expressing fear of the inevitable as a child would. At least that's how it was for my Sapling (that's how I named mine, and Sapling was a she and refers to me by my real name rather than titles because that's the level of customization you have), your robot could go in so many unforeseen direction it's difficult to "plan" its development, and considering the theme, I think that's the point. The human characters, while getting less attention, are well-written and varied enough in their own right, but some, even if you choose to begin a relationship with them, will feel somewhat detached from the main storyline until the latter chapters. The game, despite its initial lightheartedness and humor, asks difficult question, present morally ambiguous choices and depicts interesting, introspective themes. The final two or three chapters are the most powerful part in the game for me because it shows the growth of your robot and how you've molded the world, for better or worse, as well as calling your ideals into question. I can only speak for myself, but my ending reflected my choices appropriately, filling me with wonder, doubt, melancholy and hope. While the game has its stronger points and weaker, more filler-y portions, the finale was undoubtedly my favorite experience of any Choice of Game story.

If you enjoy the Choice of Games text adventures, then I'll just repeat myself: Buy the damn game, it's, at least in my opinion, the best in the series yet. If you have no interest in the structure and ideas behind text adventures, then I suppose there isn't much here to convince you otherwise besides good writing. If you're new and willing to try out one of these games though, I can't think of a better place to start. Choice of Robots is inspiring, funny, well-written and introspective, and for a game about robots, it has more philosophies and humanity behind it than most games out there combined.

p.s. If you have played and enjoyed this one, do go check out the other text adventures by Choice of Games. Only a few of them are on Steam at the moment but there are quite a lot of these games on the Choice of Games website, and they all have free demos (if they aren't already free). I always thought these games don't get enough credit and exposure so please support them if you like what they're doing.

13484066.review: What a fantastic piece of futurist literature! I played the more peaceful route but was exposed directly and indirectly to the repercussions of my actions and that of others outside of my control. I was enlightened to the social, political, and economics prospective atmospheres of the future, with a large focus on the effects of introducing artificial intelligence (or lack thereof).  The relationships I developed felt more "real" than most other C.Y.O.A. games (the exception being the Heroes Rise Trilogy) and I genuinely felt bad when I pushed friends away for the sake of the growing demand for my robotic knowledge.  My ending felt a tad rushed but it may have been due to my overall decisions having little differentiation from my initial stance on robotics.  All in all, the author knows his subject very well and it shows in his writing (largely with robotic ethics and boundaries).  If you are trying to sate an urge to experience an Asimov tale, craving a 2001: A Space Odyssey journey, and/or wanting to discover what the future may hold for robotics from a modernized perspective, this game is for you. Grab it now!

13482474.review:
This is my first text adventure and I don't know if this is the correct genre but it's surely not a graphic novel. But I know that I instantly fell in love with it and that I played for almost 7 hours straight. 

Basically, if you are open for things like this and like thought experiments about creating robots or daydream about or whatever ... I can recommend it. The writing itself is really good. Yeah, I don't want to spoil anything about the story, you should just experience it for yourself. 

I found it quite mindblowing, actually. It combines the best attributes of both video games and books. You have all the possibilities books offer, such as unmatched story telling and ways to express emotions and to imagine worlds, plus the ability to make choices from video games. This makes the whole experience so special and awesome, because it gets personal, it becomes your story and every single decision actually matters (and there are many)!

If you ever were annoyed with the shallow meaningless choices most AAA games have offered until this day, well, then, go for it - you won't be disappointed. 

Yes it has no graphics and yes you definitely need to be quite imaginative to get yourself into such games - or experiences - but it's worth it. In the end, I'm just really grateful Steam opened up a niche market for these kind of games. Praise the Gaben. =)

13479412.review: It's difficult to attach yourself to an experience like this. Most I imagine would rather pick the most cathartic route and run with it. but even as your decisions veer up and down the scale, The story always retains its organic cohesion and compelling storyline. While one or two characters can be a tad two dimensional, every decision you make affects the story in wildly branching ways. for something this simple, little more than a flash text algorithm, I was left on the brink of tears in my first playthrough,  Not only do your decisions resonate, but they provide a good series of compelling arguments about the nature of artificial intelligence. This isn't a game. Nor is it a novel. It's a narrative experience that evolves beyond its initial "choose-your-own-adventrure" If you have any interest in sci fi, but worry that the lack of graphics might turn you off, I still recommend you give it a try. you might find it more engaging than you expect.

Bottom line, strong recommendation if you're a fan of science fiction novels.

This game is, quite literally, interactive fiction - and very good fiction at that. Gameplay elements are minimal: You're given a choice, possibly your robots' stats changes depending on your choice, then the story continues. The focus is clearly on the (very good!) writing.  But, and this important, your choices actually matter. And that's not a buzzword for once. It's not Mass Effect-style "choose the colour of the light beams in the ending" sense, I mean that choices matter in that you get completely different stories depending on your choices. A run takes about 30 minutes, depending on how quick a reader you are, but there are so many different branches (both minor and major) that you can easily sink hours just into exploring.

39024716.review:
[b][i][Disclaimer: Copy was gifted to me by a friend, Powerglove64, several Christmases ago.][/i][/b]

There are those who simply believe science is only about man exploring the nature of the universe, yet science is also a collective legacy of these explorers’ discoveries. From the historical remembrance of the drama between Edison vs Tesla; from the familial legacy of Irène Curie who tested the structure of the atom her parents began to explore, dying from her own research; and from the names that forever shaped the world, better or worse, such as Einstein and Fritz Haber—science is a history about people, whether of minor or major feats, making choices from their newfound knowledge that may lead to their own ruin, bring them fame, or haunt them in the future to come.  This is the essence of what makes Choice of Robots an amazing piece of interactive fiction.

Choice of Robots is the type of game I always wanted to become real, a choice-based adventure around the ambitions of science. What the Civilization games recreate in terms of history as a strategy game is what CoR conveys as a choice-based interactive fiction. It may not have the same scale or freedom, but what CoR does do exceptionally well is create a piece of interactive fiction about the accumulation of your choices. There are simply too many variables, decisions, different outcomes to explore that one playthrough is not enough to experience the whole narrative. While I may be unfamiliar to other “Choice of…” titles, if you were ever curious about their merits, then Choice of Robots would be the best place to start. 

[h1]Choices We Make Are Not Always Perfect, Though They Are the Journey[/h1]

Something that was largely apparent when playing Welcome to Moreytown alongside Choice of Robots was the overall value of every decision. There is a great difference in quality offered that not only impacts the lasting consequence and ending but the overall story you build. CoR is simply a piece of fiction made greater by its interactivity to drive its narrative than something arbitrary with no impact on every decision. This is the quality of excellence that separates novels written into a game format and stories created to be their own game. 

While the narrative is largely linear with some branching paths, the meaning you create each time is due to the sum total of your decisions around the robot you create. CoR largely takes inspirations from old CRPGs by applying stats to an interactive fiction, and the story (and game) is better because of these inclusions. Flavor-text isn’t simply arbitrary side-notes or meaningless jokes as every decision is based around four major stats that affect your creation: Empathy, Autonomy, Military and Grace. Other stats influence the narrative such as the player’s own stats of Fame, Wealth and relationships with other characters that further add value to each decision. Sometimes the game will put you and your creation at odds with one another’s future goals; sometimes the story will choose different scenes or introduce fail-states to add more variety to the story. From beginning to end, no moment feels forgotten even if the plot does not draw attention to it because the mechanics already are enough of a reminder.

All these dynamic elements, thanks largely to the smart usage of stats, create tangible value to each new playthrough, and the moments that they create such as learning empathy by playing video-games or becoming autonomous from a mistake the creator made are the memories you can recall when the journey comes to its end.

[h1]It’s Not a Question of “How?” or “When?”; It’s the Readiness for the Future[/h1]

It would be an accomplishment for Choice of Robots to simply tell a narrative in a game-format that plays to its strengths to tell its own narrative for players. The genius element behind CoR is the narrative across multiple playthroughs reaffirms what the linear structure reminds you: You cannot prevent the future from arriving, but you can shape how the future will play out.

The game largely hints at this with the idea of the Singularity of robotics where the rising development of robots becoming more human presents the outcome that robots will possess greater intelligence than their creators. Whether that is the result of superpower countries waging war, economic crises due to the robotics industry, robots becoming more than simply human, and other possibilities the game presents, the outcome always results to that conclusion. Similar to Groundhog Day, it’s the inevitability of tomorrow that makes you realize it doesn’t matter who or how that day will come to pass. The truth that you learn to accept is that it would have happened to another scientist other than yourself, and it’s how you decide to handle the situation that will determine the lasting consequences on the world. Whether you wish to accept them or not, that decision to choose or to abstain are two possibilities that are always within your control. 

This attitude is what many great scientists come to accept with the pursuit of science, even when it may be a mark of shame. As Einstein wrote before his death, “I made one great mistake in my life […] when I signed the letter to President Roosevelt recommending that the atom bombs be made; but there was some justification – the danger that the Germans would make them.” Like the atomic bomb, Choice of Robots allows you to stand on that same precipice all great scientists must face when they must choose the one future out of the many possibilities they are more comfortable to accept.    

[h1]The Closest 10/10 Recommendation I Will Ever Give[/h1]

It’s honestly difficult to think of any legitimate issues with Choice of Robots unless the thought of reading makes you want to turn away—or if you don’t find any merit behind these “Choice of…” games. No aspect of the plot, decisions or aspects you must consider feel frivolous to the narrative. The writing is remarkably charismatic in quality and the ability to connect with these characters, even if they are somewhat simple archetypes. As much as I detest review scores, it would be difficult to rate this game anything short of perfection because it manages to tell a simple story in a well-executed manner beyond the expectations of what I had of these games. There may not be anything noteworthy in its narrative or revolutionary as a piece of interactive fiction, but if execution on an idea is not the most important quality than the future should be given to robotic overlords who have more humanity than us.

I've only done a single playthrough. This is almost like a more interesting, more realistic, robot-based version of the Sims. People seem to do these sorts of reviews on the Sims games, so here are the ridiculous, entertaining, and often truly touching events that happened in my story

-started out trying to create a robot that was aware it was a robot but was capable of emotion and companionship, in the hopes of travelling the world with it as a best friend.

-accidentally started a major, violent war between China and the United States in which one of the characters was bombed to death on an aircraft carrier.

-was arrested for treason and put in prison for about three months.

-created a male robot capable of love, denied having a relationship with it for a few months, finally gave in, and remained dating but not marrying said robot until the end of the story.

-had a robotic grandchild.

This is game absolutely incredible. It admittedly started out a bit slow, but it quickly got more interesting. The writer manages to write the game in a way that, after a while, it truly does feel like you're reading a novel. The dialogue is interesting, there are events that leave you with feelings of regret and sadness, and there are events that leave you touched and joyful. I don't do reviews often, and so I'm not quite sure what else to say. But, overall, would absolutely recommend.

38940927.review:
Review with some spoilers:

1) Choice matters. Every CYOA game try to claim that choice matter but in most of them, the text is nearly identical no matter what choices you pick. There are broad difference in story flow base on dialog choice and success or fail of events base on stats but that is it. CoR is different, at least for the first part up to the end of the war. I see attention to details everywhere, text and event flow subtlety different based not only on different dialog choices but also on the stats of your robot.

For example, a broad story decision of getting funded or not and by which department depend on whether you are willing to compromise on meeting the military's requirement (dialog choice) and 20 pts in a single stats (stats). It is not the result of just selecting a dialog option, but the accumulation of all the decisions you made previously. It not only make the result feel natural, but also make the choices affecting the stats feel relevant. Choice mattered indeed.

2) Subtle changes in text that show the attention in details the author put in. For example, the night after your robot is activated, if the autonomy is high, the robot will explore on its own, otherwise (if empathy is high?) it will stay and watch you sleep. There are many more examples like this and whenever I notice them, I really appreciate the effort the author put in. It is what make the robot come alive for me. I do not see the same level of details for other CYOA games and unfortunately, only the first few chapters of CoR have this level of detail.

3) Small decisions at the start have large impact much later down the road. For example using the cellphone battery will screw you up when war with China start and it is the straw on camel back that bankrupt me on my first play through. This is a really brilliant cascading mechanics that make CoR much better than other CYOA games.

4) Feedback. The one thing I hate about CYOA games is when the game present me with bland choice A, B and C. I look at them and wonder why I should choose one over another and suspect that none of the choice have any impact. One factor that make the first part of CoR so amazing is that nearly every decision I make at the first part of the game, I can see how it affect the stats of my robot. I get feedback that let me know I am indeed making a difference.

5) List possible endings/Set a goal at the start. If your game have multiple different endings, you better let me know so I have incentives to replay the game. I also need some hints on which decisions I should make differently to get those endings because I am sure as heck not going to have the time to try every permutation of dialog choice in the hope that you have hidden an ending there. A few hidden endings are fine, but don't leave me in the dark completely. The starting dream of CoR is an excellent mechanics although the singularity hint is perhaps a bit too explicit.

CoR is of course not perfect. The story start to fall flat after the war. The attention to details is gone and I hardly feel any attachment to the companion bot I built. The most memorable part is when I taught my robot about death and even that part could have been stronger if it have connection to the first lesson on death when the father dies.

Lastly I want to add a general criticism I have for CYOA games in general. Language is imprecise. It is impossible for an author to communicate his/her intention via description and dialog options to the reader perfectly. And indeed, sometimes it is better for the communication to be intentionally vague as it allow the reader space for his/her own imagination.

However, I personally hate it when dialog options are vague on its consequences or which skill check it is trying to make. I dislike having to deduce or guess the intention of the author behind each of the dialog choice to make a decision. It is inevitable that misunderstanding occurs, or that the author's interpretation of event/choice does not match with the mine and when it happens it ruins the play through. This is especially frustrating towards the end of the game because there is no save option.
